fr: Ses soeurs faisaient aujourd'hui pour lui tout ce qu'elles pouvaient faire en l'appelant << pauvre Richard >>, mais en realite il n'avait ete rien de plus que le lourd, insensible et inutile Dick Musgrove ; n'ayant droit, vivant ou mort, qu'a ce diminutif de son nom.

eng: The real circumstances of this pathetic piece of family history were, that the Musgroves had had the ill fortune of a very troublesome, hopeless son; and the good fortune to lose him before he reached his twentieth year;
fr: La verite de cette pathetique histoire etait que les Musgrove avaient eu le malheur d'avoir un fils mauvais sujet, et la chance de le perdre avant qu'il eut atteint sa vingtieme annee.

eng: He had been several years at sea, and had, in the course of those removals to which all midshipmen are liable, and especially such midshipmen as every captain wishes to get rid of, been six months on board Captain Frederick Wentworth's frigate, the Laconia; and from the Laconia he had, under the influence of his captain, written the only two letters which his father and mother had ever received from him during the whole of his absence; that is to say, the only two disinterested letters; all the rest had been mere applications for money.
fr: Il avait ete plusieurs annees en mer, et dans le cours de ces changements frequents pour les mousses dont le capitaine desire se debarrasser, il avait ete six mois sur la fregate Laconia, commandee par le capitaine Frederic Wenvorth, et sous l'influence de ce dernier, il avait ecrit a ses parents les deux seules lettres desinteressees qu'ils eussent jamais recues de lui ; les autres n'etaient que des demandes d'argent.

eng: In each letter he had spoken well of his captain; but yet, so little were they in the habit of attending to such matters, so unobservant and incurious were they as to the names of men or ships, that it had made scarcely any impression at the time; and that Mrs Musgrove should have been suddenly struck, this very day, with a recollection of the name of Wentworth, as connected with her son, seemed one of those extraordinary bursts of mind which do sometimes occur.
fr: Il disait toujours du bien de son capitaine, mais ses parents s'en souciaient si peu qu'ils n'y avaient fait aucune attention, et si Mme Musgrove fut frappee par le nom de Wenvorth associe avec celui de son fils, c'etait par un de ces phenomenes de la memoire assez frequents chez les personnes distraites.

eng: She had gone to her letters, and found it all as she supposed; and the re-perusal of these letters, after so long an interval, her poor son gone for ever, and all the strength of his faults forgotten, had affected her spirits exceedingly, and thrown her into greater grief for him than she had known on first hearing of his death.
fr: Elle avait relu les lettres de ce fils perdu pour toujours, et cette lecture, apres un si long intervalle, alors que les fautes etaient oubliees, l'avait affectee plus profondement que la nouvelle de sa mort.

eng: Mr Musgrove was, in a lesser degree, affected likewise; and when they reached the cottage, they were evidently in want, first, of being listened to anew on this subject, and afterwards, of all the relief which cheerful companions could give them.
fr: M. Musgrove l'etait aussi, mais a un moindre degre, et en arrivant au cottage ils avaient besoin d'etre ecoutes et egayes.

eng: To hear them talking so much of Captain Wentworth, repeating his name so often, puzzling over past years, and at last ascertaining that it might, that it probably would, turn out to be the very same Captain Wentworth whom they recollected meeting, once or twice, after their coming back from Clifton--a very fine young man--but they could not say whether it was seven or eight years ago, was a new sort of trial to Anne's nerves.
fr: Ce fut une nouvelle epreuve pour Anna d'entendre parler de Wenvorth, et repeter son nom si souvent, d'entendre disputer sur les dates, et affirmer enfin que ce ne pouvait etre que le capitaine Wenvorth, ce beau jeune homme qu'on avait rencontre plusieurs fois en revenant de Clifton huit annees auparavant.

eng: She found, however, that it was one to which she must inure herself.
fr: Elle vit qu'il fallait s'accoutumer a ce supplice, et tacher de devenir insensible a cette arrivee.

eng: Since he actually was expected in the country, she must teach herself to be insensible on such points.
fr: Non seulement il etait attendu prochainement, mais les Musgrove, reconnaissants des bontes qu'il avait eues pour leur fils, et pleins de respect pour le caractere que Dick leur avait depeint, desiraient vivement faire sa connaissance.

eng: And not only did it appear that he was expected, and speedily, but the Musgroves, in their warm gratitude for the kindness he had shewn poor Dick, and very high respect for his character, stamped as it was by poor Dick's having been six months under his care, and mentioning him in strong, though not perfectly well-spelt praise, as "a fine dashing felow, only two perticular about the schoolmaster," were bent on introducing themselves, and seeking his acquaintance, as soon as they could hear of his arrival.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The resolution of doing so helped to form the comfort of their evening.
fr: Cette resolution contribua a leur faire passer une soiree agreable.

eng: Chapter 7
fr: CHAPITRE VII

eng: A very few days more, and Captain Wentworth was known to be at Kellynch, and Mr Musgrove had called on him, and come back warm in his praise, and he was engaged with the Crofts to dine at Uppercross, by the end of another week.
fr: Quelques jours plus tard, on sut que le capitaine etait a Kellynch. M. Musgrove lui fit visite et revint enchante. Il l'avait invite a diner avec les Croft pour la semaine suivante, et n'avait pu, a son grand regret, fixer un jour plus rapproche.

eng: It was an afternoon of distress, and Anne had every thing to do at once; the apothecary to send for, the father to have pursued and informed, the mother to support and keep from hysterics, the servants to control, the youngest child to banish, and the poor suffering one to attend and soothe; besides sending, as soon as she recollected it, proper notice to the other house, which brought her an accession rather of frightened, enquiring companions, than of very useful assistants.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But a week must pass; only a week, in Anne's reckoning, and then, she supposed, they must meet; and soon she began to wish that she could feel secure even for a week.
fr: Anna calcula qu'elle n'avait plus qu'une semaine de tranquillite ; mais elle faillit rencontrer le capitaine, qui rendit aussitot a M. Musgrove sa visite.

eng: So here he is to go away and enjoy himself, and because I am the poor mother, I am not to be allowed to stir; and yet, I am sure, I am more unfit than anybody else to be about the child.
fr: Ainsi, il va s'amuser, et parce que je suis la pauvre mere, il ne m'est pas permis de bouger ; et cependant je suis moins capable que personne de soigner l'enfant.

eng: I did not think Charles would have been so unfeeling.
fr: Je ne croyais pas Charles si egoiste.

eng: Talks of his being going on so well! How does he know that he is going on well, or that there may not be a sudden change half an hour hence?
fr: Il dit qu'il va mieux. Sait-il s'il n'y aura point un changement soudain, dans une demi-heure ?

eng: Very unfeeling! I must say it is very unfeeling of him to be running away from his poor little boy.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: This is always my luck. If there is anything disagreeable going on men are always sure to get out of it, and Charles is as bad as any of them.
fr: Charles ne vaut pas mieux que les autres. Il n'a pas de coeur ; laisser ainsi son pauvre petit garcon !

eng: She said nothing, therefore, till he was out of the room, but as soon as there was only Anne to hear-- "So you and I are to be left to shift by ourselves, with this poor sick child; and not a creature coming near us all the evening! I knew how it would be.
fr: << Ainsi on nous laisse seules nous distraire comme nous pourrons avec ce pauvre enfant malade, et pas une ame pour nous tenir compagnie le soir. Je le prevoyais ; je n'ai pas de chance ; s'il survient une chose desagreable, les hommes s'en dispensent.

eng: Mary knew, from Charles's manner of speaking, that he was quite determined on going, and that it would be of no use to teaze him.
fr: Marie vit que Charles etait decide a partir. Elle ne dit rien, mais aussitot qu'elle fut seule avec Anna :

eng: Husbands and wives generally understand when opposition will be vain.
fr: Les femmes comprennent generalement quand l'opposition est inutile.

eng: "Nothing can be going on better than the child," said he; "so I told my father, just now, that I would come, and he thought me quite right. Your sister being with you, my love, I have no scruple at all. You would not like to leave him yourself, but you see I can be of no use. Anne will send for me if anything is the matter."
fr: << Votre soeur est avec vous, ma chere, et vous-meme, vous n'aimeriez pas a quitter l'enfant. Je suis inutile ici, Anna m'enverra chercher s'il est necessaire. ~~~ >>

eng: His father very much wished him to meet Captain Wentworth, and there being no sufficient reason against it, he ought to go; and it ended in his making a bold, public declaration, when he came in from shooting, of his meaning to dress directly, and dine at the other house.
fr: D'ailleurs son pere desirait beaucoup le presenter a Wenvorth. Au retour de la chasse, il declara audacieusement qu'il allait s'habiller et diner chez son pere.

eng: This was quite a female case, and it would be highly absurd in him, who could be of no use at home, to shut himself up.
fr: C'etait l'affaire d'une femme, et ce serait absurde a lui de s'enfermer a la maison.

eng: The child was to be kept in bed and amused as quietly as possible; but what was there for a father to do?
fr: Mais que pouvait faire le pere ?

eng: It had been a great disappointment to Mr Musgrove to find that no earlier day could be fixed, so impatient was he to shew his gratitude, by seeing Captain Wentworth under his own roof, and welcoming him to all that was strongest and best in his cellars.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It must be a work of time to ascertain that no injury had been done to the spine; but Mr Robinson found nothing to increase alarm, and Charles Musgrove began, consequently, to feel no necessity for longer confinement.
fr: L'enfant devait rester couche, et s'amuser aussi tranquillement que possible.

eng: Charles Musgrove, indeed, afterwards, shewed more of inclination; "the child was going on so well, and he wished so much to be introduced to Captain Wentworth, that, perhaps, he might join them in the evening; he would not dine from home, but he might walk in for half an hour."
fr: Mais bientot Charles changea d'avis ; puisque l'enfant allait si bien, il pouvait aller passer une heure a Great-House apres le diner.

eng: "Oh no; as to leaving the little boy," both father and mother were in much too strong and recent alarm to bear the thought; and Anne, in the joy of the escape, could not help adding her warm protestations to theirs.
fr: Ils ne voudraient sans doute pas quitter l'enfant. << Oh ! ~~~ non, >> s'ecrierent le pere et la mere.

eng: The same story and the same raptures were repeated, when the two girls came with their father, through the gloom of the evening, to make enquiries; and Mr Musgrove, no longer under the first uneasiness about his heir, could add his confirmation and praise, and hope there would be now no occasion for putting Captain Wentworth off, and only be sorry to think that the cottage party, probably, would not like to leave the little boy, to give him the meeting.
fr: La meme histoire et les memes ravissements se repeterent le soir, quand elles vinrent avec leur pere prendre des nouvelles de l'enfant. M. Musgrove confirma ces louanges. Il ne pouvait reculer l'invitation faite le matin au capitaine, et regrettait que les habitants du cottage ne pussent venir aussi.

eng: And in short, he had looked and said everything with such exquisite grace, that they could assure them all, their heads were both turned by him; and off they ran, quite as full of glee as of love, and apparently more full of Captain Wentworth than of little Charles.
fr: Elles s'echapperent en courant, plus occupees du capitaine que du petit garcon.

eng: How glad they had been to hear papa invite him to stay dinner, how sorry when he said it was quite out of his power, and how glad again when he had promised in reply to papa and mamma's farther pressing invitations to come and dine with them on the morrow--actually on the morrow; and he had promised it in so pleasant a manner, as if he felt all the motive of their attention just as he ought.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: staying five minutes behind their father and mother, to endeavour to express how perfectly delighted they were with him, how much handsomer, how infinitely more agreeable they thought him than any individual among their male acquaintance, who had been at all a favourite before.
fr: Il avait accepte d'une maniere charmante, comme s'il comprenait le motif de cette politesse. Il avait parle et agi avec une grace si exquise, qu'il leur avait tourne la tete.

eng: Till he came and had examined the child, their apprehensions were the worse for being vague; they suspected great injury, but knew not where; but now the collar-bone was soon replaced, and though Mr Robinson felt and felt, and rubbed, and looked grave, and spoke low words both to the father and the aunt, still they were all to hope the best, and to be able to part and eat their dinner in tolerable ease of mind; and then it was, just before they parted, that the two young aunts were able so far to digress from their nephew's state, as to give the information of Captain Wentworth's visit;
fr: Cependant il donna bon espoir, et l'on put aller diner plus tranquillement. Les deux jeunes filles resterent quelques instants apres le depart de leurs parents pour raconter la visite du capitaine ; dire combien elles etaient enchantees et contentes que leur pere l'eut invite a diner pour le lendemain.

eng: Her brother's return was the first comfort; he could take best care of his wife; and the second blessing was the arrival of the apothecary.
fr: Le retour de son beau-frere la soulagea beaucoup ; il pouvait au moins prendre soin de sa femme. Le docteur examina l'enfant, remit la fracture et parla ensuite a voix basse et d'un air inquiet au pere et a la mere.

eng: His collar-bone was found to be dislocated, and such injury received in the back, as roused the most alarming ideas.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The child's situation put the visit entirely aside; but she could not hear of her escape with indifference, even in the midst of the serious anxiety which they afterwards felt on his account.
fr: On revint en toute hate.  ~~~ Anna dut etre partout a la fois, chercher le docteur, avertir le pere, s'occuper de la mere pour empecher une attaque de nerfs, diriger les domestiques, renvoyer le plus jeune enfant, soigner et soulager le pauvre malade, enfin donner des nouvelles aux Musgrove, dont l'arrivee lui donna plus d'embarras que d'aide.

eng: She and Mary were actually setting forward for the Great House, where, as she afterwards learnt, they must inevitably have found him, when they were stopped by the eldest boy's being at that moment brought home in consequence of a bad fall.
fr: Elle et Marie se dirigeaient vers Great-House quand on vint leur dire que l'aine des petits garcons avait fait une chute grave : l'enfant avait une luxation de la colonne vertebrale.

eng: Captain Wentworth made a very early return to Mr Musgrove's civility, and she was all but calling there in the same half hour.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The child had a good night, and was going on well the next day.
fr: L'enfant eut une bonne nuit et alla mieux le lendemain ; le docteur ne voyait rien d'alarmant, et Charles commenca a trouver inutile de se sequestrer ainsi.

eng: But in this he was eagerly opposed by his wife, with "Oh! no, indeed, Charles, I cannot bear to have you go away. Only think if anything should happen?"
fr: Mais sa femme s'y opposa : << Oh ! non, Charles, je ne souffrirai pas que vous sortiez. ~~~ Si quelque chose arrivait ! >>

eng: My being the mother is the very reason why my feelings should not be tried.
fr: Precisement parce que je suis sa mere, on ne devrait pas me mettre a une telle epreuve.

eng: and indeed, Mary, I cannot wonder at your husband. Nursing does not belong to a man; it is not his province.
fr: Vraiment, Marie, je ne suis pas surprise que votre mari soit sorti. Ce n'est pas l'affaire des hommes.

eng: I have not nerves for the sort of thing.
fr: Je n'ai pas la patience qu'il faut pour cela.

eng: I am not at all equal to it.
fr: Je ne suis pas de force a la supporter.

eng: You saw how hysterical I was yesterday.
fr: Vous savez combien j'ai souffert des nerfs hier ?

eng: But that was only the effect of the suddenness of your alarm--of the shock. You will not be hysterical again. I dare say we shall have nothing to distress us.
fr: C'etait l'effet d'une commotion soudaine ; j'espere que rien n'arrivera qui puisse nous effrayer.

eng: I perfectly understand Mr Robinson's directions, and have no fears;
fr: J'ai bien compris les instructions du docteur, et je ne crains rien.

eng: A sick child is always the mother's property: her own feelings generally make it so.
fr: Il me semble que je suis aussi bonne mere qu'une autre ; mais ma presence n'est pas plus utile ici que celle de Charles.

eng: I hope I am as fond of my child as any mother, but I do not know that I am of any more use in the sick-room than Charles, for I cannot be always scolding and teazing the poor child when it is ill;
fr: Je ne puis pas toujours gronder et tourmenter un pauvre petit malade.

eng: and you saw, this morning, that if I told him to keep quiet, he was sure to begin kicking about.
fr: Vous avez vu, ce matin, quand je lui disais de se tenir tranquille, il s'est mis a donner des coups de pied autour de lui.

eng: But, could you be comfortable yourself, to be spending the whole evening away from the poor boy?
fr: Seriez-vous tranquille si vous passiez votre soiree loin de lui ?

eng: Yes; you see his papa can, and why should not I? Jemima is so careful; and she could send us word every hour how he was.
fr: Pourquoi non ? ~~~ son pere le fait bien. Jemina certainement est si soigneuse.

eng: I really think Charles might as well have told his father we would all come.
fr: Charles aurait pu dire a son pere que nous irions tous.

eng: I am not more alarmed about little Charles now than he is. I was dreadfully alarmed yesterday, but the case is very different to-day.
fr: Je ne suis pas plus inquiete que lui. Hier, c'etait bien different, mais aujourd'hui ! ~~~

eng: Well, if you do not think it too late to give notice for yourself, suppose you were to go, as well as your husband. Leave little Charles to my care. Mr and Mrs Musgrove cannot think it wrong while I remain with him.
fr: Eh bien ! si vous croyez qu'il n'est pas trop tard pour avertir, laissez-moi soigner le petit Charles. M. et Mme Musgrove ne trouveront pas mauvais que je reste avec lui.

eng: "Are you serious?"
fr: -- Parlez-vous serieusement ?

eng: '"Dear me! that's a very good thought, very good, indeed."'
fr: 'Mon Dieu quelle bonne idee ! En verite, autant que j'y aille.'

eng: 'You, who have not a mother's feelings, are a great deal the properest person.'
fr: 'Vous n'avez pas les sentiments d'une mere : vous etes la personne qu'il faut.'

eng: 'To be sure, I may just as well go as not, for I am of no use at home--am I?'
fr: 'Je ne sers a rien ici, n'est-ce pas ?'

eng: 'cried Mary, her eyes brightening.'
fr: 'dit Marie les yeux brillants.'

eng: 'and it only harasses me.'
fr: 'et cela me tourmente.'

eng: 'You can make little Charles do anything; he always minds you at a word.'
fr: 'Jules vous obeit au moindre mot.'

eng: 'It will be a great deal better than leaving him only with Jemima.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'Oh! I shall certainly go; I am sure I ought if I can, quite as much as Charles,'
fr: 'Ah ! bien certainement j'irai, car on desire beaucoup que je fasse connaissance avec le capitaine,'

eng: 'for they want me excessively to be acquainted with Captain Wentworth,'
fr: 'et cela ne vous fait rien de rester seule.'

eng: 'and I know you do not mind being left alone.'
fr: 'Quelle excellente idee !'

eng: 'An excellent thought of yours, indeed, Anne.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'I will go and tell Charles, and get ready directly.'
fr: 'Je vais le dire a Charles, et je serai bientot prete.'

eng: You can send for us, you know, at a moment's notice, if anything is the matter; but I dare say there will be nothing to alarm you.
fr: Vous nous enverrez chercher, s'il le faut, mais j'espere que rien d'alarmant ne surviendra.

eng: I should not go, you may be sure, if I did not feel quite at ease about my dear child."
fr: Je n'irais pas, croyez-le bien, si je n'etais tout a fait tranquille sur mon cher enfant.

eng: Had he wished ever to see her again, he need not have waited till this time; he would have done what she could not but believe that in his place she should have done long ago, when events had been early giving him the independence which alone had been wanting.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The next moment she was tapping at her husband's dressing-room door, and as Anne followed her up stairs, she was in time for the whole conversation, which began with Mary's saying, in a tone of great exultation-- "I mean to go with you, Charles, for I am of no more use at home than you are.
fr: >> Elle alla frapper a la porte de son mari, et Anna l'entendit dire d'un ton joyeux : << Je vais avec vous, Charles, car je ne suis pas plus necessaire que vous ici.

eng: If I were to shut myself up for ever with the child, I should not be able to persuade him to do anything he did not like.
fr: Si je m'enfermais toujours avec l'enfant, je n'aurais aucune influence sur lui.

eng: He must be either indifferent or unwilling.
fr: S'il avait desire la revoir, il n'aurait pas attendu jusque-la, puisque les evenements lui avaient donne l'independance qui lui manquait d'abord.

eng: It is Anne's own proposal, and so I shall go with you, which will be a great deal better, for I have not dined at the other house since Tuesday."
fr: Elle me l'a propose elle-meme. Ainsi, je vais avec vous, ce qui sera beaucoup mieux, car je n'ai pas dine a Great-House depuis mardi.

eng: "This is very kind of Anne," was her husband's answer, "and I should be very glad to have you go; but it seems rather hard that she should be left at home by herself, to nurse our sick child."
fr: -- Anna est bien bonne, repondit son mari, je suis fort content que vous y alliez. Mais n'est-il pas bien dur de la laisser seule a la maison pour garder notre enfant malade ? >>

eng: Anne was now at hand to take up her own cause, and the sincerity of her manner being soon sufficient to convince him, where conviction was at least very agreeable, he had no farther scruples as to her being left to dine alone, though he still wanted her to join them in the evening, when the child might be at rest for the night, and kindly urged her to let him come and fetch her, but she was quite unpersadable;
fr: Anna put alors plaider sa propre cause ; elle le fit de maniere a ne lui laisser aucun scrupule. Charles tacha d'obtenir, mais en vain, qu'elle vint les rejoindre le soir.

eng: and this being the case, she had ere long the pleasure of seeing them set off together in high spirits.
fr: Bientot elle eut le plaisir de les voir partir contents, quelque peu motive que fut leur bonheur.

eng: They were gone, she hoped, to be happy, however oddly constructed such happiness might seem;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: as for herself, she was left with as many sensations of comfort, as were, perhaps, ever likely to be hers.
fr: Quant a elle, elle eprouvait autant de contentement qu'il lui etait donne d'en avoir jamais.

eng: She knew herself to be of the first utility to the child; and what was it to her if Frederick Wentworth were only half a mile distant, making himself agreeable to others?
fr: Elle se savait indispensable a l'enfant, et que lui importait que Frederic Wenvorth se rendit agreable aux autres, a une demi-lieue de la ?

eng: Anne will stay; Anne undertakes to stay at home and take care of him.
fr: Anna restera : elle se charge d'en prendre soin.

eng: She would have liked to know how he felt as to a meeting.
fr: Elle se demandait s'il envisageait cette rencontre avec indifference, ou avec deplaisir.

eng: Perhaps indifferent, if indifference could exist under such circumstances.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mary talked, but she could not attend.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: In two minutes after Charles's preparation, the others appeared; they were in the drawing-room.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Her eye half met Captain Wentworth's, a bow, a curtsey passed; she heard his voice; he talked to Mary, said all that was right, said something to the Miss Musgroves, enough to mark an easy footing; the room seemed full, full of persons and voices, but a few minutes ended it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Charles shewed himself at the window, all was ready, their visitor had bowed and was gone, the Miss Musgroves were gone too, suddenly resolving to walk to the end of the village with the sportsmen: the room was cleared, and Anne might finish her breakfast as she could.
fr: Anna resta seule, achevant de dejeuner comme elle put.

eng: "It is over! it is over!" she repeated to herself again and again, in nervous gratitude. "The worst is over!"
fr: << C'est fini, se repetait-elle avec une joie nerveuse. Le plus difficile est fait. >>

eng: The morning hours of the Cottage were always later than those of the other house, and on the morrow the difference was so great that Mary and Anne were not more than beginning breakfast when Charles came in to say that they were just setting off, that he was come for his dogs, that his sisters were following with Captain Wentworth; his sisters meaning to visit Mary and the child, and Captain Wentworth proposing also to wait on her for a few minutes if not inconvenient; and though Charles had answered for the child's being in no such state as could make it inconvenient, Captain Wentworth would not be satisfied without his running on to give notice.
fr: Ses soeurs le suivaient avec Wenvorth, qui avait voulu saluer Marie. Celle-ci fut tres flattee de cette attention et enchantee de le recevoir, tandis qu'Anna etait agitee par mille sentiments dont le plus consolant etait qu'il ne resterait pas longtemps.

eng: She had seen him. They had met. They had been once more in the same room.
fr: Elle l'avait vu ! Ils s'etaient trouves encore une fois dans la meme chambre !

eng: Soon, however, she began to reason with herself, and try to be feeling less.
fr: Bientot, cependant, elle se raisonna, et s'efforca d'etre moins emue.

eng: Eight years, almost eight years had passed, since all had been given up.
fr: Presque huit annees s'etaient ecoulees depuis que tout etait rompu.

eng: How absurd to be resuming the agitation which such an interval had banished into distance and indistinctness!
fr: Combien il etait absurde de ressentir encore une agitation que le temps aurait du effacer !

eng: And it was soon over.
fr: Son regard rencontra celui du capitaine ; il fit de la tete un leger salut, puis il parla a Marie, dit quelques mots aux misses Musgrove ; un moment la chambre sembla animee et remplie ; puis Charles vint a la fenetre dire que tout etait pret.

eng: Mary, very much gratified by this attention, was delighted to receive him, while a thousand feelings rushed on Anne, of which this was the most consoling, that it would soon be over.
fr: Anna et Marie etaient encore a table le lendemain matin, quand Charles vint pour chercher ses chiens.

eng: He had inquired after her, she found, slightly, as might suit a former slight acquaintance, seeming to acknowledge such as she had acknowledged, actuated, perhaps, by the same view of escaping introduction when they were to meet.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He wished to avoid seeing her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Anne understood it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was to come to breakfast, but not at the Cottage, though that had been proposed at first; but then he had been pressed to come to the Great House instead, and he seemed afraid of being in Mrs Charles Musgrove's way, on account of the child, and therefore, somehow, they hardly knew how, it ended in Charles's being to meet him to breakfast at his father's.
fr: Il s'etait informe d'Anna comme d'une personne qu'il aurait tres peu connue, voulant peut-etre, comme elle, echapper a une presentation quand ils se rencontreraient.

eng: charming manners in Captain Wentworth, no shyness or reserve; they seemed all to know each other perfectly, and he was coming the very next morning to shoot with Charles.
fr: Le capitaine avait des manieres charmantes ; ni timidite, ni reserve ; il semblait etre une ancienne connaissance. Il devait, le lendemain, chasser avec Charles, et dejeuner avec lui a Great-House.

eng: There had been music, singing, talking, laughing, all that was most agreeable;
fr: On avait cause, chante, fait de la musique.

eng: Her brother and sister came back delighted with their new acquaintance, and their visit in general.
fr: Charles et Marie revinrent ravis de leur nouvelle connaissance et de leur soiree.

eng: What might not eight years do?
fr: Que de changements huit ans pouvaient apporter !

eng: Events of every description, changes, alienations, removals--all, all must be comprised in it, and oblivion of the past-- how natural, how certain too!
fr: tous resumes en un mot : l'oubli du passe !

eng: It included nearly a third part of her own life.
fr: C'etait presque le tiers de sa propre vie.

eng: Alas! ~~~ with all her reasoning, she found, that to retentive feelings eight years may be little more than nothing.
fr: Helas, il fallait bien le reconnaitre, pour des sentiments emprisonnes, ce temps n'est rien.

eng: And the next moment she was hating herself for the folly which asked the question.
fr: Un moment apres, elle se haissait pour cette folle question.

eng: Now, how were his sentiments to be read?
fr: Comment devait-elle interpreter les sentiments de Wenvorth ?

eng: but she was perfectly unsuspicious of being inflicting any peculiar wound.
fr: mais cette fois elle ne soupconna pas quelle blessure elle lui faisait.

eng: Mary had no feelings to make her respect her sister's in a common way,
fr: En general, Marie manquait d'egards pour sa soeur,

eng: for, after the Miss Musgroves had returned and finished their visit at the Cottage she had this spontaneous information from Mary:-- "Captain Wentworth is not very gallant by you, Anne, though he was so attentive to me. Henrietta asked him what he thought of you, when they went away, and he said, 'You were so altered he should not have known you again.'"
fr: que Marie vint resoudre, en lui disant brusquement : << Le capitaine, qui a ete si attentif pour moi, n'a pas ete tres galant a votre egard, Anna. Henriette lui a demande ce qu'il pensait de vous, et il a repondu qu'il ne vous aurait pas reconnue, que vous etiez changee. >>

eng: On one other question which perhaps her utmost wisdom might not have prevented, she was soon spared all suspense;
fr: Malgre toute sa sagesse, elle s'en faisait une autre,

eng: Was this like wishing to avoid her?
fr: Desirait-il l'eviter ?

eng: "Altered beyond his knowledge."
fr: << Changee a ne pas me reconnaitre !...

eng: Anne fully submitted, in silent, deep mortification.
fr: >> Elle se soumit en silence, mais profondement humiliee.

eng: Doubtless it was so, and she could take no revenge, for he was not altered, or not for the worse.
fr: C'etait donc vrai ! ~~~ et elle ne pouvait pas lui rendre la pareille, car lui n'avait pas vieilli.

eng: She had used him ill, deserted and disappointed him; and worse, she had shewn a feebleness of character in doing so, which his own decided, confident temper could not endure.
fr: elle l'avait rejete, abandonne, elle avait montre une faiblesse de caractere, que la nature confiante, decidee, du jeune homme ne supportait pas.

eng: He had thought her wretchedly altered, and in the first moment of appeal, had spoken as he felt.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: No: the years which had destroyed her youth and bloom had only given him a more glowing, manly, open look, in no respect lessening his personal advantages.
fr: Les annees qui avaient detruit la beaute de la jeune fille avaient donne a Wenvorth un regard plus brillant, un air plus male, plus ouvert, et n'avaient nullement diminue ses avantages physiques.

eng: She had seen the same Frederick Wentworth.
fr: C'etait toujours le meme Frederic Wenvorth !

eng: "So altered that he should not have known her again!" These were words which could not but dwell with her.
fr: << Si changee qu'il ne l'aurait pas reconnue ! >> Ces mots ne pouvaient sortir de son esprit.

eng: Yet she soon began to rejoice that she had heard them. They were of sobering tendency; they allayed agitation; they composed, and consequently must make her happier.
fr: Mais bientot elle fut bien aise de les avoir entendus : ils etaient faits pour la refroidir et calmer son agitation.

eng: Frederick Wentworth had used such words, or something like them, but without an idea that they would be carried round to her.
fr: Frederic ne pensait pas qu'on repeterait ses paroles ; il l'avait trouvee tristement changee et avait dit son impression.

eng: He had not forgiven Anne Elliot.
fr: Il ne pardonnait pas a Anna Elliot ;

eng: She had already acknowledged it to herself, and she could not think differently, let him think of her as he would.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had given him up to oblige others. ~~~ It had been the effect of over-persuasion.
fr: Elle l'avait sacrifie pour satisfaire d'autres personnes.

eng: It had been weakness and timidity.
fr: C'etait de la timidite et de la faiblesse.

eng: It was now his object to marry.
fr: Maintenant il etait riche et desirait se marier.

eng: Her power with him was gone for ever.
fr: Elle avait perdu pour toujours son pouvoir.

eng: They had no conversation together, no intercourse but what the commonest civility required.
fr: Ils ne se parlaient pas, eux qui autrefois, au milieu de la plus nombreuse reunion, eussent trouve impossible de ne pas se parler !

eng: It was a perpetual estrangement.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was rich, and being turned on shore, fully intended to settle as soon as he could be properly tempted; actually looking round, ready to fall in love with all the speed which a clear head and a quick taste could allow.
fr: Il etait pret a donner son coeur a toute jeune fille aimable qui se presenterait a lui, excepte Anna Elliot.

eng: He had been most warmly attached to her, and had never seen a woman since whom he thought her equal; but, except from some natural sensation of curiosity, he had no desire of meeting her again.
fr: Il avait eu pour elle un profond attachement et n'avait jamais vu depuis une femme qui l'egalat ; mais il n'entrait maintenant qu'un sentiment de curiosite dans le desir de la revoir.

eng: He had a heart for either of the Miss Musgroves, if they could catch it; a heart, in short, for any pleasing young woman who came in his way, excepting Anne Elliot.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: This was his only secret exception, when he said to his sister, in answer to her suppositions:-- "Yes, here I am, Sophia, quite ready to make a foolish match.
fr: Il disait a sa soeur : << Je demande une jeune fille entre quinze et trente ans ; un peu de beaute, quelques sourires, quelques flatteries pour les marins, et je suis un homme perdu.

eng: Anybody between fifteen and thirty may have me for asking.
fr: N'est-ce pas assez pour rendre aimable un homme qui n'a pas eu la societe des femmes ?

eng: Once so much to each other!
fr: Jamais, a l'exception de l'amiral et de sa femme, on n'eut trouve deux coeurs aussi unis qu'ils l'etaient autrefois.

eng: Now nothing!
fr: Maintenant ils etaient moins que des etrangers l'un pour l'autre.

eng: There had been a time, when of all the large party now filling the drawing-room at Uppercross, they would have found it most difficult to cease to speak to one another.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: With the exception, perhaps, of Admiral and Mrs Croft, who seemed particularly attached and happy, (Anne could allow no other exceptions even among the married couples), there could have been no two hearts so open, no tastes so similar, no feelings so in unison, no countenances so beloved.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Now they were as strangers; nay, worse than strangers, for they could never become acquainted.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: His profession qualified him, his disposition lead him, to talk; and "That was in the year six;" "That happened before I went to sea in the year six," occurred in the course of the first evening they spent together: and though his voice did not falter, and though she had no reason to suppose his eye wandering towards her while he spoke, Anne felt the utter impossibility, from her knowledge of his mind, that he could be unvisited by remembrance any more than herself.
fr: Des le premier soir la profession du capitaine l'amena a dire : << En telle annee......... avant d'embarquer...... >> etc. Sa voix ne tremblait pas, mais Anna etait sure qu'elle etait associee a son passe.

eng: Whether former feelings were to be renewed must be brought to the proof; former times must undoubtedly be brought to the recollection of each; they could not but be reverted to; the year of their engagement could not but be named by him, in the little narratives or descriptions which conversation called forth.
fr: Le passe devait sans doute se presenter souvent a leur memoire.

eng: They were soon dining in company together at Mr Musgrove's, for the little boy's state could no longer supply his aunt with a pretence for absenting herself; and this was but the beginning of other dinings and other meetings.
fr: Ils dinerent chez M. Musgrove, car la sante de l'enfant ne pouvait pas servir plus longtemps de pretexte a sa tante.

eng: Chapter 8 From this time Captain Wentworth and Anne Elliot were repeatedly in the same circle.
fr: CHAPITRE VIII A dater de ce jour, le capitaine et Anna se trouverent souvent ensemble.

eng: "Something a little inferior I shall of course put up with, but it must not be much. If I am a fool, I shall be a fool indeed, for I have thought on the subject more than most men."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "That is the woman I want," said he.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "A strong mind, with sweetness of manner," made the first and the last of the description.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: His bright proud eye spoke the conviction that he was nice; and Anne Elliot was not out of his thoughts, when he more seriously described the woman he should wish to meet with.
fr: Son oeil fier et brillant disait qu'il se savait seduisant, et il ne pensait guere a Anna en designant ainsi la femme qu'il voudrait rencontrer : << Un esprit fort, uni a une grande douceur. >>

eng: He said it, she knew, to be contradicted.
fr: Il disait cela pour etre contredit.

eng: A little beauty, and a few smiles, and a few compliments to the navy, and I am a lost man.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There must be the same immediate association of thought, though she was very far from conceiving it to be of equal pain.
fr: Autrefois, ils etaient tout l'un pour l'autre : maintenant plus rien.

eng: Should not this be enough for a sailor, who has had no society among women to make him nice?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: When he talked, she heard the same voice, and discerned the same mind.
fr: Quand Frederic parlait, c'etait pour elle, la meme voix, le meme esprit.

eng: Hardly fit for service then. Reported fit for home service for a year or two, and so I was sent off to the West Indies."
fr: alors qu'il etait presque hors de service. Je fus envoye avec lui aux Indes orientales.

eng: There was a very general ignorance of all naval matters throughout the party; and he was very much questioned, and especially by the two Miss Musgroves, who seemed hardly to have any eyes but for him, as to the manner of living on board, daily regulations, food, hours, &c., and their surprise at his accounts, at learning the degree of accommodation and arrangement which was practicable, drew from him some pleasant ridicule, which reminded Anne of the early days when she too had been ignorant, and she too had been accused of supposing sailors to be living on board without anything to eat, or any cook to dress it if there were, or any servant to wait, or any knife and fork to use.
fr: Ceux qui l'entouraient, etant tres ignorants des choses de la marine, lui faisaient mille questions. Les misses Musgrove etaient tout oreilles lorsqu'il decrivait la vie a bord, les repas, les occupations de chaque heure ; et leur surprise, en apprenant les arrangements et l'installation d'un navire, faisait surgir quelque plaisante reponse, qui rappelait a Anna le temps ou elle etait elle-meme ignorante de ces choses. Elle aussi avait ete plaisantee pour avoir cru qu'on vivait a bord sans provisions, sans cuisinier ni domestiques, et qu'on n'avait ni cuillers ni fourchettes.

eng: From thus listening and thinking, she was roused by a whisper of Mrs Musgrove's who, overcome by fond regrets, could not help saying-- "Ah! Miss Anne, if it had pleased Heaven to spare my poor son, I dare say he would have been just such another by this time."
fr: Un soupir de Mme Musgrove l'eveilla de sa reverie : << Ah ! mademoiselle, lui dit-elle tout bas, si le ciel m'avait conserve mon pauvre fils, il serait un autre homme, aujourd'hui ! >>

eng: Anne suppressed a smile, and listened kindly, while Mrs Musgrove relieved her heart a little more; and for a few minutes, therefore, could not keep pace with the conversation of the others.
fr: Anna reprima un sourire, et ecouta patiemment Mme Musgrove, qui continua a soulager son coeur. Quand elle put donner son attention a ce qui se faisait autour d'elle, elle vit que les misses Musgrove avaient apporte la liste navale pour y chercher les noms des navires que le capitaine avait commandes.

eng: When she could let her attention take its natural course again, she found the Miss Musgroves just fetching the Navy List (their own navy list, the first that had ever been at Uppercross), and sitting down together to pore over it, with the professed view of finding out the ships that Captain Wentworth had commanded.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Your first was the Asp, I remember; we will look for the Asp."
fr: << Votre premier navire etait l'Aspic.

eng: "You will not find her there.
fr: -- Vous ne le trouverez pas ici.

eng: Quite worn out and broken up. I was the last man who commanded her.
fr: Il a ete use et demoli ; j'ai ete son dernier capitaine,

eng: "Phoo! phoo!" cried the Admiral, "what stuff these young fellows talk!'
fr: -- Bah ! s'ecria l'amiral. Quelles sornettes debitent ces jeunes gens !'

eng: The girls looked all amazement.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "The Admiralty," he continued, "entertain themselves now and then, with sending a few hundred men to sea, in a ship not fit to be employed.
fr: L'Amiraute s'amuse a envoyer de temps en temps quelques centaines d'hommes en mer dans un navire hors de service,

eng: But they have a great many to provide for; and among the thousands that may just as well go to the bottom as not, it is impossible for them to distinguish the very set who may be least missed."
fr: mais comme elle en a beaucoup a surveiller, parmi les mille navires qui peuvent sombrer, il s'en trouve quelquefois un qui est encore bon.

eng: Never was a better sloop than the Asp in her day.
fr: On ne vit jamais un meilleur sloop que l'Aspic dans son temps.

eng: For an old built sloop, you would not see her equal.
fr: Vous n'auriez pas trouve son egal, a ce vieux sloop !

eng: '"To be sure you did. What should a young fellow like you do ashore for half a year together?'
fr: '-- Vous avez raison. Qu'est-ce qu'un jeune homme comme vous pouvait faire a terre pendant six grands mois ?'

eng: 'I wanted to be doing something.'
fr: 'J'avais besoin de faire quelque chose.'

eng: 'It was a great object with me at that time to be at sea; a very great object,'
fr: 'J'avais, dans ce temps-la, un grand motif pour m'embarquer.'

eng: 'Lucky fellow to get anything so soon, with no more interest than his."
fr: 'Heureux garcon, de reussir si vite avec si peu de protection !'

eng: '"I felt my luck, Admiral, I assure you;" replied Captain Wentworth, seriously.'
fr: '-- Je compris mon bonheur, amiral, je vous assure, repondit Wenvorth avec un grand serieux.'

eng: 'He knows there must have been twenty better men than himself applying for her at the same time.'
fr: 'Il fut demande par vingt personnes qui le meritaient mieux que lui.'

eng: 'Lucky fellow to get her!'
fr: 'Frederic a ete un heureux garcon de l'avoir !'

eng: '"I was as well satisfied with my appointment as you can desire.'
fr: 'J'etais aussi content que vous pouvez le desirer.'

eng: If a man had not a wife, he soon wants to be afloat again."
fr: Si un homme n'est pas marie, il faut qu'il retourne bien vite en mer.

eng: Four-and-twenty hours later, and I should only have been a gallant Captain Wentworth, in a small paragraph at one corner of the newspapers; and being lost in only a sloop, nobody would have thought about me."
fr: 'Vingt-quatre heures plus tard, il ne serait reste du vaillant capitaine Wenvorth qu'un paragraphe dans les journaux, et, son navire n'etant qu'un sloop, personne n'y aurait fait attention.'

eng: Dick had been left ill at Gibraltar, with a recommendation from his former captain to Captain Wentworth."'
fr: 'Dick y etait reste malade avec une recommandation de son premier capitaine pour le capitaine Wenvorth.'

eng: "It was at Gibraltar, mother, I know.
fr: '-- Ce fut a Gibraltar, ma mere.'

eng: I always forgot."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Charles, my dear," (beckoning him to her), "do ask Captain Wentworth where it was he first met with your poor brother.
fr: 'Charles, demandez au capitaine ou il prit votre frere ; je l'oublie toujours.'

eng: "And so then, I suppose," said Mrs Musgrove, in a low voice, as if thinking aloud, "so then he went away to the Laconia, and there he met with our poor boy.
fr: 'C'est alors, sans doute, dit Mme Musgrove a voix basse, qu'il prit le commandement de la Laconia et prit a bord notre pauvre cher fils ?'

eng: Anne's shudderings were to herself alone; but the Miss Musgroves could be as open as they were sincere, in their exclamations of pity and horror.
fr: 'Anna fremit interieurement, mais les misses Musgrove purent exprimer librement leur pitie et leur horreur.'

eng: We had not been six hours in the Sound, when a gale came on, which lasted four days and nights, and which would have done for poor old Asp in half the time; our touch with the Great Nation not having much improved our condition.
fr: 'nous n'etions pas depuis six heures dans le Sund, qu'un vent s'eleva qui aurait acheve notre pauvre Aspic. Il dura quatre jours et quatre nuits.'

eng: Ah! she was a dear old Asp to me.
fr: 'Ah ! c'etait mon cher vieil Aspic.'

eng: I brought her into Plymouth;
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: and after taking privateers enough to be very entertaining, I had the good luck in my passage home the next autumn, to fall in with the very French frigate I wanted.
fr: 'j'eus le bonheur d'accoster, l'ete suivant, la fregate francaise que je cherchais ; je la remorquai a Plymouth.'

eng: and I never had two days of foul weather all the time I was at sea in her;
fr: 'Je n'ai jamais eu avec lui deux jours de mauvais temps, et apres avoir pris bon nombre de corsaires,'

eng: I knew that we should either go to the bottom together, or that she would be the making of me;
fr: 'Je savais que nous coulerions a fond ensemble, ou qu'il ferait ma fortune.'

eng: I knew she would.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She did all that I wanted.
fr: 'Il faisait ce que je voulais.'

eng: "I had no more discoveries to make than you would have as to the fashion and strength of any old pelisse, which you had seen lent about among half your acquaintance ever since you could remember, and which at last, on some very wet day, is lent to yourself.
fr: 'Je n'avais pas plus de decouvertes a faire que vous n'en auriez pour une vieille pelisse pretee a vos connaissances, de temps immemorial, et qui vous serait enfin pretee a vous-meme un jour de pluie.'

eng: "I knew pretty well what she was before that day;" said he, smiling.
fr: '-- Je savais d'avance ce qu'il etait, dit-il en riant.'

eng: and here another instance of luck.
fr: 'Par une autre bonne chance,'

eng: '"But, Captain Wentworth," cried Louisa, "how vexed you must have been when you came to the Asp, to see what an old thing they had given you."
fr: '-- Capitaine Wenvorth, dit Louisa, vous avez du etre bien vexe, en montant sur l'Aspic, de voir quel vieux navire on vous avait donne ?'

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: but, Charles, tell Captain Wentworth, he need not be afraid of mentioning poor Dick before me, for it would be rather a pleasure to hear him talked of by such a good friend."
fr: dites-lui qu'il ne craigne pas de nommer le pauvre Dick devant moi, car ce sera plutot un plaisir d'entendre parler de lui par un si bon ami.

eng: Excellent fellow. I shall never forget his happiness.
fr: l'excellent garcon ! Je n'oublierai jamais combien il fut heureux a cause de sa femme.

eng: Her feelings made her speak low; and Captain Wentworth, hearing only in part, and probably not having Dick Musgrove at all near his thoughts, looked rather in suspense, and as if waiting for more.
fr: L'emotion lui coupait la voix, et Wenvorth, qui n'entendait qu'a demi, et ne songeait nullement a Dick, attendait la suite avec surprise.

eng: "My brother," whispered one of the girls; "mamma is thinking of poor Richard."
fr: << Maman pense a mon frere Richard, >> dit Louisa a voix basse.

eng: "Poor dear fellow!"
fr: -- Pauvre cher enfant !

eng: "And I am sure, Sir," said Mrs Musgrove, "it was a lucky day for us, when you were put captain into that ship. We shall never forget what you did."
fr: -- Ce fut un beau jour pour nous, que celui ou vous futes nomme capitaine de ce navire, dit Mme Musgrove. Nous n'oublierons jamais ce que vous avez fait.

eng: I wished for him again the next summer, when I had still the same luck in the Mediterranean.
fr: J'aurais voulu qu'il fut la l'ete suivant, quand j'eus le meme bonheur dans la Mediterranee.

eng: Poor Harville, sister! You know how much he wanted money: worse than myself.
fr: Pauvre Harville ! Vous savez, ma soeur, qu'il avait encore plus besoin d'argent que moi.

eng: A friend of mine and I had such a lovely cruise together off the Western Islands.
fr: Mon ami et moi, nous fimes une si belle croisiere aux Indes occidentales !

eng: He felt it all, so much for her sake.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He had a wife.
fr: Il etait marie,

eng: Charles, being somewhat more mindful of the probabilities of the case, only nodded in reply, and walked away.
fr: Charles, sans doute moins tranquille sur les consequences, repondit par un signe de tete et s'eloigna.

eng: "Ah! those were pleasant days when I had the Laconia! How fast I made money in her.
fr: << Ah ! c'etaient de bons jours, quand je commandais la Laconia. J'ai gagne bien de l'argent avec elle !

eng: The girls were now hunting for the Laconia; and Captain Wentworth could not deny himself the pleasure of taking the precious volume into his own hands to save them the trouble, and once more read aloud the little statement of her name and rate, and present non-commissioned class, observing over it that she too had been one of the best friends man ever had.
fr: Les jeunes filles se mirent a chercher la Laconia, et le capitaine se donna le plaisir de la trouver lui-meme, ajoutant que c'etait un de ses meilleurs amis.

eng: continued Mrs Musgrove; "he was grown so steady, and such an excellent correspondent, while he was under your care!
fr: continua Mme Musgrove. ~~~ Il etait devenu si range, si bon sous vos ordres, et nous ecrivait de si bonnes lettres !

eng: Ah!
fr: Ah !

eng: it would have been a happy thing, if he had never left you.
fr: plut a Dieu qu'il ne vous eut jamais quitte !

eng: and while the agitations of Anne's slender form, and pensive face, may be considered as very completely screened, Captain Wentworth should be allowed some credit for the self-command with which he attended to her large fat sighings over the destiny of a son, whom alive nobody had cared for.
fr: et tandis qu'Anna s'abritait derriere elle pour cacher son agitation, la facon dont le capitaine ecoutait les doleances de Mme Musgrove et ses larges soupirs n'etait pas sans merite.

eng: It was no insignificant barrier, indeed. Mrs Musgrove was of a comfortable, substantial size, infinitely more fitted by nature to express good cheer and good humour, than tenderness and sentiment;
fr: plus faite pour representer la bonne humeur et la bonne chere, que la tendresse et le sentiment,

eng: They were actually on the same sofa, for Mrs Musgrove had most readily made room for him; they were divided only by Mrs Musgrove.
fr: Anna etait assise a l'autre coin du divan, separee de lui par la vaste corpulence de Mme Musgrove,

eng: but it was too transient an indulgence of self-amusement to be detected by any who understood him less than herself;
fr: mais ce fut si rapide qu'elle seule s'en apercut.

eng: There was a momentary expression in Captain Wentworth's face at this speech, a certain glance of his bright eye, and curl of his handsome mouth, which convinced Anne, that instead of sharing in Mrs Musgrove's kind wishes, as to her son, he had probably been at some pains to get rid of him;
fr: En entendant cela, une expression fugitive traversa la figure de Wenvorth : un pli de sa bouche et un certain regard convainquirent Anna qu'il n'etait pas de l'avis de Mme Musgrove, et qu'il avait eu probablement quelque peine a se debarrasser de Dick ;

eng: "I assure you, Captain Wentworth, we are very sorry he ever left you."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: in another moment he was perfectly collected and serious, and almost instantly afterwards coming up to the sofa, on which she and Mrs Musgrove were sitting, took a place by the latter, and entered into conversation with her, in a low voice, about her son, doing it with so much sympathy and natural grace, as shewed the kindest consideration for all that was real and unabsurd in the parent's feelings.
fr: Un instant apres, il etait serieux et maitre de lui ; il vint s'asseoir a cote de Mme Musgrove, et causa de son fils avec une grace naturelle qui temoignait de sa sympathie pour tout sentiment vrai.

eng: Personal size and mental sorrow have certainly no necessary proportions.
fr: Le chagrin n'est pas necessairement en rapport avec la constitution.

eng: A large bulky figure has as good a right to be in deep affliction, as the most graceful set of limbs in the world.
fr: Une grosse personne a aussi bien le droit d'etre affligee profondement que la plus gracieuse femme.

eng: The Admiral abused him for his want of gallantry.
fr: L'amiral le plaisanta sur son manque de galanterie :

eng: He defended himself; though professing that he would never willingly admit any ladies on board a ship of his, excepting for a ball, or a visit, which a few hours might comprehend.
fr: il se defendit, tout en declarant qu'il n'admettrait jamais une femme a son bord, si ce n'est pour un bal, ou en visite.

eng: "But, if I know myself," said he, "this is from no want of gallantry towards them. It is rather from feeling how impossible it is, with all one's efforts, and all one's sacrifices, to make the accommodations on board such as women ought to have. There can be no want of gallantry, Admiral, in rating the claims of women to every personal comfort high, and this is what I do. I hate to hear of women on board, or to see them on board; and no ship under my command shall ever convey a family of ladies anywhere, if I can help it."
fr: << Ce n'est point faute de galanterie, dit-il, mais par l'impossibilite d'avoir dans un navire le confortable necessaire aux femmes, et auquel elles ont droit. Je ne puis souffrir d'avoir une femme a bord, et aucun navire commande par moi n'en recevra jamais. >>

eng: "Should I? I am glad I was not a week later then."
fr: -- Je suis heureux alors de n'avoir pas ete la. >>

eng: This brought his sister upon him. "Oh! Frederick! But I cannot believe it of you.--All idle refinement!--Women may be as comfortable on board, as in the best house in England.
fr: Sa soeur s'ecria : << Ah ! Frederic ! est-ce vous qui dites cela ? Quel raffinement inutile ! ~~~ Les femmes sont aussi bien a bord que dans la meilleure maison d'Angleterre.

eng: But, fair or not fair, there are unbecoming conjunctions, which reason will patronize in vain--which taste cannot tolerate--which ridicule will seize.
fr: Neanmoins, il y a des contrastes que la raison admet, mais qui froissent le gout et attirent le ridicule.

eng: The Admiral, after taking two or three refreshing turns about the room with his hands behind him, being called to order by his wife, now came up to Captain Wentworth, and without any observation of what he might be interrupting, thinking only of his own thoughts, began with-- "If you had been a week later at Lisbon, last spring, Frederick, you would have been asked to give a passage to Lady Mary Grierson and her daughters."
fr: L'amiral, apres avoir fait quelques tours dans la chambre, les mains derriere le dos, s'approcha de Wenvorth, et, tout a ses propres pensees, il lui dit, sans s'occuper s'il l'interrompait : << Si vous aviez ete une semaine plus tard a Lisbonne, Frederic, vous auriez eu a bord lady Marie Grierson et ses filles.

eng: I believe I have lived as much on board as most women, and I know nothing superior to the accommodations of a man-of-war.
fr: Je ne sais rien de superieur aux arrangements d'un navire.

eng: 'I declare I have not a comfort or an indulgence about me, even at Kellynch Hall," (with a kind bow to Anne), "beyond what I always had in most of the ships I have lived in; and they have been five altogether."
fr: 'Je declare que je n'ai pas plus de confortable a Kellynch que dans les cinq navires que j'ai habites.'

eng: "Nothing to the purpose," replied her brother.
fr: '-- Il n'est pas question de cela, dit Frederic ;'

eng: "You were living with your husband, and were the only woman on board."
fr: '-- vous etiez avec votre mari, et la seule femme a bord.'

eng: "But you, yourself, brought Mrs Harville, her sister, her cousin, and three children, round from Portsmouth to Plymouth.'
fr: 'Mais vous avez bien pris, de Portsmouth a Plymouth, Mme Harville, sa soeur, sa cousine et trois enfants !'

eng: Where was this superfine, extraordinary sort of gallantry of yours then?"
fr: Ou etait donc alors votre superfine et extraordinaire galanterie ?

eng: "Depend upon it, they were all perfectly comfortable."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "All merged in my friendship, Sophia. I would assist any brother officer's wife that I could, and I would bring anything of Harville's from the world's end, if he wanted it. But do not imagine that I did not feel it an evil in itself."
fr: '-- Absorbee dans mon amitie, Sophie ; je voulais etre utile a la femme d'un collegue, et j'aurais transporte au bout du monde tout ce que Harville aurait voulu. Mais croyez bien que je regardais cela comme une chose facheuse.'

eng: "My dear Frederick, you are talking quite idly. Pray, what would become of us poor sailors' wives, who often want to be conveyed to one port or another, after our husbands, if everybody had your feelings?"
fr: '-- Mon cher Frederic, ce que vous dites ne signifie rien. Que deviendrions-nous, nous autres pauvres femmes de marins, si les autres pensaient comme vous ?'

eng: "My feelings, you see, did not prevent my taking Mrs Harville and all her family to Plymouth."
fr: '-- Cela ne m'empecha pas, comme vous voyez, de conduire Mme Harville et sa famille a Plymouth.'

eng: "I might not like them the better for that perhaps. Such a number of women and children have no right to be comfortable on board."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "But I hate to hear you talking so like a fine gentleman, and as if women were all fine ladies, instead of rational creatures. ~~~ We none of us expect to be in smooth water all our days."
fr: -- Mais je n'aime pas a vous entendre parler comme un beau gentilhomme s'adressant a de belles ladies : nous n'avons pas la pretention d'etre toujours sur l'eau douce.

eng: "Ah!
fr: -- Ah !

eng: "my dear," said the Admiral, "when he had got a wife, he will sing a different tune.
fr: 'ma chere, dit l'amiral, quand il aura une femme, il parlera autrement.

eng: Chapter 9
fr: Il avait fait le projet d'aller voir son frere, dans le comte de Shrop, mais l'attrait d'Uppercross l'y fit renoncer.

eng: When he is married, if we have the good luck to live to another war, we shall see him do as you and I, and a great many others, have done.
fr: Si nous avons le bonheur d'avoir une autre guerre, il fera comme nous, et sera reconnaissant qu'on lui amene sa femme.

eng: We shall have him very thankful to anybody that will bring him his wife."
fr: -- Je me tais, dit Wenvorth, puisque les gens maries m'attaquent,

eng: I have crossed the Atlantic four times, and have been once to the East Indies, and back again, and only once; besides being in different places about home: Cork, and Lisbon, and Gibraltar.
fr: Mais je n'ai jamais ete au dela des tropiques ni dans les Indes occidentales, car je n'appelle pas de ce nom Bermude ou Bahama.

eng: "Now I have done," cried Captain Wentworth.
fr: Eh bien ! ~~~ non.

eng: She felt that he had every thing to elevate him which general attention and deference, and especially the attention of all the young women, could do.
fr: Quoi d'etonnant s'il etait un peu gate par de telles flatteries ?

eng: The Miss Hayters, the females of the family of cousins already mentioned, were apparently admitted to the honour of being in love with him; and as for Henrietta and Louisa, they both seemed so entirely occupied by him, that nothing but the continued appearance of the most perfect good-will between themselves could have made it credible that they were not decided rivals.
fr: Telles etaient les pensees d'Anna, tandis que ses doigts couraient machinalement sur le piano.

eng: If he were a little spoilt by such universal, such eager admiration, who could wonder?
fr: Pendant un moment, elle sentit qu'il la regardait, qu'il observait ses traits alteres, cherchant peut-etre a y retrouver ce qui l'avait charme autrefois.

eng: These were some of the thoughts which occupied Anne, while her fingers were mechanically at work, proceeding for half an hour together, equally without error, and without consciousness.
fr: Il demanda quelque chose ; elle entendit qu'on repondait : << Oh non ! elle ne danse plus ; elle prefere jouer, et elle n'est jamais fatiguee. >>

eng: Once she felt that he was looking at herself, observing her altered features, perhaps, trying to trace in them the ruins of the face which had once charmed him; and once she knew that he must have spoken of her; she was hardly aware of it, till she heard the answer; but then she was sure of his having asked his partner whether Miss Elliot never danced?
fr: Elle avait quitte le piano ; il prit sa place, essayant de noter un air dont il voulait donner une idee aux misses Musgrove.

eng: The answer was, "Oh, no; never; she has quite given up dancing. She had rather play. She is never tired of playing."
fr: Elle s'approcha par hasard ; alors il se leva et avec une politesse etudiee : << Je vous demande pardon, mademoiselle, c'est votre place ; >>

eng: Once, too, he spoke to her.
fr: et malgre le refus d'Anna il se retira.

eng: It was a merry, joyous party, and no one seemed in higher spirits than Captain Wentworth.
fr: Louise et Henriette semblaient si occupees de lui que, sans leur amitie reciproque, on eut pu les croire rivales.

eng: She had left the instrument on the dancing being over, and he had sat down to try to make out an air which he wished to give the Miss Musgroves an idea of.
fr: Elle en avait assez !

eng: He had intended, on first arriving, to proceed very soon into Shropshire, and visit the brother settled in that country, but the attractions of Uppercross induced him to put this off.
fr: Bientot on le vit chaque jour a Uppercross.

eng: There was so much of friendliness, and of flattery, and of everything most bewitching in his reception there; the old were so hospitable, the young so agreeable, that he could not but resolve to remain where he was, and take all the charms and perfections of Edward's wife upon credit a little longer.
fr: Les Musgrove n'etaient pas plus empresses a l'inviter que lui a venir, surtout le matin, car l'amiral et sa femme sortaient toujours ensemble quand il n'y avait personne au chateau.

eng: It was soon Uppercross with him almost every day.
fr: Ils s'interessaient a leur nouvelle propriete et visitaient leurs prairies, leurs bestiaux, ou faisaient volontiers un tour en voiture.

eng: The Musgroves could hardly be more ready to invite than he to come, particularly in the morning, when he had no companion at home, for the Admiral and Mrs Croft were generally out of doors together, interesting themselves in their new possessions, their grass, and their sheep, and dawdling about in a way not endurable to a third person, or driving out in a gig, lately added to their establishment.
fr: L'intimite du capitaine etait a peine etablie a Uppercross, quand Charles Hayter y revint, et en prit ombrage. ~~~

eng: Hitherto there had been but one opinion of Captain Wentworth among the Musgroves and their dependencies. It was unvarying, warm admiration everywhere; but this intimate footing was not more than established, when a certain Charles Hayter returned among them, to be a good deal disturbed by it, and to think Captain Wentworth very much in the way.
fr: Charles Hayter etait l'aine des cousins.

eng: "Ay, that we shall."
fr: Ah ! je penserai autrement quand je serai marie !

eng: Anne did not wish for more of such looks and speeches.
fr: CHAPITRE IX

eng: Captain Wentworth was come to Kellynch as to a home, to stay as long as he liked, being as thoroughly the object of the Admiral's fraternal kindness as of his wife's.
fr: Il y avait tant d'amitie, de flatterie, quelque chose de si seduisant dans la reception qu'on lui faisait ; les parents etaient si hospitaliers, les enfants si aimables, qu'il ne put s'arracher de la.

eng: On its being proposed, Anne offered her services, as usual; and though her eyes would sometimes fill with tears as she sat at the instrument, she was extremely glad to be employed, and desired nothing in return but to be unobserved.
fr: Il etait l'objet des attentions et des deferences de tout le monde.

eng: Unintentionally she returned to that part of the room; he saw her, and, instantly rising, said, with studied politeness-- "I beg your pardon, madam, this is your seat;" and though she immediately drew back with a decided negative, he was not to be induced to sit down again.
fr: Cette froide et ceremonieuse politesse etait plus qu'elle n'en pouvait supporter.

eng: "There is nothing so bad as a separation. I am quite of your opinion. I know what it is, for Mr Musgrove always attends the assizes, and I am so glad when they are over, and he is safe back again."
fr: Ce fut une joyeuse soiree.

eng: The evening ended with dancing.
fr: Le capitaine avait le plus d'entrain de tous.

eng: I can only say, 'No, I shall not;' and then they say again, 'Yes, you will,' and there is an end of it."
fr: >> Il se leva, et s'eloigna.

eng: He got up and moved away.
fr: << Vous avez du voyager beaucoup ? dit Mme Musgrove a Mme Croft.

eng: "What a great traveller you must have been, ma'am!" said Mrs Musgrove to Mrs Croft.
fr: -- Oui, madame.

eng: "Pretty well, ma'am in the fifteen years of my marriage; though many women have done more.
fr: Pendant les quinze premieres annees de mon mariage, j'ai traverse quatre fois l'Atlantique, j'ai ete aux Indes orientales, sans compter differents endroits voisins de l'Angleterre : Cork, Lisbonne, Gibraltar.

eng: His cold politeness, his ceremonious grace, were worse than anything.
fr: Le capitaine Wenvorth etait venu a Kellynch comme chez lui, pour y rester autant qu'il lui plairait ; car il etait aime par l'amiral comme un frere.

eng: "When once married people begin to attack me with,--'Oh! you will think very differently, when you are married.'
fr: On me repond si : je n'ai plus rien a dire.

eng: We do not call Bermuda or Bahama, you know, the West Indies."
fr: << Je vous assure, madame, dit Mme Croft, que rien ne surpasse les commodites d'un navire de guerre ; j'entends celui d'un rang superieur.

eng: But I never went beyond the Streights, and never was in the West Indies.
fr: >> Mme Musgrove, qui ne connaissait pas un seul de ces noms, n'eut rien a repondre.

eng: I lived in perpetual fright at that time, and had all manner of imaginary complaints from not knowing what to do with myself, or when I should hear from him next; but as long as we could be together, nothing ever ailed me, and I never met with the smallest inconvenience."
fr: >> On dansa pour terminer la soiree.

eng: "And I do assure you, ma'am," pursued Mrs Croft, "that nothing can exceed the accommodations of a man-of-war; I speak, you know, of the higher rates.
fr: Je n'ai jamais connu le mal de mer.

eng: When you come to a frigate, of course, you are more confined; though any reasonable woman may be perfectly happy in one of them; and I can safely say, that the happiest part of my life has been spent on board a ship.
fr: La seule fois que j'ai souffert fut l'hiver que je passai seule a Deal, quand l'amiral etait dans les mers du Nord.

eng: While we were together, you know, there was nothing to be feared.
fr: N'ayant pas de nouvelles, je vivais dans de continuelles craintes et je ne savais que faire de mon temps.

eng: Thank God! I have always been blessed with excellent health, and no climate disagrees with me.
fr: -- Oui, repondit Mme Musgrove, rien n'est si triste qu'une separation.

eng: A little disordered always the first twenty-four hours of going to sea, but never knew what sickness was afterwards.
fr: Je le sais par moi-meme.

eng: The only time I ever really suffered in body or mind, the only time that I ever fancied myself unwell, or had any ideas of danger, was the winter that I passed by myself at Deal, when the Admiral (Captain Croft then) was in the North Seas.
fr: Quand M. Musgrove va aux assises, je ne suis tranquille que quand il est revenu.

eng: Mrs Musgrove had not a word to say in dissent; she could not accuse herself of having ever called them anything in the whole course of her life.
fr: Le plus heureux temps de ma vie a ete a bord. ~~~ J'etais avec mon mari, et, grace a Dieu, j'ai toujours eu une excellente sante ; aucun climat ne m'est mauvais.

eng: "Aye, to be sure. Yes, indeed, oh yes! I am quite of your opinion, Mrs Croft," was Mrs Musgrove's hearty answer.
fr: Anna offrit ses services, et fut heureuse de passer inapercue.

eng: Charles Hayter was the eldest of all the cousins, and a very amiable, pleasing young man, between whom and Henrietta there had been a considerable appearance of attachment previous to Captain Wentworth's introduction.
fr: C'etait un tres aimable et agreable jeune homme, et jusqu'a l'arrivee de Wenvorth, un grand attachement semblait exister entre lui et Henriette.

eng: "You know," said she, "I cannot think him at all a fit match for Henrietta; and considering the alliances which the Musgroves have made, she has no right to throw herself away.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She looked down very decidedly upon the Hayters, and thought it would be quite a misfortune to have the existing connection between the families renewed--very sad for herself and her children.
fr: Elle regardait comme une veritable infortune pour elle et pour ses enfants que de nouveaux liens de parente s'etablissent avec cette famille.'

eng: It suited Mary best to think Henrietta the one preferred on the very account of Charles Hayter, whose pretensions she wished to see put an end to.
fr: Marie aurait voulu qu'Henriette fut preferee pour mettre fin aux pretentions de Hayter.

eng: That would be a noble thing, indeed, for Henrietta! She would take place of me then, and Henrietta would not dislike that. Sir Frederick and Lady Wentworth! It would be but a new creation, however, and I never think much of your new creations."
fr: C'est elle qui prendrait ma place en ce cas, et cela ne lui deplairait pas. Mais apres tout, ce ne serait qu'une nouvelle noblesse, et je n'en fais pas grand cas. >>

eng: Charles gave it for Louisa, Mary for Henrietta, but quite agreeing that to have him marry either could be extremely delightful.
fr: Charles penchait pour Louise, Marie pour Henriette, et tous les deux s'accordaient a dire qu'un mariage avec l'une ou avec l'autre serait extremement desirable.

eng: Oh! it would be a capital match for either of his sisters."
fr: << Dieu ! s'ecriait Marie, s'il allait s'elever aux plus grands honneurs !

eng: Here was a fortune at once; besides which, there would be the chance of what might be done in any future war; and he was sure Captain Wentworth was as likely a man to distinguish himself as any officer in the navy.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Charles "had never seen a pleasanter man in his life; and from what he had once heard Captain Wentworth himself say, was very sure that he had not made less than twenty thousand pounds by the war.
fr: Wenvorth avait du, d'apres ses propres paroles, gagner 50 000 livres pendant la guerre ; c'etait une fortune, et s'il survenait une autre guerre, il etait homme a se distinguer.

eng: "Upon my word it would," replied Mary. "Dear me! If he should rise to any very great honours! If he should ever be made a baronet! 'Lady Wentworth' sounds very well.
fr: S'il etait cree baronnet ! Lady Wenvorth ! cela sonne tres bien. Quelle chance pour Henriette.

eng: Henrietta was perhaps the prettiest, Louisa had the higher spirits; and she knew not now, whether the more gentle or the more lively character were most likely to attract him.
fr: Henriette etait peut-etre plus jolie, Louise plus intelligente.

eng: He was in orders; and having a curacy in the neighbourhood, where residence was not required, lived at his father's house, only two miles from Uppercross.
fr: Il etait dans les ordres, mais sa presence n'etant pas exigee a la cure, il vivait chez son pere a une demi-lieue d'Uppercross.

eng: Henrietta fully thought so herself, before Captain Wentworth came; but from that time Cousin Charles had been very much forgotten.
fr: Henriette semblait avoir oublie son cousin ; on se demandait si elle etait aimee du capitaine.

eng: Charles's attentions to Henrietta had been observed by her father and mother without any disapprobation. "It would not be a great match for her; but if Henrietta liked him,"-- and Henrietta did seem to like him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The two families had always been on excellent terms, there being no pride on one side, and no envy on the other, and only such a consciousness of superiority in the Miss Musgroves, as made them pleased to improve their cousins.
fr: Les deux familles avaient toujours ete dans des termes excellents, car d'un cote il n'y avait pas d'orgueil ; de l'autre, pas d'envie. Les misses Musgrove avaient seulement une conscience de leur superiorite qui leur faisait patronner leurs cousines avec plaisir.

eng: Mr Hayter had some property of his own, but it was insignificant compared with Mr Musgrove's; and while the Musgroves were in the first class of society in the country, the young Hayters would, from their parents' inferior, retired, and unpolished way of living, and their own defective education, have been hardly in any class at all, but for their connexion with Uppercross, this eldest son of course excepted, who had chosen to be a scholar and a gentleman, and who was very superior in cultivation and manners to all the rest.
fr: Tandis que les Musgrove etaient les premiers de la contree, la vie mesquine et retiree des Hayter, l'education peu soignee des enfants, les auraient places en dehors de la societe sans leurs relations avec Uppercross. Le fils aine etait seul excepte ; il etait tres superieur a sa famille comme manieres et culture d'esprit.

eng: They had each had money, but their marriages had made a material difference in their degree of consequence.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mrs Musgrove and Mrs Hayter were sisters.
fr: Mme Musgrove et Mme Hayter etaient soeurs, mais leur mariage leur avait fait une position tres differente.

eng: A short absence from home had left his fair one unguarded by his attentions at this critical period, and when he came back he had the pain of finding very altered manners, and of seeing Captain Wentworth.
fr: Une courte absence avait prive Henriette de ses attentions, et en revenant il vit avec chagrin qu'on avait pris sa place.

eng: There was not the smallest appearance of solicitude or remark about them in the Mansion-house; but it was different at the Cottage: the young couple there were more disposed to speculate and wonder; and Captain Wentworth had not been above four or five times in the Miss Musgroves' company, and Charles Hayter had but just reappeared, when Anne had to listen to the opinions of her brother and sister, as to which was the one liked best.
fr: Au cottage, c'etait different. Le jeune menage semblait plus dispose a faire des conjectures, et Anna eut bientot a ecouter leurs opinions sur la preference de Wenvorth.

eng: Which of the two sisters was preferred by Captain Wentworth was as yet quite doubtful, as far as Anne's observation reached.
fr: Laquelle des deux soeurs preferait-il ?

eng: Mr and Mrs Musgrove, either from seeing little, or from an entire confidence in the discretion of both their daughters, and of all the young men who came near them, seemed to leave everything to take its chance.
fr: Les parents, soit ignorance du monde, soit confiance dans la prudence de leurs filles, semblaient laisser tout au hasard et ne se preoccuper de rien.

eng: I do not think any young woman has a right to make a choice that may be disagreeable and inconvenient to the principal part of her family, and be giving bad connections to those who have not been used to them.
