fr: Il faut avouer que la cheminee de la salle a manger fume un peu, mais seulement quand le vent est grand et vient du nord, ce qui n'arrive pas trois fois par hiver,

eng: Mary had had her evils; but upon the whole, as was evident by her staying so long, she had found more to enjoy than to suffer.
fr: Marie avait eu des ennuis, mais son long sejour prouvait qu'elle avait eu plus de plaisir que de peine.

eng: Chapter 14
fr: CHAPITRE XIV

eng: Charles Hayter had been at Lyme oftener than suited her; and when they dined with the Harvilles there had been only a maid-servant to wait, and at first Mrs Harville had always given Mrs Musgrove precedence; but then, she had received so very handsome an apology from her on finding out whose daughter she was, and there had been so much going on every day, there had been so many walks between their lodgings and the Harvilles, and she had got books from the library, and changed them so often, that the balance had certainly been much in favour of Lyme.
fr: Charles Hayter etait venu plus souvent, il est vrai, qu'elle n'aurait voulu ; puis, chez les Harville, il n'y avait qu'un domestique pour servir a table, et au commencement on n'avait pas donne a Marie la premiere place. ~~~ Mais on lui avait fait de si gracieuses excuses, quand on avait su de qui elle etait fille, et l'on avait ete si prevenant ensuite ; on lui avait prete des livres, et l'on avait fait si souvent de jolies promenades, que la balance etait en faveur de Lyme.

eng: She had been taken to Charmouth too, and she had bathed, and she had gone to church, and there were a great many more people to look at in the church at Lyme than at Uppercross; and all this, joined to the sense of being so very useful, had made really an agreeable fortnight.
fr: Tout cela, joint a la conviction d'etre tres utile, lui avait fait passer une agreable quinzaine.

eng: Anne enquired after Captain Benwick.
fr: Anna s'informa de Benwick.

eng: "I declare, Charles, I never heard him mention Anne twice all the time I was there.
fr: << Je vous assure, Charles, que je ne l'ai pas entendu nommer Anna deux fois.

eng: Mary's face was clouded directly.
fr: La figure de Marie se rembrunit aussitot.

eng: I declare, Anne, he never talks of you at all."
fr: -- Je n'en sais rien, mais il vous admire beaucoup.

eng: "No," admitted Charles, "I do not know that he ever does, in a general way; but however, it is a very clear thing that he admires you exceedingly.
fr: Sa tete est remplie des lectures que vous lui avez recommandees, et il desire en causer avec vous.

eng: His head is full of some books that he is reading upon your recommendation, and he wants to talk to you about them; he has found out something or other in one of them which he thinks--oh! I cannot pretend to remember it, but it was something very fine--I overheard him telling Henrietta all about it; and then 'Miss Elliot' was spoken of in the highest terms!
fr: Il a decouvert... oh ! je ne puis me rappeler quoi, quelque chose de tres beau. Il expliquait cela a Henriette, et, parlant de vous, il prononcait les mots : elegance, douceur, beaute. Oh !

eng: Now Mary, I declare it was so, I heard it myself, and you were in the other room.
fr: ~~~ je l'ai entendu, Marie ; vous etiez dans l'autre chambre : il ne pouvait tarir sur les perfections de miss Elliot.

eng: 'Elegance, sweetness, beauty.'
fr: -- Il faut convenir, dit Marie avec vivacite, que, s'il a dit cela, ce n'est pas a sa louange :

eng: Oh! there was no end of Miss Elliot's charms."
fr: sa femme est morte en juin dernier.

eng: "And I am sure," cried Mary, warmly, "it was a very little to his credit, if he did.
fr: Un coeur pareil n'est pas desirable ; n'est-ce pas, lady Russel ?

eng: Miss Harville only died last June.
fr: -- Et je vous affirme que vous le verrez bientot, dit Charles, il n'a pas eu le courage de venir au cottage, mais il trouvera quelque jour la route de Kellynch, comptez-y.

eng: Such a heart is very little worth having; is it, Lady Russell? I am sure you will agree with me."
fr: Je lui ai dit que l'eglise meritait d'etre vue, et comme il a du gout pour ces sortes de choses il aura la un bon pretexte.

eng: "I must see Captain Benwick before I decide," said Lady Russell, smiling.
fr: ~~~ Il a ecoute avidement, et je suis sur qu'il viendra bientot. Ainsi je vous avertis, lady Russel. --

eng: "And that you are very likely to do very soon, I can tell you, ma'am," said Charles.
fr: Les amis d'Anna seront toujours les bienvenus chez moi, repondit-elle obligeamment. --

eng: "Though he had not nerves for coming away with us, and setting off again afterwards to pay a formal visit here, he will make his way over to Kellynch one day by himself, you may depend on it.
fr: Oh !'

eng: "Oh! he talks of you," cried Charles, "in such terms--"
fr: << Oh ! il parle de vous dans des termes... >>

eng: So, I give you notice, Lady Russell."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mary interrupted him.
fr: Marie l'interrompit :

eng: "Any acquaintance of Anne's will always be welcome to me," was Lady Russell's kind answer.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She boldly acknowledged herself flattered, and continued her enquiries.
fr: Elle dit qu'on la flattait trop, et continua a questionner.

eng: Anne's good-will, however, was not to be lessened by what she heard.
fr: Le bon vouloir d'Anna cependant n'en fut point diminue.

eng: But Mary did not give into it very graciously, whether from not considering Captain Benwick entitled by birth and situation to be in love with an Elliot, or from not wanting to believe Anne a greater attraction to Uppercross than herself, must be left to be guessed.
fr: Marie laissa tomber la conversation, soit qu'elle ne jugeat pas Benwick digne de pretendre a une miss Elliot, soit qu'elle ne reconnut pas a Anna le pouvoir de rendre Uppercross plus attrayant.

eng: Mary knows it is."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: That is the fact, upon my honour.
fr: Voila la verite ; parole d'honneur. >>

eng: "He fancied that if he went with us, he should find you close by: he fancied everybody to be living in Uppercross; and when he discovered that Lady Russell lived three miles off, his heart failed him, and he had not courage to come.
fr: Il s'imaginait vous trouver ici ; quand il a su que vous etiez a une lieue de nous, il n'a pas eu le courage de venir.

eng: It was all your doing," (turning to Anne.)
fr: Voici votre oeuvre, dit-il a Anna.

eng: Charles laughed again and said, "Now Mary, you know very well how it really was.
fr: Charles dit en riant : << Mais, Marie, vous savez bien ce qu'il en est.

eng: I suppose he was afraid of finding it dull; but upon my word I should have thought we were lively enough at the Cottage for such a heart-broken man as Captain Benwick."
fr: Il a sans doute craint de s'ennuyer, mais en verite j'aurais cru que nous etions assez gais au cottage pour le coeur brise du capitaine Benwick. >>

eng: We asked him to come home with us for a day or two: Charles undertook to give him some shooting, and he seemed quite delighted, and, for my part, I thought it was all settled; when behold! on Tuesday night, he made a very awkward sort of excuse; 'he never shot' and he had 'been quite misunderstood,' and he had promised this and he had promised that, and the end of it was, I found, that he did not mean to come.
fr: Nous lui avons demande de venir passer quelques jours chez nous ; Charles devait l'emmener a la chasse. Il paraissait tres content, quand, mardi soir, il donna une singuliere excuse : Il ne chassait jamais ; on ne l'avait pas compris : il avait promis ceci, puis cela, etc. ; enfin il ne venait pas.

eng: I do not know what he would be at.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh! Captain Benwick is very well, I believe, but he is a very odd young man.
fr: << Oh ! Benwick va tres bien, dit Marie ; mais c'est un drole de garcon. Il ne sait ce qu'il veut.

eng: Charles laughed.
fr: Charles se mit a rire :

eng: "Oh!'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I told him the distance and the road, and I told him of the church's being so very well worth seeing; for as he has a taste for those sort of things, I thought that would be a good excuse, and he listened with all his understanding and soul; and I am sure from his manner that you will have him calling here soon.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: as to being Anne's acquaintance," said Mary, "I think he is rather my acquaintance, for I have been seeing him every day this last fortnight."
fr: dit Marie, quant a etre une connaissance d'Anna, il est plutot la mienne, car je l'ai vu tous les jours de cette quinzaine.

eng: "Yes, that he will!" exclaimed Mary, tauntingly. "He will sit poring over his book, and not know when a person speaks to him, or when one drops one's scissors, or anything that happens. Do you think Lady Russell would like that?"
fr: '-- Oui, s'ecria railleusement Marie. Il meditera sur son livre, et ne saura pas si on lui parle, ou si on laisse tomber ses ciseaux. Croyez-vous que lady Russel aime cela ?'

eng: The Musgroves came back to receive their happy boys and girls from school, bringing with them Mrs Harville's little children, to improve the noise of Uppercross, and lessen that of Lyme. Henrietta remained with Louisa; but all the rest of the family were again in their usual quarters. Lady Russell and Anne paid their compliments to them once, when Anne could not but feel that Uppercross was already quite alive again. Though neither Henrietta, nor Louisa, nor Charles Hayter, nor Captain Wentworth were there, the room presented as strong a contrast as could be wished to the last state she had seen it in.
fr: '~~~ Apres l'avoir attendu une semaine, lady Russel le declara indigne de l'interet qu'il avait commence a lui inspirer. Les Musgrove revinrent pour les vacances de leurs enfants et ramenerent avec eux ceux de Mme Harville, Henriette resta avec Louisa. Lady Russel et Anna allerent faire visite a Mansion-House : la maison avait deja repris quelque gaite.'

eng: "Well, as your joint acquaintance, then, I shall be very happy to see Captain Benwick."
fr: '-- Eh bien, je serai tres heureuse de voir le capitaine Benwick comme votre connaissance a toutes deux.'

eng: "You will not find anything very agreeable in him, I assure you, ma'am. He is one of the dullest young men that ever lived."
fr: '-- Vous ne trouverez rien de tres agreable en lui, je vous assure : c'est l'homme le plus ennuyeux qu'on puisse voir.'

eng: "He has walked with me, sometimes, from one end of the sands to the other, without saying a word. He is not at all a well-bred young man. I am sure you will not like him."
fr: 'Il s'est promene sur la plage avec moi, plusieurs fois, sans dire un mot : Il n'est pas bien eleve, et il est certain que vous ne l'aimerez pas.'

eng: "There we differ, Mary," said Anne. "I think Lady Russell would like him. I think she would be so much pleased with his mind, that she would very soon see no deficiency in his manner."
fr: '-- En cela, nous differons, dit Anna. Je crois que lady Russel l'aimera, et que son esprit lui plaira tellement qu'elle ne trouvera aucun defaut a ses manieres.'

eng: "So do I, Anne," said Charles. "I am sure Lady Russell would like him. He is just Lady Russell's sort. Give him a book, and he will read all day long."
fr: '-- Je pense comme vous, dit Charles. Il a justement ce qu'il faut pour lady Russel. Donnez-lui un livre, et il lira toute la journee.'

eng: Immediately surrounding Mrs Musgrove were the little Harvilles, whom she was sedulously guarding from the tyranny of the two children from the Cottage, expressly arrived to amuse them. On one side was a table occupied by some chattering girls, cutting up silk and gold paper; and on the other were tressels and trays, bending under the weight of brawn and cold pies, where riotous boys were holding high revel; the whole completed by a roaring Christmas fire, which seemed determined to be heard, in spite of all the noise of the others. Charles and Mary also came in, of course, during their visit, and Mr Musgrove made a point of paying his respects to Lady Russell, and sat down close to her for ten minutes, talking with a very raised voice, but from the clamour of the children on his knees, generally in vain.
fr: 'Mme Musgrove, entouree des petits Harville, les protegeait contre la tyrannie des enfants du cottage. D'un cote on voyait une table occupee par les jeunes filles babillardes, decoupant des papiers d'or et de soie ; d'un autre, des plateaux charges de patisseries auxquelles les joyeux garcons faisaient fete. Un brillant feu de Noel faisait entendre son petillement en depit du bruit. Charles et Marie etaient la aussi ; M. Musgrove s'entretenait avec lady Russel et ne parvenait pas a se faire entendre, assourdi par les cris des enfants qu'il avait sur les genoux.'

eng: Lady Russell could not help laughing. "Upon my word," said she, "I should not have supposed that my opinion of any one could have admitted of such difference of conjecture, steady and matter of fact as I may call myself. I have really a curiosity to see the person who can give occasion to such directly opposite notions. I wish he may be induced to call here. And when he does, Mary, you may depend upon hearing my opinion; but I am determined not to judge him beforehand."
fr: '>> Lady Russel ne put s'empecher de rire : << En verite, dit-elle, je n'aurais pas suppose que l'opinion d'une personne calme et positive comme moi put etre appreciee si differemment. Je suis vraiment curieuse de voir celui qui peut donner lieu a des idees si opposees. Il faut le decider a venir ici. Soyez sure, alors, Marie, que je dirai mon opinion ; mais je suis decidee a ne pas le juger d'avance.'

eng: Lady Russell began talking of something else.
fr: '>> Lady Russel causa d'autre chose.'

eng: Mary spoke with animation of their meeting with, or rather missing, Mr Elliot so extraordinarily.
fr: 'Marie parla avec animation de la rencontre de M. Elliot.'

eng: "He is a man," said Lady Russell, "whom I have no wish to see. His declining to be on cordial terms with the head of his family, has left a very strong impression in his disfavour with me."
fr: '<< C'est un homme, dit lady Russel, que je ne desire pas voir. Son refus d'etre en bons termes avec le chef de la famille m'a laisse une impression defavorable. >>'

eng: This decision checked Mary's eagerness, and stopped her short in the midst of the Elliot countenance.
fr: 'Cette reflexion abattit l'enthousiasme de Marie et l'arreta court dans sa description.'

eng: With regard to Captain Wentworth, though Anne hazarded no enquiries, there was voluntary communication sufficient. His spirits had been greatly recovering lately as might be expected. As Louisa improved, he had improved, and he was now quite a different creature from what he had been the first week. He had not seen Louisa; and was so extremely fearful of any ill consequence to her from an interview, that he did not press for it at all; and, on the contrary, seemed to have a plan of going away for a week or ten days, till her head was stronger. He had talked of going down to Plymouth for a week, and wanted to persuade Captain Benwick to go with him; but, as Charles maintained to the last, Captain Benwick seemed much more disposed to ride over to Kellynch.
fr: 'Anna n'osa faire de questions sur Wenvorth, mais elle sut qu'il etait moins inquiet a mesure que Louisa se remettait. Il n'avait pas vu Louisa et craignait tellement l'emotion d'une entrevue avec elle, qu'il avait resolu de s'absenter une dizaine de jours. A partir de ce moment, lady Russel et Anna penserent souvent a Benwick.'

eng: There can be no doubt that Lady Russell and Anne were both occasionally thinking of Captain Benwick, from this time. Lady Russell could not hear the door-bell without feeling that it might be his herald; nor could Anne return from any stroll of solitary indulgence in her father's grounds, or any visit of charity in the village, without wondering whether she might see him or hear of him. Captain Benwick came not, however. He was either less disposed for it than Charles had imagined, or he was too shy; and after giving him a week's indulgence, Lady Russell determined him to be unworthy of the interest which he had been beginning to excite.
fr: 'Lady Russel ne pouvait entendre sonner sans croire aussitot que c'etait lui, et Anna, chaque fois qu'elle sortait, se demandait en rentrant si elle allait le trouver a la maison. Cependant on ne vit pas Benwick. Etait-il moins desireux de venir que Charles ne le croyait, ou etait-ce timidite de sa part ?'

eng: "You will not like him, I will answer for it."
fr: '-- Vous ne l'aimerez pas, je vous en reponds.'

eng: It was a fine family-piece.
fr: C'etait un beau tableau de famille.

eng: Anne, judging from her own temperament, would have deemed such a domestic hurricane a bad restorative of the nerves, which Louisa's illness must have so greatly shaken.
fr: Anna, jugeant les choses d'apres son temperament, trouvait que cet ouragan domestique n'etait guere fait pour calmer les nerfs de Louisa, si elle eut ete la ; mais Mme Musgrove n'en jugeait pas ainsi.

eng: But Mrs Musgrove, who got Anne near her on purpose to thank her most cordially, again and again, for all her attentions to them, concluded a short recapitulation of what she had suffered herself by observing, with a happy glance round the room, that after all she had gone through, nothing was so likely to do her good as a little quiet cheerfulness at home.
fr: Apres avoir chaudement remercie Anna de tous ses services, et recapitule tout ce qu'elle-meme avait souffert, elle dit, en jetant un regard heureux autour d'elle, que rien ne pouvait lui faire plus de bien que cette petite gaite tranquille.

eng: Mr Elliot, and his friends in Marlborough Buildings, were talked of the whole evening. "Colonel Wallis had been so impatient to be introduced to them! and Mr Elliot so anxious that he should!"
fr: Voila ce que disait le modeste Sir Walter ; mais sa fille et Mme Clay ne lui permettaient pas de s'effacer ainsi et affirmaient qu'il avait au moins aussi bon air que le colonel, dont les cheveux etaient gris.

eng: She persisted in a very determined, though very silent disinclination for Bath; caught the first dim view of the extensive buildings, smoking in rain, without any wish of seeing them better; felt their progress through the streets to be, however disagreeable, yet too rapid; for who would be glad to see her when she arrived?
fr: elle persistait dans son antipathie pour Bath. Elle apercut la longue suite de maisons enfumees, sans eprouver le desir de les voir de plus pres : le trajet, quoique desagreable, lui sembla trop rapide, car personne ne la desirait,

eng: Allowances, large allowances, she knew, must be made for the ideas of those who spoke.
fr: Tout en faisant la part de l'exageration,

eng: Anne listened, but without quite understanding it.
fr: Anna ecoutait, mais sans comprendre.

eng: Mr Elliot had called repeatedly, had dined with them once, evidently delighted by the distinction of being asked, for they gave no dinners in general; delighted, in short, by every proof of cousinly notice, and placing his whole happiness in being on intimate terms in Camden Place.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Sir Walter seemed to admit it as complete apology; and though Elizabeth could not see the circumstance in quite so favourable a light, she allowed it be a great extenuation.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A very fine woman with a large fortune, in love with him!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Here was a great deal to soften the business.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Without that attraction, not all her money would have tempted Elliot, and Sir Walter was, moreover, assured of her having been a very fine woman.
fr: Tout cela attenuait beaucoup sa faute, et Sir Walter l'excusa completement : il l'avait recu, invite a diner, et M. Elliot paraissait tres heureux.

eng: She had sought him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She heard it all under embellishment.
fr: elle sentait qu'il y avait quelque chose d'inexplicable dans la conduite actuelle de M. Elliot, dans son desir si vif de renouer des relations si longtemps interrompues.

eng: There had been the charm.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Colonel Wallis had known Mr Elliot long, had been well acquainted also with his wife, had perfectly understood the whole story.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: This was an article not to be entered on by himself; but a very intimate friend of his, a Colonel Wallis, a highly respectable man, perfectly the gentleman, (and not an ill-looking man, Sir Walter added), who was living in very good style in Marlborough Buildings, and had, at his own particular request, been admitted to their acquaintance through Mr Elliot, had mentioned one or two things relative to the marriage, which made a material difference in the discredit of it.
fr: Il, avait connu la femme de son ami ; elle n'etait pas de famille noble, mais elle etait instruite, bien elevee et riche et adorait William Elliot.

eng: The circumstances of his marriage, too, were found to admit of much extenuation.
fr: Ce fut le colonel Wallis, son ami intime, qui fournit une excuse pour le mariage de M. Elliot.

eng: He could refer Sir Walter to all who knew him; and certainly, the pains he had been taking on this, the first opportunity of reconciliation, to be restored to the footing of a relation and heir-presumptive, was a strong proof of his opinions on the subject.
fr: Sir Walter pouvait en appeler a tous ceux qui connaissaient M. Elliot, et, certainement, les efforts qu'il avait faits pour se reconcilier avec la famille etaient une preuve en sa faveur.

eng: He was astonished, indeed, but his character and general conduct must refute it.
fr: Son caractere et sa conduite dementaient cette accusation.

eng: He, who had ever boasted of being an Elliot, and whose feelings, as to connection, were only too strict to suit the unfeudal tone of the present day.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, already mentioned)

eng: Upon the hint of having spoken disrespectfully or carelessly of the family and the family honours, he was quite indignant.
fr: Il etait indigne qu'on eut pu l'accuser d'avoir parle de la famille sans respect ; lui, qui s'etait toujours vante d'etre un Elliot, et qui avait, sur la parente, des idees trop strictes pour l'epoque actuelle !

eng: He had never had an idea of throwing himself off; he had feared that he was thrown off, but knew not why, and delicacy had kept him silent.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She was certainly not a woman of family, but well educated, accomplished, rich, and excessively in love with his friend.
fr: Voila ce qui l'avait seduit, et non sa fortune.

eng: All that sounded extravagant or irrational in the progress of the reconciliation might have no origin but in the language of the relators.
fr: Materiellement parlant, il n'y gagnait rien, puisque le domaine et le titre de Kellynch lui revenaient en tout cas.

eng: Still, however, she had the sensation of there being something more than immediately appeared, in Mr Elliot's wishing, after an interval of so many years, to be well received by them.
fr: Elle ne trouvait qu'une solution : c'etait peut-etre a cause d'Elisabeth.

eng: In a worldly view, he had nothing to gain by being on terms with Sir Walter; nothing to risk by a state of variance.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "How is Mary looking?" said Sir Walter, in the height of his good humour.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Modest Sir Walter! He was not allowed to escape, however. His daughter and Mrs Clay united in hinting that Colonel Wallis's companion might have as good a figure as Colonel Wallis, and certainly was not sandy-haired.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Such scarecrows as the streets were full of! It was evident how little the women were used to the sight of anything tolerable, by the effect which a man of decent appearance produced. He had never walked anywhere arm-in-arm with Colonel Wallis (who was a fine military figure, though sandy-haired) without observing that every woman's eye was upon him; every woman's eye was sure to be upon Colonel Wallis."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The worst of Bath was the number of its plain women. He did not mean to say that there were no pretty women, but the number of the plain was out of all proportion. He had frequently observed, as he walked, that one handsome face would be followed by thirty, or five-and-thirty frights; and once, as he had stood in a shop on Bond Street, he had counted eighty-seven women go by, one after another, without there being a tolerable face among them. It had been a frosty morning, to be sure, a sharp frost, which hardly one woman in a thousand could stand the test of. But still, there certainly were a dreadful multitude of ugly women in Bath; and as for the men! they were infinitely worse.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Sir Walter thought much of Mrs Wallis; she was said to be an excessively pretty woman, beautiful. "He longed to see her. He hoped she might make some amends for the many very plain faces he was continually passing in the streets.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: and there was a Mrs Wallis, at present known only to them by description, as she was in daily expectation of her confinement; but Mr Elliot spoke of her as "a most charming woman, quite worthy of being known in Camden Place," and as soon as she recovered they were to be acquainted.
fr: << Quelle figure a Marie ? dit Sir Walter, a l'apogee de sa bonne humeur.'

eng: Mr Elliot appeared to think that he (Sir Walter) was looking exactly as he had done when they last parted;" but Sir Walter had "not been able to return the compliment entirely, which had embarrassed him. He did not mean to complain, however. Mr Elliot was better to look at than most men, and he had no objection to being seen with him anywhere."
fr: Les hommes etaient autant d'epouvantails dont les rues etaient pleines. A la maniere dont les femmes regardaient le colonel Wallis, quand il marchait au bras de Sir Walter, on pouvait juger combien rarement elles voyaient un bel homme.

eng: He did justice to his very gentlemanlike appearance, his air of elegance and fashion, his good shaped face, his sensible eye; but, at the same time, "must lament his being very much under-hung, a defect which time seemed to have increased; nor could he pretend to say that ten years had not altered almost every feature for the worse.
fr: Un jour il avait compte quatre-vingt-sept femmes, sans en trouver une passable. Il est vrai que c'etait par un froid brouillard du matin.

eng: They were describing him themselves; Sir Walter especially.
fr: C'etait la le fleau de Bath.

eng: They could not listen to her description of him.
fr: Sir Walter desirait connaitre Mme Wallis ; on la disait tres jolie ; cela le dedommagerait des laids visages qu'il rencontrait a chaque instant dans les rues.

eng: "Oh! yes, perhaps, it had been Mr Elliot. They did not know. It might be him, perhaps."
fr: On ne parla, le soir, que de M. Elliot et de M. Wallis ;

eng: Anne mentioned the glimpses she had had of him at Lyme, but without being much attended to.
fr: Il convenait aussi qu'il avait vieilli ; tandis que M. Elliot affirmait que Sir Walter n'avait pas change depuis dix ans.

eng: Most earnestly did she wish that he might not be too nice, or too observant if Elizabeth were his object; and that Elizabeth was disposed to believe herself so, and that her friend Mrs Clay was encouraging the idea, seemed apparent by a glance or two between them, while Mr Elliot's frequent visits were talked of.
fr: Sir Walter rendait justice a William Elliot, a son elegance, a sa figure agreable, mais il deplorait son attitude penchee, defaut que le temps avait augmente.

eng: How her temper and understanding might bear the investigation of his present keener time of life was another concern and rather a fearful one.
fr: Mme Clay encourageait Elisabeth dans la pensee qu'Elliot la recherchait ; elles echangeaient des regards qu'Anna surprit au passage.

eng: Elizabeth was certainly very handsome, with well-bred, elegant manners, and her character might never have been penetrated by Mr Elliot, knowing her but in public, and when very young himself.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, already mentioned)

eng: There might really have been a liking formerly, though convenience and accident had drawn him a different way; and now that he could afford to please himself, he might mean to pay his addresses to her.
fr: Anna se demandait avec inquietude comment Elisabeth pourrait soutenir un examen plus attentif, et souhaitait qu'Elliot ne fut pas trop perspicace.

eng: She could only offer one solution; it was, perhaps, for Elizabeth's sake.
fr: Sa soeur etait certainement tres belle, ses manieres etaient distinguees et elegantes ; et Elliot, qui ne l'avait vue qu'en public, ne connaissait peut-etre pas son caractere.

eng: A sensible man, and he had looked like a very sensible man, why should it be an object to him?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: In all probability he was already the richer of the two, and the Kellynch estate would as surely be his hereafter as the title.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It had originated in misapprehension entirely.
fr: Il avait cru qu'on voulait rompre avec lui, et s'etait retire par delicatesse.

eng: He had explained away all the appearance of neglect on his own side.
fr: son impolitesse apparente venait d'un malentendu.

eng: They had not a fault to find in him.
fr: Ils se justifia a tous egards ;

eng: Chapter 15 Sir Walter had taken a very good house in Camden Place, a lofty dignified situation, such as becomes a man of consequence; and both he and Elizabeth were settled there, much to their satisfaction.
fr: CHAPITRE XV Sir Walter avait loue dans le quartier aristocratique une maison de grande apparence dont lui et Elisabeth etaient tres satisfaits.

eng: He had been in Bath about a fortnight; (he had passed through Bath in November, in his way to London, when the intelligence of Sir Walter's being settled there had of course reached him, though only twenty-four hours in the place, but he had not been able to avail himself of it;) but he had now been a fortnight in Bath, and his first object on arriving, had been to leave his card in Camden Place, following it up by such assiduous endeavours to meet, and when they did meet, by such great openness of conduct, such readiness to apologize for the past, such solicitude to be received as a relation again, that their former good understanding was completely re-established.
fr: Il avait passe quinze jours a Bath et, des son arrivee, avait depose sa carte a Camben-Place. Il y fut ensuite tres assidu, et montra une telle franchise, une telle hate a s'excuser du passe, et un si grand desir d'etre recu a l'avenir comme un parent, que la bonne entente d'autrefois fut completement retablie.

eng: She was put down in Camden Place; and Lady Russell then drove to her own lodgings, in Rivers Street.
fr: Elle descendit a Camben-Place, et lady Russel a son appartement, rue River.

eng: Anne was not animated to an equal pitch by the circumstance, but she felt that she would rather see Mr Elliot again than not, which was more than she could say for many other persons in Bath.
fr: Anna n'y mettait pas autant d'animation, mais elle preferait le revoir, et elle n'aurait pu en dire autant de bien d'autres a Bath.

eng: If he really sought to reconcile himself like a dutiful branch, he must be forgiven for having dismembered himself from the paternal tree.
fr: s'il cherchait reellement a se reconcilier, il fallait lui pardonner de s'etre ecarte de la famille.

eng: She had a great wish to see him.
fr: Maintenant elle desirait vivement le voir ;

eng: This was very wonderful if it were true; and Lady Russell was in a state of very agreeable curiosity and perplexity about Mr Elliot, already recanting the sentiment she had so lately expressed to Mary, of his being "a man whom she had no wish to see."
fr: ~~~ Cela etait fort etonnant. Lady Russel etait tres curieuse et tres perplexe, et retractait deja ce qu'elle avait dit a Anna : << Un homme qu'elle n'avait aucun desir de voir. >>

eng: If Elizabeth and her father did not deceive themselves, had been taking much pains to seek the acquaintance, and proclaim the value of the connection, as he had formerly taken pains to shew neglect.
fr: Si Elisabeth et son pere ne se trompaient pas, il les recherchait avec autant de soin qu'il en avait mis a les eviter.

eng: He had called in Camden Place; had called a second time, a third; had been pointedly attentive.
fr: Il etait venu plusieurs fois a Camben-Place et s'etait montre extremement attentif.

eng: Anne entered it with a sinking heart, anticipating an imprisonment of many months, and anxiously saying to herself, "Oh! when shall I leave you again?"
fr: Anna avait le coeur triste en entrant ; elle voyait devant elle un emprisonnement de plusieurs mois, et se disait avec anxiete : << Ah ! quand partirai-je ? >>

eng: Mr Elliot was in Bath.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, already mentioned)

eng: And looked back, with fond regret, to the bustles of Uppercross and the seclusion of Kellynch.
fr: et elle donna un souvenir de regret a la gaite bruyante d'Uppercross et a la solitude de Kellynch-Lodge.

eng: Anne did not share these feelings.
fr: Anna n'etait pas de cet avis :

eng: No, these were noises which belonged to the winter pleasures; her spirits rose under their influence; and like Mrs Musgrove, she was feeling, though not saying, that after being long in the country, nothing could be so good for her as a little quiet cheerfulness.
fr: Elle se sentait renaitre, et, comme Mme Musgrove, elle pensait, mais sans le dire, qu'apres avoir ete longtemps a la campagne, rien n'etait si bon pour elle qu'une petite distraction tranquille.

eng: When Lady Russell not long afterwards, was entering Bath on a wet afternoon, and driving through the long course of streets from the Old Bridge to Camden Place, amidst the dash of other carriages, the heavy rumble of carts and drays, the bawling of newspapermen, muffin-men and milkmen, and the ceaseless clink of pattens, she made no complaint.
fr: Peu de temps apres, elle arriva a Bath par un pluvieux apres-midi, longeant la longue suite de rues depuis Old-Bridge jusqu'a Camben-Place, eclaboussee par les equipages, assourdie par le bruit des charrettes et des camions, par les cris de marchands de journaux et de gateaux, ceux des laitieres et des pietons, elle ne se plaignit pas : non, c'etaient la des bruits appartenant aux plaisirs de l'hiver.

eng: Everybody has their taste in noises as well as in other matters; and sounds are quite innoxious, or most distressing, by their sort rather than their quantity.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I hope I shall remember, in future," said Lady Russell, as soon as they were reseated in the carriage, "not to call at Uppercross in the Christmas holidays."
fr: << Je me souviendrai a l'avenir qu'il ne faut pas venir ici pendant les vacances de Noel, >> dit lady Russel une fois montee en voiture.

eng: Captain Wentworth was gone, for the present, to see his brother in Shropshire.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The Harvilles had promised to come with her and stay at Uppercross, whenever she returned.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Elizabeth's last letter had communicated a piece of news of some interest.
fr: La derniere lettre d'Elisabeth lui annoncait que M. Elliot etait a Bath.

eng: Her mother could even think of her being able to join their party at home, before her brothers and sisters went to school again.
fr: Les Harville avaient promis de la ramener a Uppercross et d'y rester quelque temps.

eng: A degree of unexpected cordiality, however, in the welcome she received, did her good.
fr: Elle fut recue cependant avec une cordialite inattendue qui lui fit du bien.

eng: Her making a fourth, when they sat down to dinner, was noticed as an advantage.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was not only pardoned, they were delighted with him.
fr: non seulement on lui pardonnait ; mais on en raffolait.

eng: Anne had a great deal to hear of Mr Elliot.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They had Mr Elliot too.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, already mentioned)

eng: But this was not all which they had to make them happy.
fr: Mais ce n'etait pas cela seul qui causait leur bonheur : c'etait la presence de M. Elliot ;

eng: She might not wonder, but she must sigh that her father should feel no degradation in his change, should see nothing to regret in the duties and dignity of the resident landholder, should find so much to be vain of in the littlenesses of a town; and she must sigh, and smile, and wonder too, as Elizabeth threw open the folding-doors and walked with exultation from one drawing-room to the other, boasting of their space; at the possibility of that woman, who had been mistress of Kellynch Hall, finding extent to be proud of between two walls, perhaps thirty feet asunder.
fr: Non ; mais elle s'attristait a la pensee que son pere eut abdique les devoirs et la dignite d'un lord residant sur ses terres, et qu'il n'en eut aucun regret ; que les petitesses d'une petite ville pussent satisfaire sa vanite. Elle soupirait, mais elle sourit quand Elisabeth, les portes ouvertes a deux battants, passa radieuse d'un salon dans un autre ; elle s'etonna que celle qui avait ete maitresse de Kellynch put trouver de quoi satisfaire son orgueil dans un espace de trente pieds de long.

eng: Could Anne wonder that her father and sister were happy?
fr: Anna pouvait-elle s'etonner que son pere et Elisabeth fussent heureux ?

eng: Here were funds of enjoyment.
fr: Quelles sources de plaisir !

eng: They had drawn back from many introductions, and still were perpetually having cards left by people of whom they knew nothing.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, implied)

eng: Everybody was wanting to visit them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, implied)

eng: Their acquaintance was exceedingly sought after.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, implied)

eng: Their house was undoubtedly the best in Camden Place; their drawing-rooms had many decided advantages over all the others which they had either seen or heard of, and the superiority was not less in the style of the fitting-up, or the taste of the furniture.
fr: Ils etaient recherches partout ; ils avaient refuse nombre de presentations, et encore a present beaucoup de personnes inconnues deposaient leurs cartes.

eng: They had the pleasure of assuring her that Bath more than answered their expectations in every respect.
fr: leur maison etait la plus belle de Camben-Place, leurs salons superieurs a tous ceux qu'ils avaient vus, aussi bien par l'arrangement que par le gout du mobilier.

eng: Uppercross excited no interest, Kellynch very little: it was all Bath.
fr: Bath avait completement repondu a leur attente :

eng: After laying out for some compliments of being deeply regretted in their old neighbourhood, which Anne could not pay, they had only a few faint enquiries to make, before the talk must be all their own.
fr: Apres quelques questions insignifiantes, la conversation n'eut plus d'autre sujet que Bath : on se souciait peu de Kellynch, et pas du tout d'Uppercross.

eng: They had no inclination to listen to her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They were evidently in excellent spirits, and she was soon to listen to the causes.
fr: Tout le monde etait de bonne humeur, et bientot Anna en sut la cause.

eng: Anne had always felt that she would pretend what was proper on her arrival, but the complaisance of the others was unlooked for.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mrs Clay was very pleasant, and very smiling, but her courtesies and smiles were more a matter of course.
fr: Mme Clay fut tres aimable et souriante, c'etait son habitude.

eng: Her father and sister were glad to see her, for the sake of shewing her the house and furniture, and met her with kindness.
fr: Son pere et sa soeur furent contents de l'avoir pour lui montrer la maison et l'ameublement ; puis elle faisait un vis-a-vis a table, ce qui etait plus gai.

eng: Louisa was now recovering apace.
fr: Anna apprit que Louisa se retablissait a vue d'oeil.

eng: "The last time I saw her she had a red nose, but I hope that may not happen every day."
fr: La derniere fois que je l'ai vue, elle avait le nez rouge, mais j'espere que cela ne lui arrive pas tous les jours.

eng: "If I thought it would not tempt her to go out in sharp winds, and grow coarse, I would send her a new hat and pelisse."
fr: '-- Si je ne craignais pas de lui donner la tentation de sortir par ce vent et de se gater le teint, je lui enverrais un chapeau neuf et une pelisse.

eng: '"Oh! no, that must have been quite accidental. In general she has been in very good health and very good looks since Michaelmas."
fr: '-- Oh ! non ; c'etait tout a fait accidentel ; depuis la Saint-Michel, elle a bonne mine et se porte bien.

eng: Anne was considering whether she should venture to suggest that a gown, or a cap, would not be liable to any such misuse, when a knock at the door suspended everything.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "A knock at the door! and so late! ~~~ It was ten o'clock. Could it be Mr Elliot? They knew he was to dine in Lansdown Crescent. It was possible that he might stop in his way home to ask them how they did. They could think of no one else. Mrs Clay decidedly thought it Mr Elliot's knock."
fr: >> On frappa a la porte. Qui pouvait-ce etre a dix heures ? Mme Clay reconnut la maniere de frapper de M. Elliot.

eng: Mrs Clay was right.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: You have been here only to be useful.'
fr: et n'avez fait que vous rendre utile.'

eng: I assure you I feel it none. She is nothing to me, compared with you;" and she was in full time to hear her father say, "My dear madam, this must not be.
fr: elle ne m'est rien, comparee a vous. >> Puis elle entendit son pere, qui disait : << Chere madame, cela ne doit pas etre.

eng: On going down to breakfast the next morning, she found there had just been a decent pretence on the lady's side of meaning to leave them. She could imagine Mrs Clay to have said, that "now Miss Anne was come, she could not suppose herself at all wanted;" for Elizabeth was replying in a sort of whisper, "That must not be any reason, indeed.
fr: Le lendemain matin, en descendant dejeuner, elle eut lieu de comprendre que cette dame avait trouve un pretexte pour s'en aller, car Elisabeth repondit tout bas : << Ce n'est pas une raison, je vous assure ;

eng: There was one point which Anne, on returning to her family, would have been more thankful to ascertain even than Mr Elliot's being in love with Elizabeth, which was, her father's not being in love with Mrs Clay; and she was very far from easy about it, when she had been at home a few hours.
fr: Il y avait une chose qu'Anna desirait connaitre par-dessus tout : c'etaient les sentiments de son pere pour Mme Clay. Apres quelques heures passees a la maison, elle etait loin d'etre tranquille.

eng: Chapter 16
fr: CHAPITRE XVI

eng: Anne could not have supposed it possible that her first evening in Camden Place could have passed so well!
fr: Anna n'aurait jamais cru passer si bien sa premiere soiree a Bath.

eng: He staid an hour with them. The elegant little clock on the mantel-piece had struck "eleven with its silver sounds," and the watchman was beginning to be heard at a distance telling the same tale, before Mr Elliot or any of them seemed to feel that he had been there long.
fr: L'elegante petite pendule aux sons argentins avait frappe onze heures avant que M. Elliot ni personne se fut apercu qu'il etait reste une heure.

eng: When he questioned, Sir Walter and Elizabeth began to question also, but the difference in their manner of doing it could not be unfelt. She could only compare Mr Elliot to Lady Russell, in the wish of really comprehending what had passed, and in the degree of concern for what she must have suffered in witnessing it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Having alluded to "an accident," he must hear the whole.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But he must not be addressing his reflections to Anne alone: he knew it; he was soon diffused again among the others, and it was only at intervals that he could return to Lyme. His enquiries, however, produced at length an account of the scene she had been engaged in there, soon after his leaving the place.
fr: Bientot, sentant qu'il ne devait pas s'adresser uniquement a Anna, il rendit la conversation plus generale. Il voulut entendre le recit de l'accident, et Anna put comparer l'interet avec lequel il ecoutait, a l'air indifferent de Sir Walter et d'Elisabeth.

eng: "The notions of a young man of one or two and twenty," said he, "as to what is necessary in manners to make him quite the thing, are more absurd, I believe, than those of any other set of beings in the world. The folly of the means they often employ is only to be equalled by the folly of what they have in view."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: As yet, you have seen nothing of Bath.
fr: Vous n'avez rien vu a Bath,

eng: She gave him a short account of her party and business at Lyme. His regret increased as he listened. He had spent his whole solitary evening in the room adjoining theirs; had heard voices, mirth continually; thought they must be a most delightful set of people, longed to be with them, but certainly without the smallest suspicion of his possessing the shadow of a right to introduce himself.
fr: Quand elle lui raconta leur voyage a Lyme, il regretta doublement sa soiree solitaire dans la chambre voisine. Il avait entendu des voix joyeuses, et aurait souhaite de se joindre a eux, mais il ne soupconnait guere qu'il pouvait y pretendre.

eng: As soon as he could, he began to talk to her of Lyme, wanting to compare opinions respecting the place, but especially wanting to speak of the circumstance of their happening to be guests in the same inn at the same time; to give his own route, understand something of hers, and regret that he should have lost such an opportunity of paying his respects to her.
fr: Il demanda a Anna ce qu'elle pensait de Lyme, et s'etendit surtout sur l'heureux hasard qui les avait reunis dans la meme auberge.

eng: He sat down with them, and improved their conversation very much. There could be no doubt of his being a sensible man. Ten minutes were enough to certify that. His tone, his expressions, his choice of subject, his knowing where to stop; it was all the operation of a sensible, discerning mind.
fr: Il s'assit et anima la conversation. Il savait choisir ses sujets, s'arreter quand il fallait. Son ton, ses expressions annoncaient beaucoup de tact.

eng: They were not the same, but they were, perhaps, equally good.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was quite as good-looking as he had appeared at Lyme, his countenance improved by speaking, and his manners were so exactly what they ought to be, so polished, so easy, so particularly agreeable, that she could compare them in excellence to only one person's manners.
fr: Sa physionomie parut a Anna aussi agreable qu'a Lyme. Ses manieres etaient si aisees, si charmantes, qu'elle ne pouvait le comparer qu'a une seule personne.

eng: He looked completely astonished, but not more astonished than pleased; his eyes brightened! and with the most perfect alacrity he welcomed the relationship, alluded to the past, and entreated to be received as an acquaintance already.
fr: Il fut aussi charme que surpris ; ses yeux brillerent de plaisir ; il fit allusion au passe, et sollicita les droits d'une ancienne connaissance.

eng: Sir Walter talked of his youngest daughter; "Mr Elliot must give him leave to present him to his youngest daughter" (there was no occasion for remembering Mary); and Anne, smiling and blushing, very becomingly shewed to Mr Elliot the pretty features which he had by no means forgotten, and instantly saw, with amusement at his little start of surprise, that he had not been at all aware of who she was.
fr: Quand les politesses furent echangees, Sir Walter presenta sa plus jeune fille, et Anna, souriante et rougissante, montra a M. Elliot le joli visage qu'il n'avait point oublie.

eng: Anne drew a little back, while the others received his compliments, and her sister his apologies for calling at so unusual an hour, but "he could not be so near without wishing to know that neither she nor her friend had taken cold the day before," &c. &c; which was all as politely done, and as politely taken, as possible, but her part must follow then.
fr: Anna se retira un peu a l'ecart, tandis qu'il s'excusait de venir a cette heure, mais il avait voulu savoir si Elisabeth et son amie n'avaient pas pris froid la nuit derniere.

eng: It was the same, the very same man, with no difference but of dress.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: If he had but asked who the party were! The name of Musgrove would have told him enough. "Well, it would serve to cure him of an absurd practice of never asking a question at an inn, which he had adopted, when quite a young man, on the principal of its being very ungenteel to be curious."
fr: Cela le guerirait, dit-il, de cette absurde habitude de ne questionner jamais.

eng: With all the state which a butler and foot-boy could give, Mr Elliot was ushered into the room.
fr: Il fut introduit avec ceremonie ;

eng: You must not run away from us now.
fr: Il ne faut pas nous fuir maintenant.

eng: You must stay to be acquainted with Mrs Wallis, the beautiful Mrs Wallis.
fr: Il faut rester, pour faire connaissance avec la belle madame Wallis.

eng: "The sight of Mrs Clay in such favour, and of Anne so overlooked, was a perpetual provocation to her there; and vexed her as much when she was away, as a person in Bath who drinks the water, gets all the new publications, and has a very large acquaintance, has time to be vexed."
fr: 'Elle etait aussi vexee que peut l'etre une personne qui passe son temps a prendre les eaux, a lire les nouvelles et a faire des visites.'

eng: "Lady Russell's composed mind and polite manners were put to some trial on this point, in her intercourse in Camden Place."
fr: 'La politesse et le savoir-vivre de celle-ci furent mis a l'epreuve quand elle vit Mme Clay en si grande faveur et Anna si negligee.'

eng: "As for herself, she might always command a home with Lady Russell."
fr: 'Quant a elle, elle pouvait demeurer avec lady Russel.'

eng: "The evil of a marriage would be much diminished, if Elizabeth were also to marry."
fr: 'Si Elisabeth se mariait, le mariage de son pere serait un mal moins grand.'

eng: "Such personal praise might have struck her, especially as it did not appear to Anne that the freckles were at all lessened."
fr: 'Ces louanges l'auraient d'autant plus etonnee que les marques en question n'avaient pas du tout disparu.'

eng: "But everything must take its chance."
fr: 'Mais il faut subir sa destinee, se dit Anna.'

eng: "If Elizabeth could but have heard this!"
fr: 'Si Elisabeth avait pu l'entendre !'

eng: "Had she been using any thing in particular?"
fr: 'Employait-elle quelque chose de particulier ?'

eng: "and added, "certainly you cannot do better than to continue as you are; you cannot be better than well; or I should recommend Gowland, the constant use of Gowland, during the spring months."
fr: 'et il ajouta : << Vous n'avez qu'a continuer ainsi : vous ne pouvez pas etre mieux qu'a present. Autrement, je vous conseillerais le constant usage du gowland pendant le printemps.'

eng: "~~~ "No, nothing." "Merely Gowland," he supposed. "No, nothing at all." "Ha! he was surprised at that;"
fr: '~~~ Peut-etre du gowland. Non ! rien du tout ? ~~~ Cela le surprenait,'

eng: "In the course of the same morning, Anne and her father chancing to be alone together, he began to compliment her on her improved looks; he thought her "less thin in her person, in her cheeks; her skin, her complexion, greatly improved; clearer, fresher."
fr: 'Sir Walter, se trouvant seul avec Anna, lui fit compliment de sa bonne mine. Il lui trouvait les joues plus pleines, le teint plus clair et plus frais.'

eng: "The lady could not but yield to such joint entreaties, and promise to stay."
fr: 'Elle ne pouvait resister a de si vives instances : elle resta.'

eng: "Her countenance, perhaps, might express some watchfulness; but the praise of the fine mind did not appear to excite a thought in her sister."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "He spoke and looked so much in earnest, that Anne was not surprised to see Mrs Clay stealing a glance at Elizabeth and herself."
fr: 'Il avait quelque chose de si vif dans les yeux et dans la voix, qu'Anna ne fut pas surprise du regard que Mme Clay jeta a Elisabeth.'

eng: "To your fine mind, I well know the sight of beauty is a real gratification."
fr: 'Je sais que la vue de la beaute est une reelle satisfaction pour votre esprit delicat.'

eng: "Mrs Clay has been using it at my recommendation, and you see what it has done for her. You see how it has carried away her freckles."
fr: 'Sur ma recommandation, Mme Clay l'a employe, et vous en voyez le resultat : ses marques de petite verole ont disparu. >>'

eng: As Mr Elliot became known to her, she grew more charitable, or more indifferent, towards the others.
fr: Quand elle connut davantage M. Elliot, elle devint plus charitable pour lui ou plus indifferente pour les autres.

eng: and yet, with a sensibility to what was amiable and lovely, and a value for all the felicities of domestic life, which characters of fancied enthusiasm and violent agitation seldom really possess.
fr: Lady Russel etait persuadee qu'il n'avait pas ete heureux en mariage ; le colonel Wallis le disait ; mais cela ne l'avait point aigri ; et lady Russel commencait a le soupconner de songer a un nouveau choix.

eng: She was sure that he had not been happy in marriage. Colonel Wallis said it, and Lady Russell saw it; but it had been no unhappiness to sour his mind, nor (she began pretty soon to suspect) to prevent his thinking of a second choice.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was steady, observant, moderate, candid; never run away with by spirits or by selfishness, which fancied itself strong feeling;
fr: Il appreciait tous les bonheurs de la vie domestique, qualite que possedent rarement les caracteres enthousiastes et remuants.

eng: he lived with the liberality of a man of fortune, without display;
fr: Il s'en rapportait a son propre jugement dans les choses importantes, mais ne heurtait pas l'opinion publique lorsqu'il s'agissait de decorum.

eng: and could not seriously picture to herself a more agreeable or estimable man.
fr: et qu'elle ne pouvait imaginer un homme plus parfait : intelligence, jugement, connaissance du monde, et avec cela un coeur affectueux.

eng: He had strong feelings of family attachment and family honour, without pride or weakness;
fr: Il vivait sans faste, mais avec la liberalite d'un homme riche.

eng: Everything united in him; good understanding, correct opinions, knowledge of the world, and a warm heart.
fr: Il avait des sentiments d'honneur et de famille, ni orgueil, ni faiblesse ;

eng: His manners were an immediate recommendation;
fr: Il se recommandait par ses manieres.

eng: he judged for himself in everything essential, without defying public opinion in any point of worldly decorum.
fr: Il etait ferme, observateur, modere et sincere, ne se laissant emporter ni par son humeur, ni par son egoisme, deguises sous le nom de sentiments eleves, et cependant il etait touche par tout ce qui etait aimable et bon.

eng: and on conversing with him she found the solid so fully supporting the superficial, that she was at first, as she told Anne, almost ready to exclaim, "Can this be Mr Elliot?"
fr: Elle lui trouvait un esprit si serieux et si agreable qu'elle fut prete a s'ecrier : << Est-ce la M. Elliot ? >>

eng: Her satisfaction in Mr Elliot outweighed all the plague of Mrs Clay.
fr: Sa satisfaction a cet egard, et nous verrons pourquoi, l'emportait sur l'ennui que lui donnait Mme Clay.

eng: 'The Bath paper one morning announced the arrival of the Dowager Viscountess Dalrymple, and her daughter, the Honourable Miss Carteret; and all the comfort of No.'
fr: 'Le journal annonca un matin l'arrivee de la douairiere, vicomtesse Dalrymph, et de sa fille, l'honorable miss Carteret.'

eng: 'It was not merely complaisance, it must be a liking to the cause, which made him enter warmly into her father and sister's solicitudes on a subject which she thought unworthy to excite them.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'His value for rank and connexion she perceived was greater than hers.'
fr: 'Elle s'apercut qu'il partageait sur la noblesse les idees de Sir Walter et d'Elisabeth.'

eng: 'They did not always think alike.'
fr: 'Leurs opinions n'etaient pas toujours semblables.'

eng: 'She knew it well; and she remembered another person's look also.'
fr: 'elle avait devine, et se rappelait aussi le regard qu'un autre lui avait jete.'

eng: 'He gave her to understand that he had looked at her with some earnestness.'
fr: 'il lui dit quel plaisir sa vue lui avait fait :'

eng: 'They went through the particulars of their first meeting a great many times.'
fr: 'Ils se rappelerent nombre de fois leur premiere rencontre ;'

eng: '~~~ In fact, Anne could never see the crape round his hat, without fearing that she was the inexcusable one, in attributing to him such imaginations; for though his marriage had not been very happy, still it had existed so many years that she could not comprehend a very rapid recovery from the awful impression of its being dissolved.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'Mr Elliot, too, it must be remembered, had not been a widower seven months. A little delay on his side might be very excusable.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'In that house Elizabeth must be first; and she was in the habit of such general observance as "Miss Elliot," that any particularity of attention seemed almost impossible.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'She could determine nothing at present.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'It was a reference to the future, which Anne, after a little observation, felt she must submit to.'
fr: 'Anna dut s'en contenter.'

eng: 'Lady Russell listened, and looked, and made only this cautious reply:--"Elizabeth! very well; time will explain."'
fr: 'Lady Russel ecouta, regarda et fit cette prudente reponse : << Elisabeth ? tres bien, nous verrons ! >>'

eng: 'Anne presumed, however, still to smile about it, and at last to mention "Elizabeth."'
fr: 'Anna se permit cependant de sourire en nommant Elisabeth.'

eng: 'It was now some years since Anne had begun to learn that she and her excellent friend could sometimes think differently; and it did not surprise her, therefore, that Lady Russell should see nothing suspicious or inconsistent, nothing to require more motives than appeared, in Mr Elliot's great desire of a reconciliation.'
fr: 'Anna savait deja par experience que son excellente amie et elle pouvaient differer d'avis ; elle ne fut donc pas surprise que lady Russel ne vit dans la conduite de M. Elliot qu'un grand desir de reconciliation.'

eng: 'However it might end, he was without any question their pleasantest acquaintance in Bath: she saw nobody equal to him; and it was a great indulgence now and then to talk to him about Lyme, which he seemed to have as lively a wish to see again, and to see more of, as herself.'
fr: 'Quoi qu'il en soit, M. Elliot etait a coup sur leur plus agreable connaissance a Bath ; elle ne trouvait personne aussi bien que lui, et trouvait un grand plaisir a parler de Lyme, qu'il desirait revoir autant qu'elle-meme.'

eng: --, Camden Place, was swept away for many days; for the Dalrymples (in Anne's opinion, most unfortunately) were cousins of the Elliots; and the agony was how to introduce themselves properly.
fr: A partir de ce moment, la tranquillite fut bannie de Camben-Place, car les Dalrymph etaient cousins des Elliot, et la difficulte etait d'etre presentes selon les regles. ~~~ Ce fut un grand sujet de perplexite.

eng: Anne had never seen her father and sister before in contact with nobility, and she must acknowledge herself disappointed.
fr: Anna n'avait pas encore vu son pere ni sa soeur en relation avec la noblesse, et son desappointement fut grand.

eng: Sir Walter had once been in company with the late viscount, but had never seen any of the rest of the family; and the difficulties of the case arose from there having been a suspension of all intercourse by letters of ceremony, ever since the death of that said late viscount, when, in consequence of a dangerous illness of Sir Walter's at the same time, there had been an unlucky omission at Kellynch.
fr: A la mort du dernier vicomte, Sir Walter, etant malade, avait neglige de repondre a la lettre de faire part qui lui fut envoyee.

eng: She had hoped better things from their high ideas of their own situation in life, and was reduced to form a wish which she had never foreseen; a wish that they had more pride;
fr: Elle avait espere qu'ils avaient une plus haute idee d'eux-memes et se trouva reduite a leur souhaiter plus d'orgueil,

eng: How to have this anxious business set to rights, and be admitted as cousins again, was the question: and it was a question which, in a more rational manner, neither Lady Russell nor Mr Elliot thought unimportant.
fr: ce fut une grave question pour lady Russel et pour M. Elliot.

eng: The neglect had been visited on the head of the sinner; for when poor Lady Elliot died herself, no letter of condolence was received at Kellynch, and, consequently, there was but too much reason to apprehend that the Dalrymples considered the relationship as closed.
fr: On lui rendit la pareille a la mort de lady Elliot : il fallait reparer cette malheureuse negligence, et etre recus comme cousins :

eng: No letter of condolence had been sent to Ireland.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: for "our cousins Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret;" "our cousins, the Dalrymples," sounded in her ears all day long.
fr: car nos cousins, les Dalrymph, resonnaient tout le jour a ses oreilles.

eng: "Family connexions were always worth preserving, good company always worth seeking; Lady Dalrymple had taken a house, for three months, in Laura Place, and would be living in style.
fr: Lady Dalrymph avait pris une maison pour trois mois a Laura-Place, et allait vivre grandement.

eng: She had been at Bath the year before, and Lady Russell had heard her spoken of as a charming woman.
fr: Elle avait ete a Bath l'annee precedente, et lady Russel l'avait entendu vanter comme une femme charmante.

eng: It was very desirable that the connexion should be renewed, if it could be done, without any compromise of propriety on the side of the Elliots."
fr: Il fallait renouer, si l'on pouvait le faire sans compromettre la dignite des Elliot.

eng: Sir Walter, however, would choose his own means, and at last wrote a very fine letter of ample explanation, regret, and entreaty, to his right honourable cousin.
fr: Sir Walter se decida a ecrire a sa noble cousine une longue lettre d'explications et de regrets.

eng: Neither Lady Russell nor Mr Elliot could admire the letter; but it did all that was wanted, in bringing three lines of scrawl from the Dowager Viscountess. ~~~ "She was very much honoured, and should be happy in their acquaintance."
fr: Personne ne put admirer cette epitre, mais elle obtint le resultat desire : c'etaient trois lignes de griffonnage de la douairiere vicomtesse : << Elle etait tres honoree, et serait tres heureuse de faire leur connaissance.

eng: The toils of the business were over, the sweets began.
fr: >> Le plus difficile etait fait ; il ne restait plus qu'a en gouter les douceurs.

eng: Had Lady Dalrymple and her daughter even been very agreeable, she would still have been ashamed of the agitation they created, but they were nothing. There was no superiority of manner, accomplishment, or understanding.
fr: d'autant plus qu'elles etaient tres ordinaires.

eng: Lady Dalrymple had acquired the name of "a charming woman," because she had a smile and a civil answer for everybody.
fr: Lady Dalrymph avait acquis le titre de femme << charmante >> parce qu'elle avait un sourire et une reponse pour chacun.

eng: and "Our cousins in Laura Place,"--"Our cousin, Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret," were talked of to everybody.
fr: et l'on allait partout repetant << nos cousines de Laura-Place >>.

eng: They visited in Laura Place, they had the cards of Dowager Viscountess Dalrymple, and the Honourable Miss Carteret, to be arranged wherever they might be most visible:
fr: On fit visite a Laura-Place ; on recut les cartes de la douairiere, vicomtesse de Dalrymph, et de l'honorable miss Carteret. Ces cartes furent mises en evidence,

eng: Anne was ashamed.
fr: Anna etait confuse de l'agitation causee par ces dames,

eng: Miss Carteret, with still less to say, was so plain and so awkward, that she would never have been tolerated in Camden Place but for her birth.
fr: Quant a miss Carteret, elle etait si vulgaire et si gauche, que sans sa noblesse on ne l'aurait pas supportee a Camben-Place.

eng: Lady Russell confessed she had expected something better; but yet "it was an acquaintance worth having;" and when Anne ventured to speak her opinion of them to Mr Elliot, he agreed to their being nothing in themselves, but still maintained that, as a family connexion, as good company, as those who would collect good company around them, they had their value.
fr: Lady Russel confessa qu'elle s'attendait a mieux, mais que c'etait une belle relation ; et quand Anna s'aventura a donner son opinion, M. Elliot convint que ces dames n'etaient rien par elles-memes, mais qu'elles avaient une valeur comme relations de famille et de bonne compagnie.

eng: "You are mistaken," said he gently, "that is not good company; that is the best.
fr: Vous vous trompez, repondit-il doucement.

eng: Anna smiled.
fr: Anna sourit.

eng: Anne smiled and said, "My idea of good company, Mr Elliot, is the company of clever, well-informed people, who have a great deal of conversation; that is what I call good company."
fr: J'appelle bonne compagnie, dit-elle a M. Elliot, les personnes instruites, intelligentes et qui savent causer.

eng: Good company requires only birth, education, and manners, and with regard to education is not very nice.
fr: Ce n'est pas la la bonne compagnie : c'est la meilleure. La bonne compagnie demande seulement de la naissance, de bonnes manieres et de l'education, et meme, elle n'est pas exigeante sur ce dernier point

eng: Birth and good manners are essential; but a little learning is by no means a dangerous thing in good company; on the contrary, it will do very well.
fr: tres peu d'instruction ne fait pas mal du tout.

eng: My cousin Anne shakes her head. ~~~ She is not satisfied. ~~~ She is fastidious.
fr: Ma cousine Anna secoue la tete : elle n'est pas satisfaite : elle est difficile.

eng: My dear cousin" (sitting down by her), "you have a better right to be fastidious than almost any other woman I know; but will it answer?
fr: << Ma chere cousine, dit-il en s'asseyant pres d'elle, vous avez plus de droits qu'une autre d'etre difficile. ~~~ Mais cela vous servira-t-il a quelque chose ?

eng: Will it make you happy?
fr: En serez-vous plus heureuse ?

eng: Will it not be wiser to accept the society of those good ladies in Laura Place, and enjoy all the advantages of the connexion as far as possible?
fr: N'est-il pas plus sage d'accepter la societe de ces bonnes dames, et d'en avoir les avantages ?

eng: "You may depend upon it, that they will move in the first set in Bath this winter, and as rank is rank, your being known to be related to them will have its use in fixing your family (our family let me say) in that degree of consideration which we must all wish for."
fr: 'Soyez sure qu'elles brilleront aux premieres places cet hiver, et cette parente donnera a votre famille (permettez-moi de dire a notre famille) le degre de consideration que nous pouvons desirer.'

eng: then recollecting herself, and not wishing to be answered, she added, "I certainly do think there has been by far too much trouble taken to procure the acquaintance."
fr: 'Je crois qu'on a pris trop de peine pour cela.'

eng: "I suppose" (smiling) "I have more pride than any of you; but I confess it does vex me, that we should be so solicitous to have the relationship acknowledged, which we may be very sure is a matter of perfect indifference to them."'
fr: 'Il faut croire, dit-elle en souriant, que j'ai plus d'orgueil que vous tous, mais j'avoue que je suis vexee de cet empressement a faire connaitre notre parente, qui doit leur etre parfaitement indifferente.'

eng: "Yes," sighed Anne, "we shall, indeed, be known to be related to them!"
fr: '-- Oui, soupira Anna, notre parente sera suffisamment connue.'

eng: "Pardon me, dear cousin, you are unjust in your own claims.
fr: -- Pardonnez-moi, ma chere cousine ; vous etes injuste dans votre propre cause.

eng: In London, perhaps, in your present quiet style of living, it might be as you say: but in Bath; Sir Walter Elliot and his family will always be worth knowing: always acceptable as acquaintance."
fr: Peut-etre qu'a Londres, avec notre simple train de vie, il en serait ainsi ; mais a Bath, Sir Walter Elliot et sa famille seront toujours apprecies a leur valeur.

eng: "Well," said Anne, "I certainly am proud, too proud to enjoy a welcome which depends so entirely upon place."
fr: -- Eh bien ! ~~~ dit Anna, je suis trop orgueilleuse pour me rejouir d'un accueil du a l'endroit ou je suis.

eng: "I love your indignation," said he; "it is very natural. ~~~ But here you are in Bath, and the object is to be established here with all the credit and dignity which ought to belong to Sir Walter Elliot.
fr: -- J'aime votre indignation, dit-il ; elle est tres naturelle ; mais vous etes a Bath, et il s'agit d'y paraitre avec la dignite et la consideration qui appartiennent de droit a Sir Walter Elliot.

eng: You talk of being proud; I am called proud, I know, and I shall not wish to believe myself otherwise; for our pride, if investigated, would have the same object, I have no doubt, though the kind may seem a little different.
fr: Vous parlez d'orgueil : on me dit orgueilleux, je le suis, et ne desire pas paraitre autre ; car notre orgueil a tous deux, si l'on cherchait bien, est de meme nature, quoiqu'il semble different.

eng: In one point, I am sure, my dear cousin," (he continued, speaking lower, though there was no one else in the room) "in one point, I am sure, we must feel alike.
fr: Sur un point, ma chere cousine (continua-t-il en parlant plus bas, quoiqu'il n'y eut personne dans la chambre), je suis sur que nous sommes du meme avis.

eng: "Miss Hamilton had left school, had married not long afterwards, was said to have married a man of fortune, and this was all that Anne had known of her, till now that their governess's account brought her situation forward in a more decided but very different form."
fr: "Miss Hamilton quitta la pension un an apres et epousa bientot un homme riche. "

eng: "We must feel that every addition to your father's society, among his equals or superiors, may be of use in diverting his thoughts from those who are beneath him."
fr: "Vous devez sentir que toute nouvelle connaissance que fera votre pere parmi ses egaux ou ses superieurs peut servir a le detacher de ceux qui sont au-dessous de lui."

eng: "While Sir Walter and Elizabeth were assiduously pushing their good fortune in Laura Place, Anne was renewing an acquaintance of a very different description."
fr: "Tandis que Sir Walter et Elisabeth se lancaient dans le grand monde, Anna renouait une connaissance d'un genre tres different."

eng: "She had called on her former governess, and had heard from her of there being an old school-fellow in Bath, who had the two strong claims on her attention of past kindness and present suffering."
fr: "Elle avait appris qu'une de ses anciennes compagnes demeurait a Bath."

eng: "Chapter 17"
fr: "CHAPITRE XVII"

eng: "Anne had gone unhappy to school, grieving for the loss of a mother whom she had dearly loved, feeling her separation from home, and suffering as a girl of fourteen, of strong sensibility and not high spirits, must suffer at such a time; and Miss Hamilton, three years older than herself, but still from the want of near relations and a settled home, remaining another year at school, had been useful and good to her in a way which had considerably lessened her misery, and could never be remembered with indifference."
fr: "Elle fit ce qu'elle put pour adoucir le chagrin d'Anna, qui en garda un souvenir reconnaissant."

eng: "He looked, as he spoke, to the seat which Mrs Clay had been lately occupying: a sufficient explanation of what he particularly meant; and though Anne could not believe in their having the same sort of pride, she was pleased with him for not liking Mrs Clay; and her conscience admitted that his wishing to promote her father's getting great acquaintance was more than excusable in the view of defeating her."
fr: "Il regardait en parlant ainsi le siege que Mme Clay avait occupe. ~~~ C'etait un commentaire suffisant ; Anna fut contente de voir qu'il n'aimait pas Mme Clay, et elle le trouva plus qu'excusable, en faveur du but qu'il poursuivait, de chercher de hautes relations a son pere."

eng: "She was a widow and poor."
fr: "Depuis deux ans, elle etait veuve et pauvre."

eng: "Her husband had been extravagant; and at his death, about two years before, had left his affairs dreadfully involved."
fr: "Son mari etait un extravagant qui dissipa sa fortune, et laissa des affaires embrouillees."

eng: "Miss Hamilton, now Mrs Smith, had shewn her kindness in one of those periods of her life when it had been most valuable."
fr: "Mme Shmith (autrefois miss Hamilton), agee de trois ans de plus qu'Anna, avait ete tres bonne pour elle, quand elle entra a quatorze ans dans une pension, apres la mort de sa mere."

eng: She had had difficulties of every sort to contend with, and in addition to these distresses had been afflicted with a severe rheumatic fever, which, finally settling in her legs, had made her for the present a cripple.
fr: Elle eut des ennuis de toute espece. ~~~ Une fievre rhumatismale qui attaqua enfin les jambes la rendit infirme.

eng: She had come to Bath on that account, and was now in lodgings near the hot baths, living in a very humble way, unable even to afford herself the comfort of a servant, and of course almost excluded from society.
fr: Elle etait venue a Bath pour se guerir et demeurait pres des bains chauds, vivant tres modestement, sans domestique, et par consequent exclue de la societe.

eng: Anne found in Mrs Smith the good sense and agreeable manners which she had almost ventured to depend on, and a disposition to converse and be cheerful beyond her expectation.
fr: Anna trouva dans Mme Shmith le bon sens et les manieres agreables auxquels elle s'attendait, et une disposition a la causerie et a la gaite au dela de son attente.

eng: but all that was uncomfortable in the meeting had soon passed away, and left only the interesting charm of remembering former partialities and talking over old times.
fr: Mais le premier malaise de leur rencontre fit bientot place au charme des vieux souvenirs.

eng: and twelve years had transformed the fine-looking, well-grown Miss Hamilton, in all the glow of health and confidence of superiority, into a poor, infirm, helpless widow, receiving the visit of her former protegee as a favour;
fr: et douze ans avaient transforme la belle et fiere miss Hamilton en une pauvre veuve infirme, recevant comme une faveur la visite de son ancienne protegee.

eng: Twelve years had changed Anne from the blooming, silent, unformed girl of fifteen, to the elegant little woman of seven-and-twenty, with every beauty except bloom, and with manners as consciously right as they were invariably gentle;
fr: Anna n'etait plus la silencieuse, timide et rougissante jeune fille de quinze ans, mais une elegante jeune femme, ayant toutes les beautes, excepte la fraicheur, aux manieres aussi agreables que parfaites ;

eng: The first ten minutes had its awkwardness and its emotion.
fr: Au premier moment, il y eut un peu de gene et d'emotion :

eng: She only consulted Lady Russell, who entered thoroughly into her sentiments, and was most happy to convey her as near to Mrs Smith's lodgings in Westgate Buildings, as Anne chose to be taken.
fr: et consulta seulement lady Russel, qui l'approuva et la conduisit dans sa voiture pres du logement de Mme Shmith.

eng: She mentioned nothing of what she had heard, or what she intended, at home. It would excite no proper interest there.
fr: elle ne dit rien chez elle,

eng: Their mutual friend answered for the satisfaction which a visit from Miss Elliot would give Mrs Smith, and Anne therefore lost no time in going.
fr: Anna, sachant par une amie commune que sa visite serait agreable, ne perdit pas de temps : elle ne dit rien chez elle, et consulta seulement lady Russel, qui l'approuva et la conduisit dans sa voiture pres du logement de Mme Shmith.

eng: Twelve years were gone since they had parted, and each presented a somewhat different person from what the other had imagined.
fr: douze ans s'etaient ecoules, et elles se trouvaient mutuellement changees.

eng: The visit was paid, their acquaintance re-established, their interest in each other more than re-kindled.
fr: Les deux anciennes amies renouvelerent connaissance.

eng: Neither the dissipations of the past--and she had lived very much in the world--nor the restrictions of the present, neither sickness nor sorrow seemed to have closed her heart or ruined her spirits.
fr: Ni les plaisirs du monde ou elle avait beaucoup vecu, ni la condition presente, pas plus que la maladie ou le chagrin, n'avaient ferme son coeur, ni eteint sa gaite.

eng: In the course of a second visit she talked with great openness, and Anne's astonishment increased.
fr: A la seconde visite, elle causa tres librement, et l'etonnement d'Anna redoubla.

eng: She could scarcely imagine a more cheerless situation in itself than Mrs Smith's.
fr: Elle ne pouvait guere imaginer une situation plus triste que celle de son amie.

eng: She had been very fond of her husband: she had buried him. ~~~ She had been used to affluence: it was gone. ~~~ She had no child to connect her with life and happiness again, no relations to assist in the arrangement of perplexed affairs, no health to make all the rest supportable.
fr: Elle avait perdu un mari qu'elle adorait, une fortune a laquelle elle etait accoutumee ; elle n'avait pas d'enfants pour la rattacher a la vie et au bonheur ; aucun parent pour l'aider dans des affaires embarrassees ; pas meme de sante pour supporter tout le reste.
