eng: Her accommodations were limited to a noisy parlour, and a dark bedroom behind, with no possibility of moving from one to the other without assistance, which there was only one servant in the house to afford, and she never quitted the house but to be conveyed into the warm bath.
fr: Elle s'accommodait d'un parloir bruyant, et d'une chambre obscure par derriere ; elle ne pouvait bouger sans l'aide de l'unique servante de l'hotel, et elle ne sortait que pour etre portee aux bains chauds.

eng: Yet, in spite of all this, Anne had reason to believe that she had moments only of languor and depression, to hours of occupation and enjoyment.
fr: En depit de tout cela, Anna avait lieu de croire que son amie n'avait que des minutes de langueur et d'accablement, contre des heures d'activite et de distraction.

eng: There had been a time, Mrs Smith told her, when her spirits had nearly failed.
fr: Mme Shmith avait eu une epoque de profond decouragement.

eng: She could not call herself an invalid now, compared with her state on first reaching Bath.
fr: En arrivant a Bath, elle etait bien plus invalide qu'alors, car elle avait eu un refroidissement en voyage, et s'etait mise au lit, avec de vives et continuelles souffrances.

eng: Then she had, indeed, been a pitiable object; for she had caught cold on the journey, and had hardly taken possession of her lodgings before she was again confined to her bed and suffering under severe and constant pain; and all this among strangers, with the absolute necessity of having a regular nurse, and finances at that moment particularly unfit to meet any extraordinary expense.
fr: Et cela parmi des etrangers, sans pouvoir se passer d'une garde, et dans une situation pecuniaire tres genee.

eng: She had weathered it, however, and could truly say that it had done her good.
fr: Elle avait subi toutes ces choses et disait qu'il en etait resulte un bien.

eng: It had increased her comforts by making her feel herself to be in good hands.
fr: Elle s'etait sentie en bonnes mains.

eng: She had seen too much of the world, to expect sudden or disinterested attachment anywhere, but her illness had proved to her that her landlady had a character to preserve, and would not use her ill;
fr: Elle connaissait trop le monde pour attendre un attachement soudain et desinteresse ; mais sa proprietaire s'etait montree tres bonne,

eng: and she had been particularly fortunate in her nurse, as a sister of her landlady, a nurse by profession, and who had always a home in that house when unemployed, chanced to be at liberty just in time to attend her.
fr: et la soeur de cette dame, garde-malade et alors sans emploi, l'avait admirablement soignee, et avait ete pour elle une amie precieuse.

eng: "And she," said Mrs Smith, "besides nursing me most admirably, has really proved an invaluable acquaintance.
fr: << Aussitot que je pus faire usage de mes mains, elle me montra a tricoter, ce qui me fut une grande distraction, et a faire ces paniers, ces pelotes et ces porte-cartes avec lesquels vous me trouvez si occupee.

eng: As soon as I could use my hands she taught me to knit, which has been a great amusement; and she put me in the way of making these little thread-cases, pin-cushions and card-racks, which you always find me so busy about, and which supply me with the means of doing a little good to one or two very poor families in this neighbourhood.
fr: Ils me fournissent les moyens de faire un peu de bien a quelques pauvres familles du voisinage. >>

eng: She had a large acquaintance, of course professionally, among those who can afford to buy, and she disposes of my merchandise.
fr: Ma garde dispose de mes marchandises, et les fait acheter a ses clients.

eng: Everybody's heart is open, you know, when they have recently escaped from severe pain, or are recovering the blessing of health, and Nurse Rooke thoroughly understands when to speak.
fr: Vous savez que quand on a echappe a un grand danger, on a le coeur plus ouvert, et Mme Rock sait quand il faut parler.

eng: She is a shrewd, intelligent, sensible woman.
fr: C'est une femme habile, sensee et intelligente, qui comprend la nature humaine.

eng: It was the choicest gift of Heaven; and Anne viewed her friend as one of those instances in which, by a merciful appointment, it seems designed to counterbalance almost every other want.
fr: C'est le plus beau don du ciel, et Anna voyait la une grace speciale, destinee a remplacer tout le reste.

eng: A submissive spirit might be patient, a strong understanding would supply resolution, but here was something more; here was that elasticity of mind, that disposition to be comforted, that power of turning readily from evil to good, and of finding employment which carried her out of herself, which was from nature alone.
fr: Une ame soumise peut etre patiente ; une forte intelligence peut etre courageuse ; mais il y avait la quelque chose de plus : cette elasticite d'esprit. Cette disposition a etre consolee, cette faculte de trouver des occupations qui la detachaient d'elle-meme : tout cela venait de sa seule nature.

eng: She always takes the right time for applying.
fr: Elle saisit toujours le bon moment.

eng: How could it be?
fr: Comment cela se pouvait-il !

eng: She watched, observed, reflected, and finally determined that this was not a case of fortitude or of resignation only.
fr: Elle conclut que ce n'etait pas seulement de la force et de la resignation.

eng: Hers is a line for seeing human nature; and she has a fund of good sense and observation, which, as a companion, make her infinitely superior to thousands of those who having only received 'the best education in the world,' know nothing worth attending to.
fr: Elle a un fond de bon sens et d'observation qui la rend infiniment superieure, comme compagne, a un millier de celles qui, ayant recu la meilleure education, ne trouvent rien digne d'elles.

eng: Call it gossip, if you will, but when Nurse Rooke has half an hour's leisure to bestow on me, she is sure to have something to relate that is entertaining and profitable: something that makes one know one's species better.
fr: Appelez cela commerage, si vous voulez ; mais quand la garde Rock a une demi-heure de loisir a me donner, je suis sure qu'elle me dira quelque chose d'amusant et d'utile, quelque chose qui nous fait mieux connaitre nos semblables.

eng: One likes to hear what is going on, to be au fait as to the newest modes of being trifling and silly.
fr: On aime a savoir ce qui se passe et quelle est la plus nouvelle maniere d'etre frivole et vain.

eng: To me, who live so much alone, her conversation, I assure you, is a treat."
fr: Pour moi, qui vis seule, sa conversation est une fete.

eng: "A sick chamber may often furnish the worth of volumes."
fr: "Une chambre de malade peut fournir matiere a des volumes."

eng: "What instances must pass before them of ardent, disinterested, self-denying attachment, of heroism, fortitude, patience, resignation: of all the conflicts and all the sacrifices that ennoble us most."
fr: "Combien d'exemples des plus nobles sacrifices !"

eng: "And it is not merely in its follies, that they are well read; for they see it occasionally under every circumstance that can be most interesting or affecting."
fr: "Combien d'exemples passent sous leurs yeux, d'attachements ardents, desinteresses et devoues ; d'heroisme, de courage, de patience et de resignation !"

eng: "Such varieties of human nature as they are in the habit of witnessing!"
fr: "Elles voient la nature humaine non pas seulement dans ses folies, mais dans les circonstances les plus interessantes et les plus touchantes."

eng: "Women of that class have great opportunities, and if they are intelligent may be well worth listening to."
fr: "les femmes de cette classe voient et entendent bien des choses, et si elles sont intelligentes, elles valent la peine d'etre ecoutees."

eng: "I can easily believe it."
fr: "-- Je vous crois aisement ;

eng: "Anne, far from wishing to cavil at the pleasure, replied," (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: "Une chambre de malade peut fournir matiere a des volumes."

eng: "Yes," said Mrs Smith more doubtingly, "sometimes it may, though I fear its lessons are not often in the elevated style you describe.
fr: -- Oui, dit Mme Shmith d'un air de doute ; cela peut arriver, mais pas dans le sens eleve que vous dites.

eng: Here and there, human nature may be great in times of trial; but generally speaking, it is its weakness and not its strength that appears in a sick chamber: it is selfishness and impatience rather than generosity and fortitude, that one hears of.
fr: Par-ci par-la la nature humaine peut etre grande en temps d'epreuves, mais en general c'est sa faiblesse et non sa force qui se montre dans une chambre de malade. ~~~ On y entend parler d'egoisme et d'impatience plus que de generosite et de courage.

eng: There is so little real friendship in the world!
fr: Il y a si peu de reelle amitie dans le monde !

eng: "and unfortunately" (speaking low and tremulously) "there are so many who forget to think seriously till it is almost too late."
fr: 'et malheureusement, dit-elle d'une voix basse et tremblante, il y en a tant qui oublient de penser serieusement jusqu'a ce qu'il soit trop tard.

eng: Anne saw the misery of such feelings.
fr: Anna vit la souffrance cachee sous ces paroles.

eng: The husband had not been what he ought, and the wife had been led among that part of mankind which made her think worse of the world than she hoped it deserved.
fr: Le mari n'avait pas fait son devoir, et la femme avait ete conduite dans une societe qui lui avait donne sur les hommes une plus mauvaise opinion qu'ils ne le meritaient.

eng: It was but a passing emotion however with Mrs Smith; she shook it off, and soon added in a different tone-- "I do not suppose the situation my friend Mrs Rooke is in at present, will furnish much either to interest or edify me.
fr: Mme Shmith secoua cette emotion momentanee et ajouta bientot d'un ton different : << La situation actuelle de mon amie Mme Rock n'a rien en ce moment qui puisse m'interesser beaucoup.

eng: She is only nursing Mrs Wallis of Marlborough Buildings; a mere pretty, silly, expensive, fashionable woman, I believe; and of course will have nothing to report but of lace and finery.
fr: Elle garde Mme Wallis, de Marlboroug-Buildings, femme tres jolie, tres mondaine, sotte et depensiere, et naturellement elle ne pourra parler que de dentelles et de chiffons.

eng: I mean to make my profit of Mrs Wallis, however.
fr: Je veux cependant tirer parti de Mme Wallis.

eng: And what is her attraction? That she is old and sickly. Upon my word, Miss Anne Elliot, you have the most extraordinary taste!'
fr: Et qu'a-t-elle pour attirer ? Elle est vieille et malade. Sur ma parole, miss Anna Elliot, vous avez un gout extraordinaire !'

eng: "Westgate Buildings!" said he, "and who is Miss Anne Elliot to be visiting in Westgate Buildings? A Mrs Smith. A widow Mrs Smith; and who was her husband? One of five thousand Mr Smiths whose names are to be met with everywhere.
fr: << Westgate-Buildings, dit Sir Walter, et c'est miss Elliot qui va la ! Une Mme Shmith ! une veuve ! ~~~ Et qui etait son mari ? un des cinq mille Shmith qu'on rencontre partout !

eng: They were not much interested in anything relative to Anne; but still there were questions enough asked, to make it understood what this old schoolfellow was; and Elizabeth was disdainful, and Sir Walter severe.
fr: Elisabeth et Sir Walter, qui ne s'interessaient guere a cela, la questionnerent cependant, et quand ils surent de quoi il s'agissait, se montrerent l'une dedaigneuse, l'autre severe.

eng: They were only asked, she was sure, because Lady Dalrymple being kept at home by a bad cold, was glad to make use of the relationship which had been so pressed on her; and she declined on her own account with great alacrity--"She was engaged to spend the evening with an old schoolfellow."
fr: ~~~ Anna s'excusa en disant qu'elle etait invitee chez une amie de pension.

eng: She was not sorry for the excuse.
fr: Elle etait certaine que lady Dalrymph les invitait parce qu'etant retenue chez elle par un refroidissement, elle etait bien aise d'user de la parente qui s'etait imposee a elle.

eng: Sir Walter, Elizabeth and Mrs Clay, returned one morning from Laura Place, with a sudden invitation from Lady Dalrymple for the same evening, and Anne was already engaged, to spend that evening in Westgate Buildings.
fr: Sir Walter, Elisabeth et Mme Clay revinrent un matin de Laura-Place avec une invitation imprevue de lady Dalrymph pour cette meme soiree qu'Anna devait passer chez son amie.

eng: Anne had called several times on her friend, before the existence of such a person was known in Camden Place.
fr: >> Anna etait allee plusieurs fois chez son amie avant que l'existence de celle-ci fut connue a Camben-Place.

eng: 'She has plenty of money, and I intend she shall buy all the high-priced things I have in hand now."
fr: 'Elle est tres riche, et il faut qu'elle achete toutes les choses cheres que j'ai en ce moment.

eng: At last, it became necessary to speak of her.
fr: A la fin, il fallut en parler.

eng: Everything that revolts other people, low company, paltry rooms, foul air, disgusting associations are inviting to you.
fr: Tout ce qui revolte les autres : basse compagnie, logement miserable, air vicie ; tout ce qui est repoussant vous attire.

eng: But surely you may put off this old lady till to-morrow: she is not so near her end, I presume, but that she may hope to see another day.
fr: Mais vous pouvez surement remettre a demain cette vieille dame ? ~~~ Elle n'est pas si pres de sa fin qu'elle ne puisse vivre un jour de plus ?

eng: What is her age?
fr: Quel age a-t-elle ?

eng: Forty?"
fr: Quarante ans !

eng: "No, sir, she is not one-and-thirty; but I do not think I can put off my engagement, because it is the only evening for some time which will at once suit her and myself."
fr: '-- Seulement trente et un. ~~~ Mais je ne crois pas pouvoir remettre ma visite, parce que c'est la seule soiree qui nous convienne a toutes deux.'

eng: "She goes into the warm bath to-morrow, and for the rest of the week, you know, we are engaged."
fr: 'Elle va aux bains chauds demain ; et vous savez que nous sommes invites pour le reste de la semaine.'

eng: "But what does Lady Russell think of this acquaintance?" asked Elizabeth.
fr: '-- Qu'est-ce que lady Russel pense de cette connaissance ? dit Elisabeth.'

eng: "She sees nothing to blame in it," replied Anne; "on the contrary, she approves it, and has generally taken me when I have called on Mrs Smith."'
fr: '-- Elle n'y voit rien a blamer ; au contraire, elle l'approuve, et m'y a souvent conduite dans sa voiture.'

eng: "Westgate Buildings must have been rather surprised by the appearance of a carriage drawn up near its pavement," observed Sir Walter.
fr: -- Westgate-Buildings a du etre surpris de voir un equipage sur ses paves, fit observer Sir Walter.

eng: Mrs Smith! Such a name!"
A widow Mrs Smith lodging in Westgate Buildings!
fr: Mme veuve Shmith ! demeurant a Westgate-Buildings !

eng: A poor widow barely able to live, between thirty and forty; a mere Mrs Smith, an every-day Mrs Smith, of all people and all names in the world, to be the chosen friend of Miss Anne Elliot, and to be preferred by her to her own family connections among the nobility of England and Ireland!
fr: Une pauvre veuve, ayant a peine de quoi vivre ! entre trente et quarante ans ! une simple Mme Shmith est l'amie intime de miss Elliot, qui la prefere a sa noble parente d'Ecosse et d'Irlande ; Mme Shmith ! quel nom !

eng: Mrs Clay, who had been present while all this passed, now thought it advisable to leave the room, and Anne could have said much, and did long to say a little in defence of her friend's not very dissimilar claims to theirs, but her sense of personal respect to her father prevented her.
fr: >> A ce moment, Mme Clay jugea convenable de quitter la chambre. Anna aurait bien voulu prendre la defense de son amie, mais elle se tut, par respect pour son pere.

eng: "Sir Henry Russell's widow, indeed, has no honours to distinguish her arms, but still it is a handsome equipage, and no doubt is well known to convey a Miss Elliot.
fr: 'La veuve de Sir Henri Russel n'a pas de couronne, il est vrai, sur ses armoiries ; neanmoins, c'est un bel equipage, et l'on sait sans doute qu'il contient une miss Elliot.

eng: She left it to himself to recollect, that Mrs Smith was not the only widow in Bath between thirty and forty, with little to live on, and no surname of dignity.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She saw that there had been bad habits; that Sunday travelling had been a common thing; that there had been a period of his life (and probably not a short one) when he had been, at least, careless in all serious matters; and, though he might now think very differently, who could answer for the true sentiments of a clever, cautious man, grown old enough to appreciate a fair character?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: How could it ever be ascertained that his mind was truly cleansed?
fr: Pour Anna, c'etait un grand defaut : elle adorait la franchise et l'enthousiasme.

eng: Mr Elliot was rational, discreet, polished, but he was not open.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was never any burst of feeling, any warmth of indignation or delight, at the evil or good of others.
fr: Elle se fiait plus a la sincerite de ceux qui disent parfois une parole irreflechie qu'a ceux dont la presence d'esprit ne fait jamais defaut, et dont la langue ne se trompe jamais.

eng: This, to Anne, was a decided imperfection.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Her early impressions were incurable.
fr: M. Elliot savait plaire a tous ; il lui avait parle ouvertement de Mme Clay, et cependant il etait aussi aimable avec elle qu'avec toute autre.

eng: She prized the frank, the open-hearted, the eager character beyond all others.
fr: Lady Russel en voyait plus ou moins que sa jeune amie, car elle n'avait aucune defiance.

eng: Warmth and enthusiasm did captivate her still.
fr: Elle ne pouvait imaginer un homme plus parfait, et rien ne lui eut ete plus doux que de voir sa bien-aimee Anna lui donner la main dans l'eglise de Kellynch, au prochain automne.

eng: She felt that she could so much more depend upon the sincerity of those who sometimes looked or said a careless or a hasty thing, than of those whose presence of mind never varied, whose tongue never slipped.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mr Elliot was too generally agreeable.
fr: CHAPITRE XVIII On etait au commencement de fevrier.

eng: Various as were the tempers in her father's house, he pleased them all.
fr: Anna etait depuis un mois a Bath, et attendait impatiemment des nouvelles d'Uppercross et de Lyme.

eng: He endured too well, stood too well with every body.
fr: Depuis trois semaines elle n'en avait pas recu : elle savait seulement qu'Henriette etait de retour a la maison et que Louisa etait encore a Lyme.

eng: She made no reply.
fr: Elle le laissa se souvenir que Mme Shmith n'etait pas la seule veuve a Bath, entre trente et quarante ans, ayant peu de fortune et ne possedant aucun titre de noblesse.

eng: Lady Russell saw either less or more than her young friend, for she saw nothing to excite distrust.
fr: << Comment ! les Croft sont a Bath ? dit Sir Walter ; que vous envoient-ils ? -- Une lettre d'Uppercross-Cottage, mon pere.'

eng: She could not imagine a man more exactly what he ought to be than Mr Elliot; nor did she ever enjoy a sweeter feeling than the hope of seeing him receive the hand of her beloved Anne in Kellynch church, in the course of the following autumn.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Chapter 18
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was the beginning of February; and Anne, having been a month in Bath, was growing very eager for news from Uppercross and Lyme.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She wanted to hear much more than Mary had communicated.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was three weeks since she had heard at all.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She only knew that Henrietta was at home again; and that Louisa, though considered to be recovering fast, was still in Lyme; and she was thinking of them all very intently one evening, when a thicker letter than usual from Mary was delivered to her; and, to quicken the pleasure and surprise, with Admiral and Mrs Croft's compliments.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The Crofts must be in Bath!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A circumstance to interest her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They were people whom her heart turned to very naturally.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "What is this?" cried Sir Walter. "The Crofts have arrived in Bath? The Crofts who rent Kellynch? What have they brought you?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "A letter from Uppercross Cottage, Sir."'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The names which occasionally dropt of former associates, the allusions to former practices and pursuits, suggested suspicions not favourable of what he had been.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She distrusted the past, if not the present.
fr: M. Elliot n'etait pas ouvert : le bien ou le mal n'excitait en lui aucun elan de plaisir ou d'indignation.

eng: He had spoken to her with some degree of openness of Mrs Clay; had appeared completely to see what Mrs Clay was about, and to hold her in contempt; and yet Mrs Clay found him as agreeable as any body.
fr: Elle y pensait un soir plus que de coutume, quand une lettre de Marie lui fut remise avec les compliments de M. et Mme Croft.

eng: That he was a sensible man, an agreeable man, that he talked well, professed good opinions, seemed to judge properly and as a man of principle, this was all clear enough.
fr: Il avait le sentiment du devoir, et elle ne pouvait le trouver en defaut sur aucun point, mais cependant elle n'aurait pas voulu repondre de lui.

eng: He certainly knew what was right, nor could she fix on any one article of moral duty evidently transgressed; but yet she would have been afraid to answer for his conduct.
fr: Elle se mefiait du passe, sinon du present. Quelques mots prononces parfois lui donnaient des soupcons ; et qui pouvait repondre des sentiments d'un homme habile et prudent, qui feignait peut-etre d'etre ce qu'il n'etait pas ?

eng: Anne kept her appointment; the others kept theirs, and of course she heard the next morning that they had had a delightful evening.
fr: Elle tint son engagement, et les autres tinrent le leur. ~~~ Il va sans dire que, le lendemain, elle entendit raconter la delicieuse soiree.

eng: She had been the only one of the set absent, for Sir Walter and Elizabeth had not only been quite at her ladyship's service themselves, but had actually been happy to be employed by her in collecting others, and had been at the trouble of inviting both Lady Russell and Mr Elliot; and Mr Elliot had made a point of leaving Colonel Wallis early, and Lady Russell had fresh arranged all her evening engagements in order to wait on her.
fr: Sir Walter et Elisabeth s'etaient empresses d'inviter, de la part de sa seigneurie, lady Russel et M. Elliot. Celui-ci avait laisse la le colonel Wallis pour venir, et lady Russel etait venue, quoiqu'elle eut deja dispose autrement de sa soiree. ~~~

eng: Anne had the whole history of all that such an evening could supply from Lady Russell.
fr: Par elle, Anna sut tout ce qui s'etait dit.

eng: To her, its greatest interest must be, in having been very much talked of between her friend and Mr Elliot; in having been wished for, regretted, and at the same time honoured for staying away in such a cause.
fr: Son amie et M. Elliot avaient cause d'elle. On l'avait desiree, regrettee ; on avait approuve le motif de son absence ; sa bonne et affectueuse visite a une ancienne compagne malade et pauvre avait ravi M. Elliot.

eng: Her kind, compassionate visits to this old schoolfellow, sick and reduced, seemed to have quite delighted Mr Elliot.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He thought her a most extraordinary young woman; in her temper, manners, mind, a model of female excellence.
fr: Il trouvait, comme lady Russel, qu'Anna etait une jeune fille extraordinaire, un modele de perfection en tous genres.

eng: He could meet even Lady Russell in a discussion of her merits; and Anne could not be given to understand so much by her friend, could not know herself to be so highly rated by a sensible man, without many of those agreeable sensations which her friend meant to create.
fr: Anna ne pouvait se savoir si hautement appreciee par un galant homme sans eprouver les emotions que lady Russel cherchait a faire naitre.

eng: She was as much convinced of his meaning to gain Anne in time as of his deserving her, and was beginning to calculate the number of weeks which would free him from all the remaining restraints of widowhood, and leave him at liberty to exert his most open powers of pleasing.
fr: Elle etait convaincue qu'il recherchait Anna, et le trouvait digne d'elle. Elle calculait combien de semaines lui restaient jusqu'a la fin de son deuil, pour qu'il put deployer toutes ses seductions.

eng: She would not speak to Anne with half the certainty she felt on the subject, she would venture on little more than hints of what might be hereafter, of a possible attachment on his side, of the desirableness of the alliance, supposing such attachment to be real and returned.
fr: Elle ne dit qu'a demi ce qu'elle pensait, hasardant seulement quelques mots sur la possibilite d'une telle alliance.

eng: Anne heard her, and made no violent exclamations; she only smiled, blushed, and gently shook her head.
fr: Anna l'ecoutait en rougissant, et secouait doucement la tete. ~~~

eng: "I am no match-maker, as you well know," said Lady Russell, "being much too well aware of the uncertainty of all human events and calculations.
fr: << Je ne suis pas une faiseuse de mariages, vous le savez, dit lady Russel. Je connais trop bien l'incertitude des previsions humaines.

eng: I only mean that if Mr Elliot should some time hence pay his addresses to you, and if you should be disposed to accept him, I think there would be every possibility of your being happy together.
fr: Je dis seulement que si M. Elliot vous recherchait et que vous fussiez disposee a l'accepter, il y aurait la des elements de bonheur.

eng: Lady Russell was now perfectly decided in her opinion of Mr Elliot.
fr: Celle-ci avait son opinion faite sur M. Elliot. ~~~

eng: "Mr Elliot is an exceedingly agreeable man, and in many respects I think highly of him," said Anne; "but we should not suit."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A most suitable connection everybody must consider it, but I think it might be a very happy one."
fr: -- M. Elliot est un homme tres aimable, et que j'estime beaucoup, mais nous ne nous convenons pas. >>

eng: Though they had now been acquainted a month, she could not be satisfied that she really knew his character.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And it was not only that her feelings were still adverse to any man save one; her judgement, on a serious consideration of the possibilities of such a case was against Mr Elliot.
fr: Quoiqu'elle le frequentat depuis un mois, elle ne pouvait dire qu'elle le connaissait ; elle voyait bien que c'etait un homme sense, aimable, qu'il causait bien, et professait de bonnes opinions.

eng: She never could accept him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The charm of Kellynch and of "Lady Elliot" all faded away.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Lady Russell said not another word, willing to leave the matter to its own operation; and believing that, could Mr Elliot at that moment with propriety have spoken for himself!--she believed, in short, what Anne did not believe.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The same image of Mr Elliot speaking for himself brought Anne to composure again.
fr: Celle-ci, venant a penser a M. Elliot plaidant lui-meme sa cause, se trouva subitement refroidie, et se dit qu'elle ne l'accepterait jamais.

eng: For a few moments her imagination and her heart were bewitched.
fr: Toutes ces images avaient un charme irresistible.

eng: Anne was obliged to turn away, to rise, to walk to a distant table, and, leaning there in pretended employment, try to subdue the feelings this picture excited.
fr: Anna se leva et s'eloigna pour se remettre de l'emotion que cette peinture excitait en elle : son imagination et son coeur etaient seduits.

eng: My dearest Anne, it would give me more delight than is often felt at my time of life!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: You are your mother's self in countenance and disposition; and if I might be allowed to fancy you such as she was, in situation and name, and home, presiding and blessing in the same spot, and only superior to her in being more highly valued!
fr: Vous etes le portrait de votre mere, ma chere Anna, au physique et au moral, et si vous preniez sa place, votre seule superiorite sur elle serait d'etre plus justement appreciee qu'elle ne le fut. >>

eng: Lady Russell let this pass, and only said in rejoinder, "I own that to be able to regard you as the future mistress of Kellynch, the future Lady Elliot, to look forward and see you occupying your dear mother's place, succeeding to all her rights, and all her popularity, as well as to all her virtues, would be the highest possible gratification to me.
fr: Lady Russel repondit seulement : << J'avoue que ma plus grande joie serait de vous voir la maitresse de Kellynch, la future lady Elliot, occupant la place de votre chere mere, succedant a tous ses droits, a sa popularite, a toutes ses vertus.

eng: The idea of becoming what her mother had been; of having the precious name of "Lady Elliot" first revived in herself; of being restored to Kellynch, calling it her home again, her home for ever, was a charm which she could not immediately resist.
fr: Lady Russel n'ajouta pas un mot, laissant Anna a ses reflexions, et se disant que si M. Elliot plaidait en ce moment sa cause...... En resume, elle croyait ce qu'Anna ne croyait pas encore.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: those letters are convenient passports. ~~~ They secure an introduction.
fr: ces lettres sont des passeports commodes pour etre recus.

eng: Mrs Harville must be an odd mother to part with them so long.
fr: Mme Harville est une etrange mere de s'en separer si longtemps.

eng: The house was cleared yesterday, except of the little Harvilles; but you will be surprised to hear they have never gone home.
fr: La maison a ete debarrassee hier, excepte des petits Harville, et vous serez surprise d'apprendre qu'ils ne sont pas venus chez moi une seule fois.

eng: Anne could listen no longer; she could not even have told how the poor Admiral's complexion escaped; her letter engrossed her. It had been begun several days back. "February 1st."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I do not reckon the Hayters as anybody.
fr: Je ne compte pas les Hayter.

eng: I should have visited Admiral Croft, however, at any rate.
fr: Neanmoins, j'aurais en tout cas visite les Croft.

eng: I know what is due to my tenant.
fr: Je sais ce que je doit a mon locataire.

eng: The holidays, however, are over at last: I believe no children ever had such long ones. I am sure I had not.
fr: Les vacances sont enfin finies. Nous n'en avons jamais eu d'aussi longues quand nous etions enfants.

eng: "My dear Anne,--I make no apology for my silence, because I know how little people think of letters in such a place as Bath.
fr: Ma chere Anna, disait la lettre, je ne m'excuse pas de mon silence, parce qu'on ne doit guere se soucier des lettres a Bath.

eng: We have had a very dull Christmas; Mr and Mrs Musgrove have not had one dinner party all the holidays.
fr: Notre Noel a ete tres triste, les Musgrove n'ont pas donne un seul diner.

eng: You must be a great deal too happy to care for Uppercross, which, as you well know, affords little to write about.
fr: Vous etes trop heureuse pour penser a Uppercross.

eng: I do not understand it. ~~~ They are not at all nice children, in my opinion; but Mrs Musgrove seems to like them quite as well, if not better, than her grandchildren.
fr: Ce ne sont pas de jolis enfants, mais Mme Musgrove semble les aimer autant et meme plus que les siens.

eng: What dreadful weather we have had!
fr: << Quel affreux temps nous avons eu !

eng: Between ourselves, I think it a great pity Henrietta did not remain at Lyme as long as Louisa; it would have kept her a little out of his way.
fr: Entre nous, c'est grand dommage qu'Henriette ne soit pas restee a Lyme aussi longtemps que Louisa, cela l'aurait tenue loin de lui.

eng: I kept my letter open, that I might send you word how Louisa bore her journey, and now I am extremely glad I did, having a great deal to add.
fr: J'ai laisse ma lettre ouverte afin de vous dire comment Louisa a supporte le voyage ; et j'en suis tres contente, car j'ai beaucoup a ajouter.

eng: I have not had a creature call on me since the second week in January, except Charles Hayter, who had been calling much oftener than was welcome.
fr: Je n'ai pas eu une seule visite depuis la deuxieme semaine de janvier, excepte Charles Hayter, qui est venu trop souvent.

eng: I am sorry to say that I am very far from well; and Jemima has just told me that the butcher says there is a bad sore-throat very much about. I dare say I shall catch it; and my sore-throats, you know, are always worse than anybody's.
fr: Je suis fachee de vous dire que je suis loin d'aller bien, et Jemina vient d'apprendre chez le boucher qu'il y a beaucoup d'angines ici. Je crois que j'en aurai une, car mes maux de gorge sont toujours plus dangereux que ceux des autres.

eng: So ended the first part, which had been afterwards put into an envelope, containing nearly as much more.
fr: Ainsi finissait la premiere partie, a laquelle avait ete ajoute ceci :

eng: I have this moment heard that the Crofts are going to Bath almost immediately; they think the Admiral gouty. Charles heard it quite by chance; they have not had the civility to give me any notice, or of offering to take anything. I do not think they improve at all as neighbours. We see nothing of them, and this is really an instance of gross inattention.
fr: J'ai entendu dire que les Croft partaient pour Bath : ils n'ont pas eu l'attention de demander mes commissions ; ils ne sont guere polis ! Nous les voyons a peine, et c'est reellement de leur part un manque d'egards.

eng: I can leave them at the Great House very well, for a month or six weeks.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: What an immense time Mrs Clay has been staying with Elizabeth! Does she never mean to go away? But perhaps if she were to leave the room vacant, we might not be invited. Let me know what you think of this. I do not expect my children to be asked, you know.
fr: Quel temps immense Mme Clay passe avec Elisabeth ! A-t-elle l'intention de s'en aller jamais ? Pensez-vous que nous serions invites si elle laissait la place libre ? Je puis tres bien laisser mes enfants a Great-House pendant un mois ou six semaines.

eng: I am glad you find Mr Elliot so agreeable, and wish I could be acquainted with him too; but I have my usual luck: I am always out of the way when any thing desirable is going on; always the last of my family to be noticed.
fr: Je suis bien aise que vous trouviez M. Elliot si aimable, et je voudrais le connaitre aussi. Mais j'ai la mauvaise chance de n'etre jamais la quand il y a quelque chose d'agreable. Je suis la derniere de la famille dont on s'occupe.

eng: We are not asked to dine with them, however, till the day after, Mrs Musgrove is so afraid of her being fatigued by the journey, which is not very likely, considering the care that will be taken of her; and it would be much more convenient to me to dine there to-morrow.
fr: Nous ne sommes invites a diner avec eux que le surlendemain, tant on craint la fatigue du voyage pour Louisa, ce qui n'est pas probable si l'on pense aux soins dont elle est l'objet. ~~~ J'aimerais bien mieux y diner demain.

eng: The carriage is gone to-day, to bring Louisa and the Harvilles to-morrow.
fr: La voiture vient de partir pour ramener demain Louisa et les Harville.

eng: It may not be felt in Bath, with your nice pavements; but in the country it is of some consequence.
fr: Vous ne vous en apercevez pas a Bath avec vos paves propres. ~~~ A la campagne, c'est autre chose.

eng: Charles joins me in love, and everything proper. Yours affectionately," "Mary M---."
fr: Charles se joint a moi pour vous dire mille choses amicales. << Votre soeur affectionnee, << Marie M. <<

eng: In the first place, I had a note from Mrs Croft yesterday, offering to convey anything to you; a very kind, friendly note indeed, addressed to me, just as it ought; I shall therefore be able to make my letter as long as I like.
fr: D'abord j'ai recu hier un mot de Mme Croft, demandant si j'avais quelque chose a vous envoyer : une lettre tres bonne, tres amicale, et adressee a moi, comme cela doit etre.

eng: The Admiral does not seem very ill, and I sincerely hope Bath will do him all the good he wants.
fr: L'amiral ne semble pas tres malade, et j'espere sincerement que Bath lui fera du bien.

eng: I shall be truly glad to have them back again. ~~~ Our neighbourhood cannot spare such a pleasant family. ~~~ But now for Louisa.
fr: Je serai vraiment heureuse quand ils reviendront : nous ne pouvons pas nous passer d'une si aimable famille.

eng: "I suspect," said Sir Walter coolly, "that Admiral Croft will be best known in Bath as the renter of Kellynch Hall.
fr: -- Je pense, dit posement Sir Walter, que l'amiral sera connu ici comme locataire de Kellynch.

eng: I have something to communicate that will astonish you not a little.
fr: << Maintenant, parlons de Louisa : vous serez bien etonnee.

eng: said Sir Walter.
fr: dit Sir Walter,

eng: "Gout and decrepitude!"
fr: -- La goutte et la decrepitude !

eng: "They come on the Admiral's account. He is thought to be gouty."
fr: -- C'est a cause du general, qui a la goutte.

eng: "How is Mary?" said Elizabeth; and without waiting for an answer, "And pray what brings the Crofts to Bath?"
fr: ~~~ << Comment se porte Marie ? >> dit Elisabeth. Et sans attendre la reponse : << Qu'est-ce qui amene les Croft a Bath ?

eng: Sir Walter wanted to know whether the Crofts travelled with four horses, and whether they were likely to be situated in such a part of Bath as it might suit Miss Elliot and himself to visit in; but had little curiosity beyond.
fr: Sir Walter desirait savoir si les Croft voyageaient a quatre chevaux, s'ils allaient habiter un assez beau quartier pour qu'on put aller les voir.

eng: Happily for her, they were not many.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was almost too wonderful for belief, and it was with the greatest effort that she could remain in the room, preserve an air of calmness, and answer the common questions of the moment.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Captain Benwick and Louisa Musgrove!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had never in her life been more astonished.
fr: Le capitaine Benwick et Louisa Musgrove ! C'etait trop etonnant pour le croire.

eng: Mary need not have feared her sister's being in any degree prepared for the news.
fr: Jamais Anna ne fut plus surprise.

eng: Certainly not a great match for Louisa Musgrove, but a million times better than marrying among the Hayters.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I hope he will be more agreeable now.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: How Charles could take such a thing into his head was always incomprehensible to me.
fr: Il est incomprehensible pour moi que Charles ait pu se mettre cela dans la tete.

eng: And this is the end, you see, of Captain Benwick's being supposed to be an admirer of yours.
fr: << Et voila la fin de la supposition que Benwick etait votre adorateur !

eng: Charles wonders what Captain Wentworth will say; but if you remember, I never thought him attached to Louisa; I never could see anything of it.
fr: Charles se demande ce que dira Wenvorth mais vous vous souvenez que je n'ai jamais cru a son attachement pour Louisa.

eng: Indeed, Mrs Harville and I quite agree that we love her the better for having nursed her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mrs Harville says her husband feels a good deal on his poor sister's account; but, however, Louisa is a great favourite with both.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: We are all very well pleased, however, for though it is not equal to her marrying Captain Wentworth, it is infinitely better than Charles Hayter; and Mr Musgrove has written his consent, and Captain Benwick is expected to-day.
fr: Nous sommes tres contents, car ce mariage, quoique moins bon que celui du capitaine Wenvorth, est un million de fois meilleur que celui de Charles Hayter. M. Musgrove a donne son consentement. On attend le capitaine Benwick.

eng: Are not you astonished?
fr: Je serais surprise que vous sachiez cela, car on ne m'en a rien dit.

eng: True, upon my honour!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Neither more nor less than his being in love with Louisa, and not choosing to venture to Uppercross till he had had an answer from Mr Musgrove; for it was all settled between him and her before she came away, and he had written to her father by Captain Harville.
fr: Il fait la cour a Louisa, et n'a pas voulu venir avant d'avoir recu la reponse de M. Musgrove a sa demande ecrite.

eng: and what do you think was the reason?
fr: Et devinez-vous pourquoi il n'y etait pas ?

eng: She and the Harvilles came on Tuesday very safely, and in the evening we went to ask her how she did, when we were rather surprised not to find Captain Benwick of the party, for he had been invited as well as the Harvilles;
fr: Elle est arrivee mardi. Le soir, en allant prendre de ses nouvelles, nous fumes surpris de ne pas trouver Benwick, car il avait ete invite aussi.

eng: "I do not know; but I can hardly suppose that, at Admiral Croft's time of life, and in his profession, he should not have many acquaintance in such a place as this."
fr: -- Je ne sais pas. Mais, a l'age de l'amiral et avec sa profession, il ne doit pas manquer de connaissances dans une ville comme Bath.

eng: "Poor old gentleman."
fr: pauvre vieux gentilhomme !

eng: "Have they any acquaintance here?" asked Elizabeth.
fr: -- Connaissent-ils quelqu'un ici ? demanda Elisabeth.

eng: No, it was not regret which made Anne's heart beat in spite of herself, and brought the colour into her cheeks when she thought of Captain Wentworth unshackled and free.
fr: Non, ce n'etait pas le regret qui, en depit d'elle-meme, faisait battre le coeur d'Anna et lui mettait la rougeur aux joues, quand elle pensait que Wenvorth etait libre !

eng: She did not mean, however, to derive much more from it to gratify her vanity, than Mary might have allowed.
fr: Mais elle n'en tirait point vanite.

eng: That was a point which Anne had not been able to avoid suspecting before; and instead of drawing the same conclusion as Mary, from the present course of events, they served only to confirm the idea of his having felt some dawning of tenderness toward herself.
fr: Anna, au lieu de tirer du present les memes conclusions que Marie, soupconnait que Benwick avait eu un commencement d'inclination pour elle.

eng: They had been thrown together several weeks; they had been living in the same small family party: since Henrietta's coming away, they must have been depending almost entirely on each other, and Louisa, just recovering from illness, had been in an interesting state, and Captain Benwick was not inconsolable.
fr: Louisa relevant de maladie etait plus interessante, et Benwick moins inconsolable.

eng: The answer soon presented itself. It had been in situation.
fr: Mais ils s'etaient trouves ensemble pendant plusieurs semaines ; ils avaient vecu dans le meme petit cercle.

eng: Where could have been the attraction?
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Their minds most dissimilar!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The high-spirited, joyous-talking Louisa Musgrove, and the dejected, thinking, feeling, reading, Captain Benwick, seemed each of them everything that would not suit the other.
fr: La vive et gaie Louisa, et le triste et sentimental Benwick ! les derniers entre tous qui semblaient se convenir !

eng: Captain Benwick and Louisa Musgrove!
fr: Le capitaine Benwick et Louisa Musgrove !

eng: She could not endure that such a friendship as theirs should be severed unfairly.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She could not endure the idea of treachery or levity, or anything akin to ill usage between him and his friend.
fr: Elle ne pouvait admettre l'idee de legerete ou de trahison.

eng: Perhaps he had quitted the field, had given Louisa up, had ceased to love, had found he did not love her.
fr: Peut-etre Wenvorth, s'apercevant qu'il n'aimait pas Louisa, s'etait-il retire ?

eng: Well might Charles wonder how Captain Wentworth would feel!
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: In her own room, she tried to comprehend it.
fr: Une fois dans sa chambre, elle chercha a comprendre.

eng: Here I am, you see, staring at a picture. I can never get by this shop without stopping.
fr: Mais est-ce la un bateau ? Regardez.

eng: This was Sir Walter and Elizabeth's share of interest in the letter; when Mrs Clay had paid her tribute of more decent attention, in an enquiry after Mrs Charles Musgrove, and her fine little boys, Anne was at liberty.
fr: Ce fut tout l'interet qu'Elisabeth prit a la lettre de Marie, et quand Mme Clay se fut informee poliment de Mme Musgrove et de ses charmants enfants, on laissa Anna tranquille.

eng: There are several odd-looking men walking about here, who, I am told, are sailors. The Crofts will associate with them."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: We had better leave the Crofts to find their own level.
fr: Il vaut mieux laisser les Croft avec leurs egaux.

eng: If we were not related, it would not signify; but as cousins, she would feel scrupulous as to any proposal of ours.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Situated as we are with Lady Dalrymple, cousins, we ought to be very careful not to embarrass her with acquaintance she might not approve.
fr: nous sommes cousins de lady Dalrymph, et nous ne devons pas lui imposer des connaissances qu'elle pourrait desapprouver.

eng: "Oh, no! I think not.
fr: -- Je ne crois pas ;

eng: Elizabeth, may we venture to present him and his wife in Laura Place?"
fr: Elisabeth, pouvons-nous nous aventurer a les presenter a Laura-Place ?

eng: She was persuaded that any tolerably pleasing young woman who had listened and seemed to feel for him would have received the same compliment.
fr: Benwick lui avait ete reconnaissant de la sympathie qu'elle lui avait montree.

eng: But what a thing here is, by way of a boat! Do look at it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He had an affectionate heart.
fr: Il avait un coeur aimant.

eng: She saw no reason against their being happy.
fr: Elle pensait qu'ils pouvaient etre heureux :

eng: He was standing by himself at a printshop window, with his hands behind him, in earnest contemplation of some print, and she not only might have passed him unseen, but was obliged to touch as well as address him before she could catch his notice.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Anne was too much engaged with Lady Russell to be often walking herself; but it so happened that one morning, about a week or ten days after the Croft's arrival, it suited her best to leave her friend, or her friend's carriage, in the lower part of the town, and return alone to Camden Place, and in walking up Milsom Street she had the good fortune to meet with the Admiral.
fr: Un matin, Anna, traversant Milton-Street, rencontra l'amiral ; il etait seul, et si occupe a regarder des gravures, qu'il ne la vit pas d'abord.

eng: She always watched them as long as she could, delighted to fancy she understood what they might be talking of, as they walked along in happy independence, or equally delighted to see the Admiral's hearty shake of the hand when he encountered an old friend, and observe their eagerness of conversation when occasionally forming into a little knot of the navy, Mrs Croft looking as intelligent and keen as any of the officers around her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Knowing their feelings as she did, it was a most attractive picture of happiness to her.
fr: Mme Croft, au milieu d'eux, paraissait aussi intelligente et aussi fine qu'aucun des officiers qui l'entouraient.

eng: Lady Russell took her out in her carriage almost every morning, and she never failed to think of them, and never failed to see them.
fr: Elle les suivait longtemps des yeux, ravie de pouvoir s'imaginer ce qu'ils disaient marchant cote a cote, heureux et independants ; ou de voir quelle cordiale poignee de mains l'amiral donnait a un ami, et le groupe anime qu'il formait parfois avec d'autres marins.

eng: Anne saw them wherever she went.
fr: Ils etaient pour elle l'image du bonheur.

eng: He was ordered to walk to keep off the gout, and Mrs Croft seemed to go shares with him in everything, and to walk for her life to do him good.
fr: La marche etait ordonnee a l'amiral pour guerir sa goutte, et Anna les rencontrait partout.

eng: They brought with them their country habit of being almost always together.
fr: Les Croft apportaient a Bath leur habitude de province d'etre toujours ensemble.

eng: The Crofts knew quite as many people in Bath as they wished for, and considered their intercourse with the Elliots as a mere matter of form, and not in the least likely to afford them any pleasure.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was not at all ashamed of the acquaintance, and did, in fact, think and talk a great deal more about the Admiral, than the Admiral ever thought or talked about him.
fr: Des lors il ne rougit pas de les connaitre, et parla beaucoup plus de l'amiral que celui-ci n'avait jamais parle de lui.

eng: The Crofts had placed themselves in lodgings in Gay Street, perfectly to Sir Walter's satisfaction.
fr: Les Croft, a la parfaite satisfaction de Sir Walter, se logerent dans Gay-Street.

eng: The visit of ceremony was paid and returned; and Louisa Musgrove was mentioned, and Captain Benwick, too, without even half a smile.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She longed to see the Crofts; but when the meeting took place, it was evident that no rumour of the news had yet reached them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They were too much like joy, senseless joy!
fr: Ils ressemblaient trop a de la joie : une joie immense.

eng: She had some feelings which she was ashamed to investigate.
fr: Elle avait honte d'analyser ses sentiments.

eng: This is treating me like a friend.
fr: je ne puis passer ici sans m'y arreter.

eng: The conclusion of the whole was, that if the woman who had been sensible of Captain Wentworth's merits could be allowed to prefer another man, there was nothing in the engagement to excite lasting wonder; and if Captain Wentworth lost no friend by it, certainly nothing to be regretted.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The day at Lyme, the fall from the Cobb, might influence her health, her nerves, her courage, her character to the end of her life, as thoroughly as it appeared to have influenced her fate.
fr: L'accident arrive a Lyme avait pu avoir une influence sur sa sante et son caractere aussi bien que sur sa destinee.

eng: The idea of Louisa Musgrove turned into a person of literary taste, and sentimental reflection was amusing, but she had no doubt of its being so.
fr: L'idee de Louisa, devenue personne litteraire et sentimentale, etait amusante.

eng: He would gain cheerfulness, and she would learn to be an enthusiast for Scott and Lord Byron; nay, that was probably learnt already; of course they had fallen in love over poetry.
fr: Mais c'etait deja fait probablement ; la poesie avait rapproche leurs coeurs.

eng: Louisa had fine naval fervour to begin with, and they would soon grow more alike.
fr: lui gagnerait de la gaite, elle de l'enthousiasme pour Byron ou Walter Scott.

eng: He must love somebody.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: When he did perceive and acknowledge her, however, it was done with all his usual frankness and good humour.
fr: Quand il l'eut apercue, il dit avec sa bonne humeur habituelle :

eng: "Ha! is it you? Thank you, thank you.
fr: << Ah ! c'est vous. Vous me voyez plante devant ce tableau :

eng: Did you ever see the like?
fr: En avez-vous jamais vu un pareil ?

eng: Well," (turning away), "now, where are you bound?
fr: Maintenant, ou allez-vous ?

eng: There, take my arm; that's right; I do not feel comfortable if I have not a woman there.
fr: Prenez mon bras ; je ne me sens pas a l'aise si je n'ai pas le bras d'une femme.

eng: "That I will, with all my heart, and farther, too. Yes, yes we will have a snug walk together, and I have something to tell you as we go along.
fr: -- Certainement, de tout mon coeur. Nous ferons une bonne promenade, et j'ai quelque chose a vous dire.

eng: "None, I thank you, unless you will give me the pleasure of your company the little way our road lies together. I am going home."
fr: -- Non, merci, a moins de faire route avec moi. Je vais a la maison.

eng: Can I go anywhere for you, or with you? Can I be of any use?"
fr: Puis-je vous accompagner, ou faire quelque chose pour vous ?

eng: "Yes, I have, presently. But here comes a friend, Captain Brigden; I shall only say, 'How d'ye do?' as we pass, however. I shall not stop.
fr: -- Oui ; mais voici un ami, le capitaine Bridgdem. Je veux seulement lui demander comment il va, en passant. Il est surpris de me voir avec une autre femme que la mienne.

eng: I wonder where that boat was built!" ~~~ (laughing heartily); "I would not venture over a horsepond in it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And yet here are two gentlemen stuck up in it mightily at their ease, and looking about them at the rocks and mountains, as if they were not to be upset the next moment, which they certainly must be.
fr: Et cependant, voila deux personnages qui y semblent parfaitement a l'aise. Ils regardent les rochers et les montagnes comme s'ils n'allaient pas etre culbutes, ce qui arrivera certainement.

eng: What queer fellows your fine painters must be, to think that anybody would venture their lives in such a shapeless old cockleshell as that?
fr: Vos peintres sont etonnants, s'ils croient qu'on voudrait risquer sa vie dans cette vieille coquille de noix informe.

eng: "Did you say that you had something to tell me, sir?"
fr: -- Vous avez quelque chose a me dire ?

eng: 'How d'ye do?' Brigden stares to see anybody with me but my wife.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She, poor soul, is tied by the leg. She has a blister on one of her heels, as large as a three-shilling piece.
fr: La pauvre ame est prise par la jambe ; elle a au talon une ampoule presque aussi large qu'une piece de cinq francs.

eng: If you look across the street, you will see Admiral Brand coming down and his brother. Shabby fellows, both of them!
fr: Voyez-vous l'amiral Brand qui vient vers nous avec son frere ? Habits rapes tous deux ; je suis content qu'ils soient de l'autre cote de la rue.

eng: I am glad they are not on this side of the way. Sophy cannot bear them. They played me a pitiful trick once: got away with some of my best men. I will tell you the whole story another time.
fr: Sophie ne peut pas les souffrir. Ils m'ont joue autrefois un vilain tour, je vous conterai cela.

eng: There comes old Sir Archibald Drew and his grandson.
fr: Voici le vieux Sir Archibald et son petit-fils.

eng: Lord! what a boat it is!" taking a last look at the picture, as they began to be in motion.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Look, he sees us; he kisses his hand to you; he takes you for my wife.
fr: Regardez, il nous voit. ~~~ Il vous envoie un baiser, et vous prend pour ma femme.

eng: Ah!
fr: Ah !

eng: the peace has come too soon for that younker.
fr: la paix est venue trop tot pour ce jeune homme.

eng: Poor old Sir Archibald!
fr: Pauvre vieux Sir Archibald !

eng: It suits us very well. We are always meeting with some old friend or other; the streets full of them every morning; sure to have plenty of chat; and then we get away from them all, and shut ourselves in our lodgings, and draw in our chairs, and are as snug as if we were at Kellynch, ay, or as we used to be even at North Yarmouth and Deal. We do not like our lodgings here the worse, I can tell you, for putting us in mind of those we first had at North Yarmouth. The wind blows through one of the cupboards just in the same way."
fr: Bath me convient tres bien ; nous rencontrons toujours quelque vieil ami. On est sur de pouvoir bavarder, puis, rentres chez nous, nous nous plongeons dans nos fauteuils, et nous sommes aussi bien qu'a Kellynch. >>

eng: She hoped when clear of Milsom Street to have her curiosity gratified; but she was still obliged to wait, for the Admiral had made up his mind not to begin till they had gained the greater space and quiet of Belmont; and as she was not really Mrs Croft, she must let him have his own way.
fr: Mais elle fut obligee d'attendre, car l'amiral s'etait mis en tete de ne parler que sur la place Belmont.

eng: As soon as they were fairly ascending Belmont, he began-- "Well, now you shall hear something that will surprise you.
fr: << Maintenant, dit-il, vous allez entendre quelque chose de surprenant ;

eng: But first of all, you must tell me the name of the young lady I am going to talk about. That young lady, you know, that we have all been so concerned for. The Miss Musgrove, that all this has been happening to. Her Christian name: I always forget her Christian name."
fr: mais d'abord dites-moi le nom de la cadette des misses Musgrove. Je l'oublie toujours. ~~~ >>

eng: Anne had been ashamed to appear to comprehend so soon as she really did; but now she could safely suggest the name of "Louisa."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Ay, ay, Miss Louisa Musgrove, that is the name.'
fr: << Oui, Louisa Musgrove, c'est cela.

eng: How do you like Bath, Miss Elliot?
fr: << Aimez-vous Bath, miss Elliot ?

eng: When they were got a little farther, Anne ventured to press again for what he had to communicate.
fr: Anna le pressa de lui dire ce qu'il avait a lui communiquer.

eng: I wish young ladies had not such a number of fine Christian names. ~~~ I should never be out if they were all Sophys, or something of that sort.
fr: Si les jeunes filles n'avaient pas d'aussi beaux noms, et s'appelaient simplement Sophie ou Marie, je ne me tromperais jamais.

eng: Even Sophy could not understand it.
fr: Sophie elle-meme n'y comprend rien,

eng: Nay, most likely they are married already, for I do not know what they should wait for."
fr: car je ne vois pas pourquoi ils attendraient.

eng: "Well, she is to marry him.
fr: Eh bien, ils doivent etre maries deja,

eng: "A little. I am a little acquainted with Captain Benwick."
fr: -- Un peu.

eng: Well, this Miss Louisa, we all thought, you know, was to marry Frederick.
fr: Eh bien ! nous pensions que cette miss Louisa allait epouser Frederic.

eng: He was courting her week after week.
fr: Depuis quelque temps il lui faisait la cour.

eng: The only wonder was, what they could be waiting for, till the business at Lyme came;
fr: On se demandait seulement pourquoi ils attendaient, quand arriva l'accident de Lyme.

eng: then, indeed, it was clear enough that they must wait till her brain was set to right.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But even then there was something odd in their way of going on.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Instead of staying at Lyme, he went off to Plymouth, and then he went off to see Edward.
fr: Frederic, au lieu de rester a Lyme, alla a Plymouth, puis il partit pour aller voir Edouard, et il y est encore.

eng: When we came back from Minehead he was gone down to Edward's, and there he has been ever since.
fr: Nous ne l'avons pas vu depuis novembre.

eng: We have seen nothing of him since November.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, partially covered by previous sentence)

eng: You know James Benwick.
fr: Vous le connaissez ?

eng: But now, the matter has taken the strangest turn of all;
fr: Mais aujourd'hui les choses ont pris le tour le plus etrange,

eng: for this young lady, the same Miss Musgrove, instead of being to marry Frederick, is to marry James Benwick.
fr: car cette jeune miss Musgrove, au lieu d'epouser Frederic, se marie avec James Benwick.

eng: "I thought Captain Benwick a very pleasing young man," said Anne, "and I understand that he bears an excellent character."
fr: -- Le capitaine Benwick est un homme tres aimable, et on lui donne un excellent caractere.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: yes, yes, there is not a word to be said against James Benwick.
fr: oui, il n'y a rien a dire contre lui.

eng: He is only a commander, it is true, made last summer, and these are bad times for getting on, but he has not another fault that I know of.
fr: Il n'est commandant que de l'annee derniere, il est vrai, et le moment est mauvais pour avoir de l'avancement, mais je ne lui connais pas d'autre defaut.

eng: An excellent, good-hearted fellow, I assure you; a very active, zealous officer too, which is more than you would think for, perhaps, for that soft sort of manner does not do him justice."
fr: C'est un excellent garcon, un officier actif et zele, plus que vous ne le croyez, peut-etre, car son air tranquille ne lui rend pas justice.

eng: "Indeed you are mistaken there, sir; I should never augur want of spirit from Captain Benwick's manners.
fr: -- Vous vous trompez, monsieur ; les manieres du capitaine ne me font pas supposer qu'il manque d'energie.

eng: I thought them particularly pleasing, and I will answer for it, they would generally please."
fr: Je les trouve tres agreables, et je suis sure qu'elles plaisent generalement.

eng: "Well, well, ladies are the best judges; but James Benwick is rather too piano for me; and though very likely it is all our partiality, Sophy and I cannot help thinking Frederick's manners better than his. There is something about Frederick more to our taste."
fr: '-- Bien, bien ; les dames sont les meilleurs juges ; mais James Benwick est un peu trop tranquille pour moi. C'est probablement l'effet de notre partialite, mais Sophie et moi, nous preferons les manieres de Frederic.'

eng: "Anne was caught. She had only meant to oppose the too common idea of spirit and gentleness being incompatible with each other, not at all to represent Captain Benwick's manners as the very best that could possibly be; and, after a little hesitation, she was beginning to say, "I was not entering into any comparison of the two friends," but the Admiral interrupted her with--"
fr: '-- Je n'avais pas l'intention, dit Anna apres un peu d'hesitation, de comparer les deux amis.'

eng: "And the thing is certainly true. It is not a mere bit of gossip. We have it from Frederick himself. His sister had a letter from him yesterday, in which he tells us of it, and he had just had it in a letter from Harville, written upon the spot, from Uppercross. I fancy they are all at Uppercross."
fr: '~~~ >> Mais l'amiral l'interrompit : << La nouvelle du mariage est certainement vraie, il n'y a pas la de cancans. Nous le savons par Frederic lui-meme, qui l'a ecrit a sa soeur. Je pense qu'ils sont tous a Uppercross ? >>'

eng: "This was an opportunity which Anne could not resist; she said, therefore, "I hope, Admiral, I hope there is nothing in the style of Captain Wentworth's letter to make you and Mrs Croft particularly uneasy. It did seem, last autumn, as if there were an attachment between him and Louisa Musgrove; but I hope it may be understood to have worn out on each side equally, and without violence. I hope his letter does not breathe the spirit of an ill-used man."
fr: 'Anna ne put resister a la tentation de dire : << J'espere, amiral, qu'il n'y a rien dans la lettre du capitaine qui puisse vous faire de peine. Il semblait exister un attachement entre lui et Louisa a l'automne dernier ; mais j'aime a croire qu'il s'en est alle de part et d'autre sans dechirement ! J'espere que le capitaine n'a a se plaindre de personne.'

eng: "Not at all, not at all; there is not an oath or a murmur from beginning to end."
fr: '-- Non, certainement ; Frederic n'est pas un homme a gemir et a se plaindre.'

eng: "Certainly. But what I mean is, that I hope there is nothing in Captain Wentworth's manner of writing to make you suppose he thinks himself ill-used by his friend, which might appear, you know, without its being absolutely said. I should be very sorry that such a friendship as has subsisted between him and Captain Benwick should be destroyed, or even wounded, by a circumstance of this sort."
fr: '-- Vous avez raison ; j'espere seulement que le capitaine n'a pas a se plaindre de son ami. Je serais bien fachee que leur amitie fut detruite, ou meme refroidie par une chose semblable.'

eng: "No, no; Frederick is not a man to whine and complain; he has too much spirit for that. If the girl likes another man better, it is very fit she should have him."
fr: 'Il a trop d'esprit pour cela. Si la jeune fille en prefere un autre, qu'elle le prenne.'

eng: "Yes, yes, I understand you.
fr: -- Oui, oui, je vous comprends.

eng: For a few minutes she saw nothing before her; it was all confusion.
fr: Pour la premiere fois, elle trahissait moins d'emotion que lui.

eng: She saw that he saw Elizabeth, that Elizabeth saw him, that there was complete internal recognition on each side; she was convinced that he was ready to be acknowledged as an acquaintance, expecting it, and she had the pain of seeing her sister turn away with unalterable coldness.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It did not surprise, but it grieved Anne to observe that Elizabeth would not know him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He looked very well, not as if he had been suffering in health or spirits, and he talked of Uppercross, of the Musgroves, nay, even of Louisa, and had even a momentary look of his own arch significance as he named her; but yet it was Captain Wentworth not comfortable, not easy, not able to feign that he was.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was consciousness of some sort or other.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Time had changed him, or Louisa had changed him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They had by dint of being so very much together, got to speak to each other with a considerable portion of apparent indifference and calmness; but he could not do it now.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mutual enquiries on common subjects passed: neither of them, probably, much the wiser for what they heard, and Anne continuing fully sensible of his being less at ease than formerly.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: After a short interval, however, he came towards her, and spoke again.
fr: << Miss Elliot ne deplait pas a son cousin, je crois ? -- Oh ! c'est assez clair. On peut deviner ce qui arrivera.'

eng: She could not have called it either cold or friendly, or anything so certainly as embarrassed.
fr: Quand ils furent partis, les dames qui etaient avec le capitaine se mirent a parler d'eux.

eng: The character of his manner was embarrassment.
fr: En sortant, Anna ne put jeter a Wenvorth qu'un bonjour, accompagne d'un doux et timide regard.

eng: He spoke to her, and then turned away.
fr: ~~~ Il lui offrit son bras.

eng: It was agitation, pain, pleasure, a something between delight and misery.
fr: Sa maniere d'etre et ses facons etaient celles d'un parent, ou d'un ami privilegie.

eng: Still, however, she had enough to feel!
fr: Wenvorth le reconnut, c'etait bien celui qu'il avait vu a Lyme s'arreter sur l'escalier pour admirer Anna.

eng: All the overpowering, blinding, bewildering, first effects of strong surprise were over with her.
fr: Elle parlait encore quand il entra.

eng: She had the advantage of him in the preparation of the last few moments.
fr: Elle refusa, disant qu'elle attendait M. Elliot.

eng: Lady Dalrymple's carriage, for which Miss Elliot was growing very impatient, now drew up; the servant came in to announce it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It was beginning to rain again, and altogether there was a delay, and a bustle, and a talking, which must make all the little crowd in the shop understand that Lady Dalrymple was calling to convey Miss Elliot.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: At last Miss Elliot and her friend, unattended but by the servant, (for there was no cousin returned), were walking off; and Captain Wentworth, watching them, turned again to Anne, and by manner, rather than words, was offering his services to her.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I am much obliged to you," was her answer, "but I am not going with them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: One can guess what will happen there.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Oh! no, that is clear enough.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Mr Elliot does not dislike his cousin, I fancy?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: As soon as they were out of sight, the ladies of Captain Wentworth's party began talking of them.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He came in with eagerness, appeared to see and think only of her, apologised for his stay, was grieved to have kept her waiting, and anxious to get her away without further loss of time and before the rain increased; and in another moment they walked off together, her arm under his, a gentle and embarrassed glance, and a "Good morning to you!" being all that she had time for, as she passed away.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was no difference between him and the man who had stood on the steps at Lyme, admiring Anne as she passed, except in the air and look and manner of the privileged relation and friend.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Captain Wentworth recollected him perfectly.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She had hardly spoken the words when Mr Elliot walked in.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He will be here in a moment, I am sure."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She was very much obliged to him, but declined it all, repeating her conviction, that the rain would come to nothing at present, and adding, "I am only waiting for Mr Elliot.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She was lost, and when she had scolded back her senses, she found the others still waiting for the carriage, and Mr Elliot (always obliging) just setting off for Union Street on a commission of Mrs Clay's.
fr: Elle avait pu se preparer, et pourtant elle etait emue. Il lui dit quelques mots.

eng: "Oh! very little, Nothing that I regard."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "But it rains."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I walk: I prefer walking."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The carriage would not accommodate so many.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: For the first time, since their renewed acquaintance, she felt that she was betraying the least sensibility of the two.
fr: Apres un silence, il dit, en montrant son parapluie : << Quoique arrive d'hier, je me suis deja equipe pour Bath. Prenez-le si vous tenez a marcher ; mais il serait plus prudent de me laisser chercher une voiture. >>

eng: He was more obviously struck and confused by the sight of her than she had ever observed before; he looked quite red.
fr: << Je vous remercie, dit-elle. Je ne monte pas en voiture ; il n'y a pas de place, et je prefere marcher. pa -- Mais il pleut. -- Oh ! tres peu ; je n'y prends pas garde >>.

eng: After a moment's pause he said: "Though I came only yesterday, I have equipped myself properly for Bath already, you see," (pointing to a new umbrella); "I wish you would make use of it, if you are determined to walk; though I think it would be more prudent to let me get you a chair."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She would see if it rained.
fr: La pluie recommencait ; il y eut dans la petite boutique un mouvement qui apprit aux assistants que lady Dalrymph venait chercher miss Elliot.

eng: Mr Elliot was attending his two cousins and Mrs Clay.
fr: Elle etait avec sa soeur, M. Elliot et Mme Clay ; on traversait la rue Nelson, il commencait a pleuvoir.

eng: They were in Milsom Street.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: It began to rain, not much, but enough to make shelter desirable for women, and quite enough to make it very desirable for Miss Elliot to have the advantage of being conveyed home in Lady Dalrymple's carriage, which was seen waiting at a little distance;
fr: Les dames entrerent dans un magasin, tandis que M. Elliot s'avancait vers lady Dalrymph, dont la voiture stationnait a quelques pas de la, et lui demandait de prendre ces dames.

eng: she, Anne, and Mrs Clay, therefore, turned into Molland's, while Mr Elliot stepped to Lady Dalrymple, to request her assistance.
fr: Mais la caleche ne contenait que quatre places, et miss Carteret etait avec sa mere.

eng: He soon joined them again, successful, of course; Lady Dalrymple would be most happy to take them home, and would call for them in a few minutes.
fr: Une place appartenait de droit a miss Elliot l'ainee ; mais il y eut un debat de politesse entre Mme Clay et Anna, pour la seconde place.

eng: She now felt a great inclination to go to the outer door; she wanted to see if it rained.
fr: Il n'etait ni froid ni amical, mais embarrasse.

eng: Miss Carteret was with her mother; consequently it was not reasonable to expect accommodation for all the three Camden Place ladies.
fr: Mais miss Elliot affirma que Mme Clay avait deja pris froid ; et M. Elliot soutint que les bottines d'Anna etaient les plus solides ; cela mit fin au debat.

eng: There could be no doubt as to Miss Elliot.
fr: Tout a coup, Anna, assise pres de la fenetre, apercut Wenvorth, qui descendait la rue.

eng: Whoever suffered inconvenience, she must suffer none, but it occupied a little time to settle the point of civility between the other two.
fr: Elle ne put s'empecher de tressaillir, tout en se disant que c'etait absurde.

eng: The rain was a mere trifle, and Anne was most sincere in preferring a walk with Mr Elliot.
fr: Pendant quelques minutes, elle ne vit rien ; tout etait confus autour d'elle.

eng: But the rain was also a mere trifle to Mrs Clay; she would hardly allow it even to drop at all, and her boots were so thick! much thicker than Miss Anne's; and, in short, her civility rendered her quite as anxious to be left to walk with Mr Elliot as Anne could be, and it was discussed between them with a generosity so polite and so determined, that the others were obliged to settle it for them;
fr: Quand elle put se remettre, on attendait encore la voiture, et M. Elliot s'appretait a faire une commission pour Mme Clay.

eng: Miss Elliot maintaining that Mrs Clay had a little cold already, and Mr Elliot deciding on appeal, that his cousin Anne's boots were rather the thickest.
fr: Elle alla vers la porte pour voir s'il pleuvait. Quel autre motif aurait-elle eu ?

eng: It was fixed accordingly, that Mrs Clay should be of the party in the carriage; and they had just reached this point, when Anne, as she sat near the window, descried, most decidedly and distinctly, Captain Wentworth walking down the street.
fr: Le capitaine devait etre parti ? Elle rebroussa chemin en voyant entrer le capitaine Wenvorth lui-meme avec plusieurs dames et gentlemen.

eng: She was sent back, however, in a moment by the entrance of Captain Wentworth himself, among a party of gentlemen and ladies, evidently his acquaintance, and whom he must have joined a little below Milsom Street.
fr: Alors le capitaine, se tournant vers Anna, lui offrit ses services plutot par son attitude que par ses paroles.

eng: Her start was perceptible only to herself; but she instantly felt that she was the greatest simpleton in the world, the most unaccountable and absurd!
fr: La vue d'Anna parut le troubler ; il rougit extremement.

eng: Before Mrs Croft had written, he was arrived, and the very next time Anne walked out, she saw him.
fr: Anna l'apercut la premiere fois qu'elle sortit.

eng: While Admiral Croft was taking this walk with Anne, and expressing his wish of getting Captain Wentworth to Bath, Captain Wentworth was already on his way thither.
fr: Tandis que l'amiral parlait de Wenvorth, celui-ci etait deja en route.

eng: Her ladyship's carriage was a barouche, and did not hold more than four with any comfort.
fr: Anna se souciait peu de la pluie et preferait marcher ; Mme Clay ne la craignait pas non plus, et etait d'ailleurs solidement chaussee.

eng: Do not you think, Miss Elliot, we had better try to get him to Bath?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Why was she to suspect herself of another motive?
fr: Anna vit avec peine, mais sans surprise, qu'Elisabeth ne voulait pas reconnaitre M. Wenvorth.

eng: 'But there is nothing at all of that nature in the letter.
fr: 'Mais sa lettre n'en dit rien.

eng: He does not give the least fling at Benwick; does not so much as say, 'I wonder at it, I have a reason of my own for wondering at it.'
fr: Il ne temoigne pas meme le plus leger etonnement.

eng: No, you would not guess, from his way of writing, that he had ever thought of this Miss (what's her name?) for himself.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He very handsomely hopes they will be happy together; and there is nothing very unforgiving in that, I think."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Anne did not receive the perfect conviction which the Admiral meant to convey, but it would have been useless to press the enquiry farther.
fr: Anna ne fut pas aussi convaincue que l'amiral. Mais il etait inutile d'en demander davantage.

eng: She therefore satisfied herself with common-place remarks or quiet attention, and the Admiral had it all his own way.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Poor Frederick!"
fr: Pauvre Frederic,

eng: said he at last.
fr: dit l'amiral ;

eng: Chapter 19
fr: CHAPITRE XIX

eng: "Now he must begin all over again with somebody else.
fr: il faut qu'il recommence a nouveaux frais.

eng: I think we must get him to Bath.
fr: Sophie doit lui ecrire de venir ; il y a ici de jolies filles, il me semble.

eng: Sophy must write, and beg him to come to Bath.
fr: Il serait inutile d'aller a Uppercross a present, car l'autre miss Musgrove est recherchee par son cousin, le jeune ministre.

eng: Here are pretty girls enough, I am sure.
fr: Ne pensez-vous pas, miss Elliot, qu'il fera mieux de venir a Bath ?

eng: It would be of no use to go to Uppercross again, for that other Miss Musgrove, I find, is bespoke by her cousin, the young parson.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She left her seat, she would go; one half of her should not be always so much wiser than the other half, or always suspecting the other of being worse than it was.
fr: Bientot un domestique annonca la voiture de lady Dalrymph.

eng: Captain Wentworth must be out of sight.
fr: Il n'attendait qu'un signe d'elle pour la saluer, mais elle se detourna avec une froideur glaciale.

eng: He is always with them; half lives in the family, I believe.
